ISED (Integrated System Energy Designer) - At a Glance

ISED (Integrated System Energy Designer) is a tool that Siemens has specifically developed for the sizing and evaluation of Distributed Energy Systems (DES). ISED takes user defined configurations, and then simulates the plant's performance over its designed lifetime.

Basic Functionality

ISED is built around a core idea: Engineers need access to good information in order to make good recommendations about the feasibility of distributed energy systems. Specifically, ISED exists to provide these engineers with a tool that allows them to analyze complex combinations of systems in order to evaluate the technical and economic feasibility throughout the design, commissioning, and operation phases of such systems. There are two main operating modes to ISED. Decarbonization Study and Dispatch Optimization.

User Interface Basics

Title Bar

The top part of the windows contains a title bar with the name of the software. When a project name is given, it displays the name of the project after the software name. To move the software window, click the title bar and drag the mouse.

Menu Bar

In the upper left corner the User Interface(UI) contains five menus:

File Menu Compare Menu Import Menu Results Menu

File Menu

The File menu contains seven entries:

  • Load Loads a project setup from disk.
  • Save Saves the current project setup.
  • Save as Saves the current project setup as a new file.
  • New Creates a new and empty project.
  • Open Existing Database Loads a results database from a former simulation run. It populates the results view and does not change the current project settings.

Compare Menu

The Compare Menu contains the entries:

Assets Projects

Assets opens a new window, in which a detailed comparison of two assets of the same type can be started. The toolbox area is divided into two parts: On the left, the source asset can be selected and on the right, the target asset can be selected.

The first combo box (on both sides) filters where the asset comes from:

  • Assets All assets from the currently loaded project.
  • Asset Library Available assets from the asset library.
  • File System Assets that have been saved to disk: ISED asset files have the file extension .sasset or .xml. Use the file dialog button next to the combo box to select the file.
Compare assets window

As long as the type of the assets is the same (e.g. Genset/Genset) every combination is valid. This allows, for example, to compare an asset from the current project with an asset from the file system. The second combo box selects the name of the asset, which is used for the comparison. Once two valid assets have been selected, the comparison starts automatically.

If the values of a parameter are visualized as a graph, the following principles apply:

  • If both graphs are equal, only one graph is painted with green graph coordinates (small squares).
  • If both graphs are different, two graphs are drawn. The graph coordinates (small squares) of the left asset are always drawn in blue whereas the graph coordinates of the target asset are always drawn in red.
  • If one of the assets has a variation, which the other asset does not have, only one graph is painted in the corresponding color: the left asset with blue graph coordinates and the right asset with red graph coordinates

Projects opens a new window, in which a source and a target project can be compared. The source project is always the currently loaded project. The target project is selected in the file dialog. The project comparison is started after the target project has been selected. As project files can be big in size, the comparison is started only once. Use the Refresh Projects toolbox button in order to restart the project comparison.

The results (shown below) are divided into five parts of each ISED project:

  • Project Compares the project information from the project tab.
  • Resources The available ISED project resources like time series or fuels. Each line is corresponding to a concrete time series or fuel. The comparison result is aggregated, e.g. Equal/Different/Added/Removed.
  • Equipment The available ISED project assets. If two assets are compared and marked as different, a double click on the cell opens up a new window with a detailed asset view. An additional toolbox button in this window can show only differences from the comparison.
  • Simulation & Dispatcher Compares the simulation parameters and logging from the Simulation & Dispatcher tab.
Compare projects window

Import Menu

This menu contains the following entries:

From PV (PVSyst or HelioScope)

From PV (PVSyst or HelioScope)

Imports a (correctly formatted) PVSyst or HelioScope export with an (optional) associated Meteonorm file.

If the Meteonorm file is not provided, then the PVSyst data is imported as an hourly time series. If the Meteonorm file is provided, it is assumed that the PVSyst/HelioScope calculation was carried out on Meteonorm data and the provided Meteonorm file is the interpolated 1 minute resolution file from the same source. During the import, the time-series are created and interpolated.

A PV plant is added to the equipment tab and automatically linked to the associated time-series.

PV import dialog

Results Menu

View Results Shows the results of the last simulation run. At the start of ISED the results view will always be empty. To see results from past simulations, the associated results database must be loaded using. View Database entry in Project Menu.

Tool Bar

In the upper left corner the ISED UI contains six buttons:

  • Save Saves a project setup.
  • Run simulation Runs a simulation based on the current project setup for one year.
  • Simulate a few days only Runs a simulation based on the current project setup for one week.
  • View results This button has the same function as the "View Results" in the Results Menu.
  • Show manual Opens this manual.
  • Dispatch Optimization Switches between Decarbonization Study and Dispatch Mode. More details are here.
Tool bar

Tabs

Six tabs are used as following:

  • Project Tab The project information is shown.
  • Resources Tab The time series and fuel resources are shown.
  • Equipment Tab The equipment used for the project are selected and shown.
  • Topology Tab The energy supply topology is shown
  • Dispatch Optimization Tab Parameters used for the dispatchers are shown.
  • Simulations Status Tab Logs from simulation are shown.
Tabs

Result View

The results view shows the aggregated Key Performance Indicates(KPI) of the last simulation run. It contains detailed technical KPIs and provides a rough evaluation of their economic impact. Clicking the symbol in the upper left corner of the results view triggers the financial evaluation view. A detailed economic evaluation may also be accessed from this view.

Financial Tool

A basic financial evaluation tool is integrated in ISED and the economic results from simulation are represented in this tool with post-processing.

Seaview

A trending tool has been customized to work with ISED. Seaview allows for the simple import of Comma-Separated Values(CSV) and ".txt" files, and the view of trends and heat maps. The CSV file may be either "comma" or "semicolon" separated. The user must define the time resolution when importing the time series (in seconds - i.e. 1 hour = 3600). Multiple files can be viewed simultaneously.

The Seaview tool can be accessed either by opening directly via the desktop or via ISED.

View Time Series From the resources tab, the "View Time Series" button will open Seaview, and include all loaded time series.

View Logs After simulating, by right clicking on a given configuration, Seaview will be loaded with the selected log.

Drag-and-drop If Seaview is open, it is possible to drag and drop a .csv or .txt file into the tool, and it will be selectable to view.

General Features

Tables Some tables in ISED have a tree-like structuring that allows to collapse and expand sets of rows. Double clicking on the header row will expand/collapse all rows.

Copy and Paste Most input tables in ISED support copy and paste from outside sources such as EXCEL. For example, to copy a cost table from EXCEL to ISED, copy (ctrl-c) it in EXCEL, then click anywhere into the table in ISED and paste it (ctrl-v).

Help Manual Having the mouse over a text in the UI and pressing the F1-key will open the manual and look up the text in the index. If it is not found in the index, a full text search is performed. All parameter tool tips are also part of the help text. To find that click onto a parameter's name and then press the F1-key.

Project Tab

The project tab contains the following fields:

Project Tab

Project Information

Customer

The customer for the project is set up here. This field is used for informational purposes only.

Project Name

The project name is set up here. This field is used for informational purposes only.

Project Lifetime

The time period for which the KPIs are calculated.

Carbon Tax

Certain assets consume Fuels, which tend to release carbon into the environment. In certain regions, the amount of carbon produced may result in taxes. In such circumstances, the user may configure the taxable amount per metric ton CO 2. The user may define a timeseries to capture variation in the price of carbon over time, with annual multipliers capturing the effect over years. If a time series is selected, then the constant value is ignored.

Each Fuel resource contains a "Carbon content" parameter, indicating the amount of carbon dioxide (in grams) generated per MJ (megajoule) of lower heating value consumed.

This tax is considered by the dispatcher as an additional cost on the energy

produced by each asset which consumes fuel, namely

where

  • C is the effective cost of the fuel,in currency per Kilowatt Hour lower heating value, considered by the dispatcher
  • P is the price of the fuel in currency per kWh lower heating value
  • T is the value of the carbon tax in currency per metric ton of CO2
  • Q is the carbon content of the fuel in g=MJ
  • = 1 x 10 -6 is the conversion factor from grams to metric tons
  • = 3:6 is the conversion factor from kWh to MJ

In addition, KPIs for the amount of carbon emitted by each asset (in metric tons), and the tax payed for it, are calculated.

Project WACC

The weighted average capital cost for nominal cash flow value in results table.

Include salvage

If selected, the residual value of assets that have not reached the end of their life at the end of project will be subtracted from the overall costs.

Currency

The project currency can be defined with a three-letter abbreviation and an exchange rate relative to euros (EUR).

Set project currency

Two options are available:

  • Update entire project data

    This updates all financial values in a project (Decarbonization study and Dispatch optimization) to the selected currency. This includes:

    • The 'Energy Values for Project LCOE (Electricity)' - project tab
    • The 'Carbon tax' - project tab
    • Fuel prices - resources tab
    • Any time series with a currency unit - resources tab
    • CAPEX, OPEX, Replacement Cost for assets and technologies. This includes any asset already in the project, as well as the same conversion when a component is added to the project
    • Any other financial parameters for components (e.g. import/export prices)
    • Dispatching cost parameters in the Multi-Step and MGC dispatchers
    • Any new simulation result databases will be saved into this currency
    • Any new simulation result logs will be written with this currency

  • Do not update project data

    No numerical values are updated, but the three-letter currency code and the exchange rate will be updated as above.

Project Notes

This field is intended for all kinds of information the user wants to store with the project.

Set location

Overview

This button allows selection of the location of the project. This includes also the import of preliminary weather data and a map visualization.

Set project location

Find location

The project location can be found either through its coordinates or its address.

Import weather data for PV

The integrated weather data is based on Meteonorm data. A default value for the UTC offset is estimated when searching for new locations. This can be updated by the user if necessary.

Create PV component If this check box is selected, a PV asset can be created with the integrated weather data. It is also possible to interpolate the solar radiation data to minute time steps by selecting the function check box.

Import time series (button) Click on this button to import the Meteonorm data corresponding to the selected location.

List of Stakeholders

By assigning assets to different stakeholders the financial interests of different parties can be taken into account in the financial analysis. In order to be able to assign a stakeholder to a asset the stakeholder must first be created and added to the stakeholders' list.

Add Adds a stakeholder.

Remove Removes a stakeholder.

Energy Values for Project LCOE (Electricity)

An LCOE (Levelized Cost of Energy) value is calculated for each configuration in the results.

When non-electrical loads exist in a project, the value of the energy flows in the project to these loads affects the Levelized Cost of Electricity for the project. The revenue from these energy flows offset the cost of generating the necessary electricity. For each energy type, there are two parameters:

First Year Value This is the unit value (in EUR/kWh) of the energy to non-electrical loads. This value does not affect dispatching.

Annual Escalation Defines the annual increase in value for the given energy type.

Topology

This topology section is a simplified version of the Topology Tab. A new bus can be added here.

Resources Tab

The resources tab contains two kinds of resources. Firstly, environmental data such as temperature, load profiles, or other time series which influence the performance of assets. Secondly, fuel types can be modified or defined.

Time Series

Overview

This section contains the following buttons:

Resources Tab

View time series

Opens a time series viewer and load all the resource time series for inspection. The time series are grouped by resolution.

The imported time series are shown in a table with the following columns:

Name Name of the time series by which it is referenced within ISED

Type Type of the time series

Unit Measurement unit expected associated with the time series

Scale factor A factor to scale the original time series when used within a asset

Annual multipliers Like an additional scale factor, which changes from year to year. The yearly factors always refer to the original series with the static scale factor applied.

Additional parameters Some time series might require additional parameters, these can be seen and edited here. Wind speed is currently the only example; it requires:

Anemometer height The height at which the time series was measured

Power law exponent The exponent used to extrapolate different heights using the wind profile power law.

Time step (S) The resolution in seconds, in which the time series is provided.

If a time series is selected (by single clicking on it) an overview is displayed below.

Statistics

  • Project Maximum Value (Year 1 Maximum) The maximum value in the time series (if a scaling factor or an annual multiplier is provided with the time series, the unscaled value is shown in parenthesis).
  • Project Average Value (Year 1 Average) The average value in the time series (if a scaling factor or an annual multiplier is provided with the time series, the unscaled value is shown in parenthesis).
  • Project Minimum Value (Year 1 Minimum) The minimum value in the time series (if a scaling factor or an annual multiplier is provided with the time series, the unscaled value is shown in parenthesis).
  • Project Cumulative Value (Year 1 Cumulative) The cumulative value of the time series, e. g. it presents the annual energy consumption when it is the load profile.

Heatmap

The heatmap has on the x-axis the days and on the y-axis the time of day. Therefore are changes from the left to the right "seasonal" changes, meanwhile changes from the bottom to the top are representing changes during the day.

Timeseries Database

The Timeseries Database (TSDB) is a web application aimed to provide a convenient way for sharing timeseries.

Overview

Timeseries that are shared with the support desk (with an appropriate disclosure on sharing within ISED) are uploaded to an integrated database to provide access to all users. A tree structure is provided to help users navigate to areas of interest. A timeseries can be scaled and noise can be added, and then downloaded to a ISED project. The TSDB is updated during the installation of ISED.

Timeseries Database overview

A tree structure with the available timeseries is shown on the left-hand side of the TSDB popup. This structure is defined by the ISED development team and can be modified as necessary. When selected, Timeseries are shown in the right-hand side of the popup. The popup includes:

  1. The timeseries name

  2. Main KPIs for the timeseries e.g. Min, Max, average and the cumulative value.

    The capacity factor is defined as:

  3. Visualization of the timeseries as a plot

  4. A section to customize the timeseries before downloading:

    1. Defining a new average

    2. Defining a new spread. Spread is defined as:

  5. Adding noise for:

    1. Each time step adds randomly generated noise to each timestep
    2. Daily adds randomly generated noise to each day

Information is provided for each timeseries including:

  1. Description a text description on the timeseries
  2. Average, spread and timestep information for the original timeseries
  3. Owner a contact on who provided the timeseries
  4. Version, last modified and created time stamp

Please contact IESsupport.spa.cn@siemens.com if you have timeseries that you would like to add to the database.

Timeseries Editor

The TimeSeries Editor (TSE) is a web application aimed to provide a convenient way for creation, editing and sharing timeseries configurations.

Functionality

Overview

Preparing realistic input data is a significant part of the simulation process. To achieve the best simulation accuracy, it is important to consider various load profiles like electrical and thermal, and power limits. TimeSeriesEditor (TSE) is a tool enabling users to gather the information from a variety of sources and quickly create yearly timeseries for simulation.

TSE Main screen (Daily View)

On the first run of TSE, the user is prompted to provide the Name and the 1st day of the Year for a new timeseries configuration.

New timeseries configuration pop-up window

From this point, a user's journey towards creating Yearly Profile is about to start.

In the TSE first screen (Daily View), the user can start working with the application by adding profiles, configuring daily profiles in Daily Load Profile Editor and visualizing selected daily profiles in Daily Load Profile Viewer.

After the user has added daily profiles, he can get to the TSE second and third screens by selecting "Yearly View" and "Heatmap" tabs at the top of the screen. In these screens the user can find the generated Yearly Timeseries in Trend and Heatmap charts, analyze KPIs, adjust Monthly Scales, change timeseries interpolation type, and apply noise by selecting time step noise or daily variation. See the details in following chapters.

TSE second tab (Yearly View)

TSE third tab (Heatmap)

If the Yearly Timeseries is available (at least one daily profile has been added), the user has following actions enabled:

  • Export timeseries configuration to a file,
  • Export yearly profile to txt file,
  • Export yearly profile to ISED,
  • Start working with another timeseries configuration via importing from the existing timeseries configuration file,
  • Discard all changes and create new timeseries configuration.

Navigation

The user can navigate in TSE using tabs: Daily View, Yearly View and Heatmap. In Daily View the user can configure input profiles. In Yearly View and Heatmap he can see the generated Yearly Timeseries.

TSE tabs: Daily View, Yearly View, Heatmap

Global settings

Two global parameters affecting the whole configuration are available in Timeseries Editor:

  • kW/MW units: this setting changes the order of magnitude of all values shown in the UI, but it will not affect the exported data unit which are assumed to always be is kW.
  • Jan 1st (day of the week): defines the target year for timeseries generation: this setting defines the weekend distribution along the yearly timeseries. Please note that leap years are not currently supported.

Global settings: units and 1st day of the year

Timeseries Configuration

Timeseries configuration is a whole set of input data created by the user: daily profiles, colors, interpolation types, etc. Timeseries editor allows to create new timeseries configuration, export (save) or import (load) timeseries configuration to/from the file.

All the modifications of a timeseries configuration are immediately saved by the application (autosave). Therefore, each change in Daily View has its effect in Year View and Heatmap right away.

Autosave

To prevent data loss in case of pressing 'F5' (refresh), closing browser or accidental shutdown, Timeseries Editor application automatically saves all the modifications.

Before creating new TSC the user is notified about the possibility to save current TSC to a file to be able to restore this work.

Daily load profiles

Adding daily profiles

The user can start working on timeseries by using 'Add Profile' button:

Add profile button

In the "Add Profile" dialog the user can choose to add default profile with some pre-defined non-zero values or to import timeseries from a file using the drop-down at the top:

Add profile dialog

Following parameters are available for configuration of a profile:

Profile Name: user-defined name, not necessarily unique

Definition Type: Weekday (Monday – Sunday), Weekend (Saturday, Sunday) or Deviation (might be either single date or date range)

Definition Date: a single date or date range for Deviation profiles can be selected with a calendar picker

Style: interpolation style used in the daily profiles chart to display the profile

  • Curved (polynomial https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polynomial_interpolation)
  • Step (piecewise constant interpolation)
  • Linear

Scale: scale to be applied to original daily profile (see details in Daily profile metrics calculation and setting)

Time resolution: the user can select default profile either with 24, 48, or 96 data points.

Color: color to be used in the chart to display the profile.

All settings except the time resolution can be changed later in the daily profile editor table.

For Deviation profiles the rule is different: there should be no overlapping of date ranges for deviation profiles. If the user tries to add a deviation profile with the date range overlapping already existing one, the warning will be shown: “Deviation profile date ranges cannot overlap. Please choose another date range.”

Warning: Month is already occupied

In case of importing values from file, following validation rules are applied to the data by TSE application:

  • data points in the file must have the "line feed" delimiter only ('space' and 'comma' are not supported)
  • the file must contain valid number of points: 24, 48 or 96 (according to supported range of time resolutions).

Once the user has added a daily profile, its chart gets displayed in the Daily load profile viewer and corresponding entry gets added to the Daily load profile editor.

A daily profile in Daily View

Daily load profile viewer

In the Daily load profile viewer, the user has a visual representation of configured daily profiles.

Daily viewer

The user can change values of a daily profile by Drag&Dropping points in the graph. The application prevents the user from setting negative values for daily profiles. The Y-axis scale is automatically adjusted to display all values of selected daily profiles.

The user can quickly show/hide groups of daily profiles from the chart using checkboxes "Weekdays", "Weekends" and "Deviations" in the top right corner of the Daily load profile viewer.

Please note: even if the profile is hidden from the chart, it still is included in calculation of Yearly Timeseries unless it is switched off in the editor table.

Editing Daily Profile

In the Daily load profile editor, the user can configure a profile using following parameters:

  • Definition Type
  • Profile name
  • Date/Date range
  • Calculated metrics:
    • Minimum [kW/MW]
    • Maximum [kW/MW]
    • Month [kWh/MWh]
    • Daily Average [kW/MW]
    • Scale
    • Spread [%]
  • Style
  • Color

Minimum, Maximum and Month are read-only metrics of a daily profile. All others are editable and can be changed at any time.

Changing Daily Average, Scale and  Spread (see Daily profile metrics) will immediately affect the values of the profile.

Daily Average, Scale and Spread

It is also possible to edit values manually in edit mode. In order to do that press edit button on the right side of the daily profile entry:

Edit Daily Profile button

In this mode the user can see the table with load values for each time point in the profile. The values can be edited by typing a new value the changes can be discarded or applied by pressing "Discard" or "Apply" buttons.

Profile Edit mode

It is also possible to Drag&Drop daily profile points in the chart in the Daily load profile viewer (see the next section). This will take immediate effect.

Import from/to Excel

The user can import profile data from Microsoft Excel document via copy/paste operation from the Excel sheet into the value row in editing mode.
For that purpose:

  1. In Excel copy the range of values (24, 48 or 96 values)
  2. In TSE open edit mode for one of profiles
  3. Click button “Paste from Excel”

Paste from Excel button

Another option to paste from Excel is to use keyboard shortcut:

  1. In Excel copy the range of values (24, 48 or 96 values)
  2. In TSE put the cursor in one of the cells
  3. Press "Ctrl+V" and the values will be pasted into the daily profile entry
  4. Press "Apply" to make changes or "Discard" to get back to previous state of the profile and exit the entry edit mode

Paste from Excel using shortcuts

The values can be copied back to Excel via pressing button "Copy to Excel":

Copy to Excel button

All values of the currently opened profile will be copied to the clipboard and can be pasted in Excel as a column.

Delete Daily Profile

The user can delete the daily profile via "recycle bin" button. Please note that this action cannot be reverted. Consider temporary hiding from the profile described in the next section if the profile might contain useful data.

Daily Profiles Selection

The user can select/deselect daily profiles using the checkbox on the left side of the profile entry. It shows/hides the profile from the chart in the Daily load profile viewer. What is more important, this setting also influences on whether this daily profile is used for generating Yearly Timeseries or not. Effectively, using this checkbox the user is turning the profile off and on.

Checkboxes to turn a profile on and off

Definition Types and Definition Dates

The configuration of definition type and selecting definition dates is an important part of generating Yearly Timeseries.

Definition Types

The user can assign one of the following types to a daily profile: weekday, weekend and deviation.

Definition Types

Depending on the definition type the profile will be applied to yearly timeseries in one of ways, see next sections.

Definition Date

The definition date is a date on which a daily profile starts to be applied to the target Year until another definition date of the same definition type is met (only for Weekday and Weekend types). Definition date of a Deviation profile denotes a single day or a date range to which the deviation will be applied.

The user can select the date for a daily profile using the calendar picker, see the picture below:

Single date selection in Calendar Picker

Daily profiles of Deviation type can be configured either for a single date or for a date range.

Date range selection in Calendar Picker

For Deviation profiles the rule is different: there should be no overlapping of date ranges for deviation profiles. If the user tries to add a deviation profile with the date range overlapping already existing one, the warning will be shown: “Deviation profile date ranges cannot overlap. Please choose another date range.”

Profiles application rules

Daily profiles are applied to the yearly profile according to the following rules:

  1. At first all Daily profiles of type Weekday are sorted by date and one by one are applied to the yearly profile. Each profile is applied to all days starting from its definition date to the next profile definition date.
  2. Then in the yearly profile obtained after Step 1, all Daily profiles of type  Weekend (sorted by date) one by one are applied to the Saturdays and Sundays starting from a definition date to the next definition date of a weekend profile.
  3. Then all Daily profile of type  Deviation are applied specifically to a definition date or definition range for the yearly profile resulting from Step 2.

Weekend profiles and deviation profiles essentially override the values propagated from weekday profiles. In other words, a weekend profile has higher priority than a weekday one and a deviation profile has higher priority than a weekend one.

Daily profile metrics

Several metrics characterizing a daily profile are displayed in the Daily Load Profile Editor panel. Let's consider them in details.

Read-only metrics:

  1. Min [kW or MW] - minimal value in current profile. The value is read-only.
  2. Max [kW or MW] - maximum value in current profile. The value is read-only.
  1. Month [kWh or MWh] - the amount of energy that might be consumed in one month if current daily profile would hold for the whole month. No other profiles are considered, monthly scaling defined in Yearly View or on Heatmap View is also not considered. The value is calculated according to the formula: 

month_energy_consumption = sum_of_profile_values * 24 / profile_length * DAYS_IN_MONTH

This characteristic is read-only and aimed to give an understanding about how the profile of interest will contribute to final amount of energy consumed in a year.

Editable metrics:

  1. Daily Ave [kW or MW] - average power in a daily profile. It has unit kW or MW depending on current state of the toggle kW/MW. Daily average is calculated as arithmetical mean of all values in a daily profile. 
    This value is editable. When the user changes the average it calculates new corresponding scale and daily profile gets recalculated. So, this change is equivalent to scaling the profile. 

newScale = currentScale * newAverage/currentAverage

  1. Scale [-] - multiplier that allows to scale the given profile along the Y axis.
  1. Spread [%] - the characteristic showing the difference between maximum and minimum value relatively to the average value of the profile. Current spread is calculated according to the formula:  

spread = (maximum - minimum) / average

This value is editable. When the user changes the spread the application recalculates the daily profile, moving each value from the average by the relative spread change. So, this change will take an effect of stretching the profile along the Y axis relatively to average value. Note that average will stay the same. When the user changes a value in the spread edit field, each value in the profile is updated according to the relation: 

newProfileValue = average + (currentProfileValue - average) * newSpread / currentSpread

It should be noted that all metric changes are immediately applied to daily profiles and to timeseries configuration. It means that recalculation of the yearly profile is triggered on every change. If the user opens the Yearly View or Heatmap tab after a metric change, he should see the updated yearly profile graph.

Initial values of the profile do not get overridden by change of average, scale or spread. If the user sets the scale back to 1, and the spread back to the initial value, he will see initial values of the profile. However, in the case the user Drag&Drops points on the chart or edits them manually in the daily editor table, source values do get changed in accordance with current scale. In that case even after reverting the scale and spread back to initial values, the changed point will be different from the source value.

Yearly profile generation

Yearly profile gets created after each change in the timeseries configuration. All the inputs in Daily profiles screen and settings in Yearly View or Heatmap are considered for yearly profile calculation. Below you can find the description of available settings in Yearly View and Heatmap.

Yearly profile time resolution

It is allowed to have daily profiles of different time resolution in one timeseries configuration. Time resolution of yearly profile is automatically derived from the input data and is equal to the highest resolution among the input daily profiles.

All daily profiles with lower resolution are resampled before being applied to yearly profile. For that purpose, linear interpolation is used to fill gaps between values and reach the required step size. The resulting extended daily profile is applied to yearly profile during its calculation.

KPIs

The KPI panel is displayed above the yearly profile chart and the heatmap. It includes the following indicators:

  1. Pmax [kW / MW] – maximum power during the year
  2. Pmin [kW / MW] – minimum power during the year
  3. Pave [kW / MW] – average power during the year
  4. Etotal [MWh / GWh] – total amount of consumed energy during the year
  5. Capacity factor [%]

Setting up timeseries interpolation type

There are two types of timeseries interpolation that can be displayed in the graph: step and smooth. Step interpolation effectively means no additional modification of values.

Step interpolation of a yearly profile

Smooth profile is calculated from step profile using special algorithm. The main idea of smoothing algorithm is to get rid of abrupt jumps caused by daily profile difference or by monthly average scaling.

Smooth interpolation for different monthly scales

Weekdays are smoothed independently of the weekends since the algorithm considers trends for them separately. Deviation days are not changed by interpolation at all.

Smooth interpolation for profiles with different definition types

Setting up time step noise

Timestep noise and daily variation are the mechanisms aimed at adding normal noise to the yearly profile and imitating real load data. Time step noise is applied independently to each value in the yearly profile, so the random multiplier is chosen for each of them.

Setting up daily variation

Similarly to time step noise, daily variation is used to add random noise (or variation to a yearly profile. Daily variation differs from the timestep noise by the lifespan of the random part: once calculated it stays the same for one day.

Monthly scaling

Adjusting the monthly scales is another way to customize the yearly profile. It can be done by dragging the point on monthly scales chart or by manual input of the scale for a month. See the picture below:

Monthly scales

By default, the scale factor table is initialized with "1". The user can easily revert all changes made through the pane by setting scale values in the table to 1.

Export yearly timeseries

As soon as the user has finished all the required adjustments and is ready with the Yearly Timeseries, he might want to  Export Yearly Timeseries to the file (.txt) or  Export Yearly Timeseries to ISED project (tool).

Action bar

Timeseries Editor has following action buttons in the left sidebar:

Sidebar with action buttons

Creating new timeseries configuration

The user can create a new timeseries configuration using the action button in the left sidebar.

Creating new timeseries configuration

The application will offer the user to export (save) the existing timeseries configuration to a file or to proceed with creating new timeseries configuration.

Confirmation before creation of new configuration

If the user chooses "Cancel" the action is cancelled and the TSC is left intact. If the user chooses No, the current TSC is discarded and its data gets lost. In case if 'Yes' option is selected, the user is presented to an overlay with initial TSC settings and he should provide TSC name (Project name) and the target Year. Effectively, creation of new timeseries configuration is equivalent to discarding of all changes made by user.

New timeseries configuration dialog

Import/export timeseries configuration

The user can export the TSC to a file in the format .tse. As a result of the export, a file with TSC in internal format is created and saved to the "Downloads" folder.

Save timeseries configuration to a file

The user can load TSC by importing from the .tse file created by TSE application. In that case the file browser is shown to the user prompting to select a file in his machine.

Export and import of TSC allows users to share the data between each other e.g. via emails.

Open timeseries configuration from file

The most seamless and advanced way of sharing Yearly Timeseries in TSE is exporting it directly to ISED project in case if TSE application has been started from ISED application.

Export yearly profile to ISED

The user will need to provide  Interpolation Type and  Decimal Separator parameters; the current TSC name displayed in the TSE header will be used as a ISED project name.

If ISED is running and has open connection with TSE (web server is ready to process TSE export request), the user in TSE will get the notification about successful export.

In case of a failure, the user gets the following notification in TSE:

Error notification

Export Yearly Timeseries to file

The user can export Yearly Timeseries to a .txt file using Action Buttons in the left sidebar.

Export yearly profile to .txt

Then the popup gets shown prompting the user to specify:  File name, Interpolation Type (Step, Smooth) and  Decimal separator (comma, dot).

Export yearly profile dialog

On pressing "Export" button, the file is generated and saved to "Downloads" folder.

Generate weather data

This button opens a dialog that allows to set the project location and at the same time import preliminary weather data. This is the same popup as described in the Project Tab "Set Location"

Add time series

This button opens a dialog for adding a new time series. When adding a time series, the following information must be provided:

File name

The name of the file to import. Use the button "Browse" to choose a file from disk. Files may either be .csv or a simple .txt file. The following format options are available:

  • Format option 1: If each row contains only a single number, this is interpreted as the value at a given point in time. The file is assumed to represent 1 year, and the values are spread evenly. For example, if 8760 values are given, then each value has a time of 3600 seconds. If 365 values are given, then there will be a single value for every day.
  • Format option 2: When the first row contains the text: "#timestepSizeInSeconds=xxxx" (without "") then the values will be spaced xxxx seconds apart, regardless of how many values are present (e.g. xxxx = 3600 for hourly data, xxxx= 1800 for half hourly data). This can be useful to create a multiyear timeseries when more than one year's worth of data is available, each year needs to be copied sequentially into a file. The following applies for timeseries with this format: 1. If the timeseries contains less than one year data, then the data will be repeated until the first year is completed. 2. If the timeseries contains a data partial period that is more than one year, and if a simulation is set to Simulate all (entire project lifetime),then the timeseries repeats so that beginning of the first year is reused to complete the partial final year 3. If the time series is for multiple years, but is shorter than the project length, and if a simulation is set to Simulate all (entire project lifetime), then the last year will be repeated until the end of the project.

Name

The name by which the time series is later referenced by assets.

Type

The type of the time series. Possible types include:

  • Power The customer load to be satisfied by the hybrid power plant. It is usually provided by the customer.
  • Global horizontal irradiation Used by the HVAC asset to determine the influence of irradiation on container heating. Usually provided by customer measurements or Meteonorm data.
  • Temperature The ambient temperature used by the battery and HVAC.
  • Wind speed The measured wind speed, used as an input for the wind park. Usually provided by either customer measurements, or a wind data provider such as AWS.
  • Normed output power to peak power Used by the PV asset to calculate the maximal PV output. The time series is assumed to be calculated from a reference PV model and normed to the DC peak power under STC of the reference block.
  • Operating reserve A time series of time dependent operation re- serve fractions. This time series allows specifying time dependent operation reserve fractions for wind and photovoltaic assets.
  • Deferrable load This is a load that can be connected to a reservoir. Together the load and the reservoir allow to configure a deferrable load, i.e. a load that must be satisfied at some point, but is decoupled by a storage. A water tower with an outflow is a good example. The "water load" must be satisfied, but this imposes no restrictions on the electrical load of the pumps as long as the tank is not empty and not full.
  • Energy price Grid assets may have variable prices, which can be set by these time series.

Remove time series

Removes the currently selected time series from the project. Will not delete the time series from the file system.

Export time series

Exports a time series to the file system.

Fuel

The fuel section contains five buttons:

Add cost

Adds a variation of cost to the search space for a specific fuel. When defining a reference configuration, the cost in the first column is used to define the cost for the reference case.

Remove cost

Removes a cost variation from the search space for the specific fuel.

Add fuel

Adds a fuel type from a selected file. The fuel is also then saved to the user's default library location on their computer. For most users, this is "Documents\ISED\UserLibrary\Fuels"

Remove fuel

Removes a fuel from the project.

Save to library

Saves a fuel type to file (in the standard fuel library folder "Documents\ISED\UserLibrary\Fuels" ).

  • Name Name of the fuel
  • Density The mass per unit volume. Density is used for the calculation of cost at different fuel units, so it should be consistent with the density where the cost of the fuel is measured.
  • Annual multipliers Yearly factors for fuel costs. The yearly factors always refer to the original fuel price.
  • Lower heating value (LHV) The lower heating value (also known as net calorific value) of a fuel is defined as the amount of heat released by combusting a specified quantity (initially at 25 °C) and returning the temperature of the combustion products to 150 °C, which assumes the latent heat of vaporization of water in the reaction products is not recovered.
  • Heating (calorific) value is a characteristic value for each substance, specifying the amount of heat released during its combustion. It is measured in energy per unit of substance and subdivided into the superior (higher) and inferior (lower) calorific value. The inferior value is given by the superior value, reduced by the vaporization heat of the water contained in the substance. The standardized abbreviations according to ISO 15971:2014 are Hs (superior) and Hi (inferior). Several other regional notions exist, e.g., in US the Hs is commonly known as higher heating value (HHV), gross calorific value (GCV) or higher calorific value (HCV). Similarly, lower heating value (LHV), net calorific value (NCV) or lowercalorific value (LCV) is used for the Hi.
  • Carbon content The carbon content of the fuel is used as a percentage of its mass. This value is used for Carbon Emissions and Carbon Taxes.
  • Unit A determinate quantity adopted as a standard of measurement for fuels. This value is used to convert fuel costs in the KPIs.
  • Cost Cost of fuel per unit. When defining a cost, the user may select between setting a constant value, or by selecting a time series. Internally, this value is converted ack to EUR/kWh for economic dispatch decisions.
Fuel Cost definition

Decarbonization Study

Decarbonization Study is an alternative to Dispatch Optimization and can be selected with the toggle button in the tool bar.

Decarbonization Study

Overview

Decarbonization Study helps determine an unbiased technology type and size suggestion for customer projects. This sizing algorithm uses perfect foresight (i.e. the entire year) to simultaneously optimize the design and dispatch of an energy system with respect to a weighting in cost and CO2 emissions. It is possible to solve for a specific weighting, or to automatically run multiple scenarios for differing CO2 emissions. Decarbonization Study is intended for initial design as simplifications are made in both the algorithm and technology models.

The reference configuration is configured to reflect either the existing energy generation system for brown- or green- field projects, or the standard generation system alternative for greenfield projects. Relevant loads (electrical, steam, hot or cold water and hydrogen) are also defined. More complex systems can be modeled by adding additional energy types (buses) and configuring how technologies are connected. Components can be copied multiple times as necessary.

Opportunities for optimizing cost and/or CO2 emissions are simulated in alternative scenarios. Technologies of interest can be activated with an associated range of size. As shown in the diagram below, cost and CO2 reduction are normally conflicting goals, as lower costs will typically cause higher CO2 emissions, and lower CO2 emissions will typically require higher costs. The Environmental Tradeoff Analysis (ETA) automatically creates a range of scenarios with staggered CO2 emissions, providing an overview of this relationship. For more information about the charts comparing configurations - see here.

Environmental Tradeoff Analysis

Simulation results provide financial and technical KPIs for each scenario including the size of opportunity technologies. Technologies that do not benefit the optimization target will have a rated size of 0. Trends showing the dispatch decision at each time step are scenario are available, and the energy flow can be viewed in a Sankey diagram.

A scenario from the results can be selected for conversion to a Dispatch Optimization project. Loads, reference equipment with the rated size and opportunity equipment with the suggested size are shown. Relevant assets from the ISED library can be selected from a dropdown and the number of units and/or size can be set. During the conversion, the selected loads and components are added to the project and relevant timeseries are connected. Any non-default parameters will be identified for specific consideration. The converted project can then be used as a basis for simulation in the dispatch optimization.

The following simplifications in the Decarbonization Study algorithm and models are made:

  • Simulation of either four (4) equidistant weeks in year with extrapolated results, or an entire year
  • Simplified models linear models. Characteristics including part-load efficiencies, lower limits, degradation and ambient temperature correction are not considered.
  • Multiple year simulations are not possible, so annual multipliers, delayed installation and replacement strategy are not simulated
  • Spinning reserve including operating reserve and redundancy is not considered, except as a buffer for oversizing an asset.
  • Stakeholder based analysis is not included

Decarbonization Study Workflow

The workflow for the Decarbonization Study is shown in the diagram below.

Decarbonization Study Workflow

1. Pre-Definition

ISED can toggle between Decarbonization Study and Dispatch Optimization in the tool bar.

Activate Decarbonization Study

Timeseries can be defined in the resource tab for:

  • Loads (electrical, steam, hot and cold water as well as hydrogen)
  • Import and export prices
  • Wind (must be connected for wind turbines)
  • Irradiation (for PV) - if needed not connected, then these will be automatically downloaded from the Meteonorm DB and connected for the first stimulation. A warning is given if the project location is still the default.
  • Fuel prices (these must be connected to the fuel on the resource tab)

Fuels can be configured for:

  • Price (as constant or timeseries)
  • CO2 content

2. Project setup

The project needs to be setup for the project on the Decarbonization Study tab. The Simulation Settings are defined on the left side of the tab, and the System is defined on the right side.

Project Setup

Simulation Settings

The timestep can be defined in minutes. A choice can be made to solve for an entire year, or to save time by simulating less time throughout the year (i.e. first week of January, April, July and October).

Opportunities settings:

Greenfield Project

If selected, then the Technologies in the Reference Configuration will not be included in the Opportunities scenarios. This is typical for a greenfield project. Often there is a clear choice between 2 distinct alternatives: either a grid with local heating or a microgrid with renewables.

As an example, an industrial site that will be built in 2 years is considering:

  • Option 1: a large grid connection + boiler for hot water
  • Option 2: a combination of renewables, storage, and heat pumps with small or no grid connection.

In this case, there is only a large grid connection in the reference scenario, but not in the Opportunities scenarios.

  • Maximum CAPEX limit
  • Maximum annual operational expenses, which includes fuel, O&M, replacements , import and exports as well as demand charges.
  • Minimum and maximum CO2 limits (these values also set the CO2 limits for the ETA)
  • Maximum technology size updates the maximum value of the range for all technologies in the opportunities as larger sizes will require longer solving times.

Weather data can be configured:

  • Select location opens the same popup from the Project and Resource tab. Within the popup the project location can be selected, which will be used to download and connect irradiation data if PV is simulated in the project and timeseries are not connected.
  • Wind park - a wind timeseries needs to be connected if wind is simulated
  • PV park - The timeseries used for PV will be shown.

System

The loads, reference and opportunity technologies can be defined in the System window. It is possible to copy any load or technologies, as well as add a bus for any energy type. Energy types are kept consistent in all views. The connection of any load or technology type can be updated by clicking on the cell representing the preferred bus for the technology. Checks are made to ensure consistency for technologies that have an input and output of the same energy type. Search, select all, and hide inactive functions help find and show the technology of interest. Technology parameters are derived from library equipment, the source for each technology is shown with the mouse-over text.

Loads Loads can be defined as either constant values or timeseries with the appropriate unit. Loads can be assigned to the Reference configuration, the Opportunities scenarios, or both using the dropdown menu. Standard assignment for new and existing projects is both. This functionality can be used to depict demand side savings by inserting two loads: Load without savings to the reference scenario, decreased load to the opportunity scenario.

Reference System The Reference System defines the existing generation system for a brown field project, or the expected generation alternative for a green field project. Specific technologies need to be selected, and the rated size configured. Any technology parameter can be updated for a project including timeseries, prices, technical parameters. Note that the CAPEX for all reference technologies is set to 0 EUR by default.

Opportunities Technologies of interest can be defined in the opportunities tab. A technology needs to be activated to be considered in a simulation.

A minimum component as well as minimum and maximum project size can be defined.

  • The minimum component size defines the smallest size that an asset could have, for example, the smallest gas turbine in Siemens portfolio. It could be possible for the technology to be either 0, or between the min and max range.
  • The minimum project size is the lower limit specified for a project. Al least this size of technology must be installed. For example, a customer may specify that at least 1MW of photovoltaic must be installed.
  • The maximum project size is the upper limit for the size considered in a simulation.

Any technology parameter can be updated for a project, including timeseries, prices, technical parameters

A fixed spinning reserve can be set for the following components:

  • Gensets
  • Reciprocating engines (CHP)
  • Gas turbines
  • Steam turbines

For Electrical Grid Connections Net metering can be activated.

  • Net metering is an incentive mechanism used in the US for encouraging photovoltaic installations. It provides revenue by crediting excess energy generated by PV when it is exported to the grid. The exported energy is credited at the same price that electricity is imported, thereby offsetting electricity import costs that occur in the same month.
  • The credit system can only offset imported energy costs, so that the monthly energy bill is lowered. It is not possible to credit more energy than is imported, so the monthly energy bill can never be positive. If additional energy is exported, then the credits can be carried to a future billing period. Therefore, it is possible to accumulate credits in summer, and use these during winter months when there is less PV generation.
  • As an approximation ISED enforces that the amount of annual exported energy to the grid cannot exceed the amount of annual imported energy.
  • State legislation, regulation and implementation means that the specific credit mechanism varies by location. These details are not modelled in ISED.
  • Net metering is not supported for custom period simulations.

Simulation A simulation can be run for the cost-optimal case plus the reference case. As an alternative, multiple scenarios can be run as an Environmental Tradeoff Analysis (ETA) plus the reference case. The number of scenarios in the ETA can be defined, and an algorithm will automatically calculate the CO2 footprint for the minimum cost and minimum CO2 scenarios. These CO2 footprints will be divided equally by the remaining number of simulations, which is then used as a target for the optimization for each scenario. The simulation should normally result in scenarios with regular step increases in their CO2 footprints.

Warnings will be given if:

  • The simulation is infeasible, for example if insufficient generation exists for a load
  • PV is included in the simulation and project location is default
  • Loads are activated with standard parameters (this is considered unlikely)
  • Prices for fuels that are simulated are default (this is considered unlikely)

3. Results

Decarbonization Study Results Tab

Results are shown as a tab. The left window shows an overview of the simulated configurations. Each configuration is shown as a column, with the recommended sizing for each component shown as rows in this table. Reference System components are listed first, and Opportunities are listed afterwards. If a component is not recommended, then the sizing will be listed as "0".

A specific scenario can be selected by either clicking on the table - or via the dropdown box. Once selected, the results for a scenario are shown on the right window. The view is consistent with the results for Dispatch Optimization results, see above for details. Specifically, this includes:

  • Cash flow
  • Technical KPIs
  • Indicative LCoE
  • Messages
  • Sankey

Plots can be shown for all scenarios, or for a selected scenario.

Additionally, the KPI selection tab can be used to select specific results from selected scenarios.

4. Conversion

Conversion Tab

In the Conversion tab the user can view the simulated technology and suggested sizes for the selected scenario. For each technology a dropdown is provided for the relevant assets in the ISED library. The number of units that are suggested to installed is calculated to ensure that more than the suggested capacity is installed. The user can override the suggested number of assets in the Actual number column. Generic assets that do not have a specific capacity simply take the suggested power e.g. boilers, electrical grid connection, etc.

Once the correct assets have been configured these can be downloaded to a ISED project with the "Convert to ISED" button.

Conversion Popup

Timeseries used in the Decarbonization Study are automatically connected to the relevant asset. Any parameters that have been changed from the default will be shown, and the user can choose which value should be used in the new Dispatch Optimization assets

Environmental Tradeoff Analysis

The Environmental Tradeoff Analysis allows the user to automatically compare different weightings of cost versus environmental impact (as quantified by Carbon Footprint). If 10 stages are selected, then the reference case + 10 configurations (varying from full environmental emphasis toward full cost emphasis) will be optimized.

The results of this analysis can then be examined in the dedicated chart views, or in the standard table view (previously described in the Results section of the Workflow.

Environmental Tradeoff Analysis Charts

Opportunities Rated Power and Capacity

Opportunities Rated Power and Capacity

The first chart describes the optimized rated sizes of the Opportunities in each configuration. All power generating or transformation assets are described in units of kW (or kW_th) and energy storage units are described in units of kWh. The horizontal axis shows the annual carbon footprint for the particular configuration. More environmentally friendly configurations are further to the left. Typically, the Reference case is furthest to the right.

By moving the mouse over the various configurations, it is possible to see recommended sizes for each component. By clicking on a point, it is possible to select a configuration to see the detailed KPIs on the right part of the screen.

Costs

Costs

The second chart describes the costs associated with each configuration. Again, the horizontal axis shows the annual carbon footprint for the particular configuration. More environmentally friendly configurations are further to the left. Typically, the Reference case is furthest to the right. Typically, costs will be highest in the reference case and in the most environmentally friendly configurations, as these imply the greatest investment in new assets.

By moving the mouse over the various configurations, it is possible to see the specific cost breakdowns for a configuration. The following cost KPIs are computed:

  • Project TOTEX - Total system cost over project lifetime
  • Project CAPEX - Initial system investment cost
  • Project OPEX - Total system operating cost over project lifetime (including O&M, fuel, import costs...)
  • Annual Operating Costs - The total system operating cost for the first year

By clicking on a point, it is possible to select a configuration to see the detailed KPIs on the right part of the screen.

Equipment Tab

Basic Functionality

On this tab, the user can see the library of different assets of different types of technologies, create an energy system by connecting assets, and customize the assets by setting parameter values.
