The lower left-hand side of the Equipment Tab contains a tabular overview of the current project setup.

  • Double clicking on the header row will collapse/expand all asset types.
  • Double clicking on a single asset type will collapse/expand only this asset type.

The table has the following columns:

  • Asset type The type of the asset.
  • Asset name The name of the asset. This entry is editable and must be unique within a project.
  • Reference If a asset is labeled by the user as a Reference, it is included into the reference configuration. In the Topology Tab such assets are shown with a green background.
  • Replacement If a asset is labeled by the user as a Replacement, then this asset will not be installed at the beginning of the simulation. Rather it is installed after a separately defined asset reaches its end of life. In the Topology Tab such assets are shown with a purple background.
  • Owner The owner which is assigned to a asset. The owner is charged with all expenses associated with a asset and all its revenues.
  • Summary Displays a short summary of important KPIs for each asset. If multiple configurations for a asset exist within one project a table is shown.

Topology

This topology section is a simplified version of Topology Tab. "Show frame lines, Show names and Fit in view" from the tool bar are shown here and same manipulations can be applied.

Parameters

The parameters section shows the parameters and their values of the deployed asset, which has been selected in the assets table. It has two buttons:

Add variation

If a particular parameter value is selected in the table below, clicking the "Add variation" Button will add a new variation to the table to allow editing a variation to this parameter. The new parameter will become part of the search space.

Remove variation

If a parameter value is selected, clicking on the "Remove variation" button will remove this parameter value from the search space.

Parameter categories

Base The "Base" view can be enabled (blue) or disabled (grey).

  • No categories are selected: When "Base" is enabled only the base parameter are shown. When "Base" is disabled all parameters are shown.
  • One or more categories are selected: When "Base" is enabled the base parameters AND the parameters belonging to the selected categories are shown. When "Base" is disabled only the parameters belonging to the selected categories are shown.

Other Categories They can be enabled (blue) or disabled (grey). It is possible to select none or multiple categories. When one or more categories are selected only the parameters belonging to the selected categories are shown.

Filter by parameter name

This search and filter parameters can be used to filter in more detail for text inside of the parameter name. This filter is applied only to the currently visible parameters. To filter for multiple words use " " (whitespace), "," (comma) or ";" (semicolon). This text filter is based on an OR concatenation. This means that when looking for multiple values a parameter will be shown if one of the values matches the filter. An Example: "Fuel, Energy; kw cost" will return a parameter containing one of the four substrings. If the parameter name is "Cost function" this parameter will be visible when using the above filter string.

Search and filter for parameters

Parameter Table

The parameter table has the following columns:

  • Parameter Name of the parameter. Hovering over this field with the mouse will yield a short help description.
  • Base The base parameter value of this configuration. These values will be used for the reference configuration and for any other configurations if no variations are specified.
  • Variation All variations of the parameter that are included in the search space.

Special Parameter Types

Each asset type will have some parameters which are unique to that particular type. However, many parameters are common between many or all assets. Here, some of these parameters, especially those which are particularly complex, are described.

Price Matrix

Price Matrix

The Price Matrix is common to all assets. It describes the main economic aspects of the asset.

  • Size: the size for which the prices are set
  • CAPEX: initial price for an asset
  • OPEX: hourly cost for an asset
  • Replacement Price: the price for replacing an asset
  • Annual Multiplier: multiplier for replacement cost, in case of delayed install this multiplier is also used for CAPEX. This does not affect OPEX.
  • Year: year in which the multiplier is being applied

CAPEX, OPEX and Replacement Prices are for a turnkey delivery including logistics, installation and commissioning. The price should include gross margin, risk, and other margins. Every project has its own specific costs e.g. labor, logistics, risk etc., the user needs to make sure that the price used is suitable for the project. The values provided in the tool are typical values provided by experts, and can be used as an indication on the type of value that might be expected.

Price Matrix

As shown in the figure above, the Price Matrix can have multiple rows. In each row, a specific size is listed, and then the corresponding CAPEX, OPEX, and Replacement Price for that size can be defined. Then, the prices at other sizes can be calculated by interpolation (red example) or extrapolation (purple example). For the special case where only a single row is defined (blue example) the prices are extrapolating assuming 0 price at 0 size.

Heat Balance Table

Heat Balance Table (HBT)

Some assets allow the user to directly enter a range of set points for all power and fuel flows within a asset. Each asset with a heat balance table interprets these values in a slightly different manner; please refer to the specific sections on each asset. However, all assets that have a Heat Balance Table will also have some type of "Rated Power", be it electrical, thermal or Hydrogen output.

If the "Rated power" parameter is different than the output power value in the last row of the heat balance table, then all values (power, fuel consumption, hydrogen, etc.) are scaled by the factor Rated power / Output power value in the last row of the heat balance table. This ensures that the efficiency remains unchanged.

If a configuration has two or more assets that are identical, then it can occur that an infinite numbers of different power-dispatch solutions (combinations of power levels of assets) will have the same global effect (economical value). By nature, two identical asset will lead to at least two optimal power dispatch solutions that are economically equally viable and can be transformed into one or the other by exchanging the power setpoints of the two assets. These symmetries can slow down finding the optimum solution. For speed, ISED uses symmetry breaking techniques. Based on an internal ranking, asset usage is disincentivized with a very small, unique factor per asset. This very small weighting between assets shall not influence the overall economical evaluation of the configuration. When economical evaluation has multiple equal solutions, the dispatch of identical assets tends towards a fixed priority ranking. As an effect, you will experience dominant/ordered dispatch behavior among multiple identical assets. In other words, identical assets tend not have the same power solutions as might be expected. An easy example: two identical assets A and B with rated power 100kW and constant efficiency (no minimum power requirements, no additional OPEX / other costs, etc.) shall cover a constant load of 100kW. Optimal power dispatch solutions are:

  • A: 100kW, B: 0kW
  • A: 50kW, B: 50kW
  • A: 0 kW, B: 100kW

In fact, there are infinitely many equivalent solutions, namely all, that have a combined power output sum of A and B equal to 100kW. ISED symmetry breaking will disincentivize the power production of asset B with a very small weighting factor and as a result the optimal solution presented by the dispatch optimizer will be:

  • A: 100kW, B: 0kW

Minimum or Maximum Power Output

Many assets that have a heat balance table also contain parameters that describe the minimum and maximum output power (as a function of time).

Minimum and Maximum Load for Assets with a Heat Balance Table

The assets that have a starting mode (Gas Turbine, Gas Engine, Steam Turbine) are not limited by a minimum power while starting. Similarly, Maximum output is only a limiting factor if it is less than 100%:

  • Minimum output power < First row of HBT -- First row of HBT is active
  • Minimum output power > First row of HBT -- Minimum output power is active
  • Maximum output power < Last row of HBT -- Maximum output power is active
  • Maximum output power > Last row of HBT -- Last row of HBT is active
For assets without a starting mode (Boiler, CompressionChiller, HeatPump, Electrolyzer, FuelCell), the minimum and maximum out powers are always active, as long as they are between 0 and 100%:
  • Minimum output power < First row of HBT -- Minimum output power is active
  • Minimum output power > First row of HBT -- Minimum output power is active
  • Maximum output power < Last row of HBT -- Maximum output power is active
  • Maximum output power > Last row of HBT -- Last row of HBT is active

Outages schedule

Outages overview
Outages Definition Max: In January, the asset is down everyday from 2am to 5am.

Many assets have an outages schedule which reflects scheduled/unscheduled downtime of the asset. While in such a period, the asset may not produce or consume power. In the Overview tab, the outages over the entire year are visualized. To define the downtime, the user selects a year and switches to the Definition Max tab. Here the user can define the downtimes on an hourly base for every single day in a month by marking the corresponding downtime hours as "0" (default color = blue). The user can then apply the defined downtime of any defined month to any other month. When switching back to the overview, the outages schedule of one year can also be applied to other years.

To define planned downtime, the user may load a profile via text file. A valid file has two values per line (timestamp) (value). Where (timestamp) is the time in seconds from the beginning of the year, and (value) =0 if in downtime, and (value)=1 if not in downtime. This time series supports a sparse formatting, and so only transitions (breakdowns and repair times) must be included.

Availability

Availability

Many assets have an Availability parameter, which allows the user to include planned or unplanned downtime. While in such a period, the asset may not produce or consume power. To define unplanned downtime, the user can define the number of expected faults per month throughout the year, as well as the minimum and maximum amount of downtime per occurrence.

To define planned downtime, the user may load a profile via text file. A valid file has two values per line (timestamp) (value). Where (timestamp) is the time in seconds from the beginning of the year, and (value) =0 if in downtime, and (value)=1 if not in downtime. This time series supports a sparse formatting, and so only transitions (breakdowns and repair times) must be included.

Potential errors include:

  • Text characters - only "0" and "1" are valid entries for an availability time series values.
  • Commas - In some countries, commas are used to denote values smaller than 1. Do not use commas in ISED
  • Thousand separators - Do not use comma separators when loading a time series for thousands, millions, etc.
  • Time stamps must be increasing - Do not list the availability out of chronological order. This is relevant especially for multiple years. e.g. 1 minute = 60s. 1 year = 365 * 24 * 60 * 60 = 31536000. The first minute of year 2 = 31536000 + 60 = 31536060.

Replacement Strategy

Replacement Strategy Pop-up with Default Strategy

Many assets have a replacement strategy parameter, which allows the user to specify what happens with the asset after its end of life is reached. If the user does not specify anything the default strategy is applied.

The default strategy is that the asset is replaced by an identical asset with exactly the same configuration except that the lifetime counter is reset to the maximal lifetime.

The second replacement strategy is that the asset will be removed from the deployment after its end of life is reached.

The third replacement strategy is that the asset is replaced by possibly multiple other assets. This means that the asset is removed from the deployment after its end of life is reached and instead possibly multiple other replacement assets are installed. Once the user has chosen this option the available replacement assets are shown and can be marked, see this figure. The available set of replacement assets consists of those assets for which the replacement column is checked in the asset section; Furthermore, each replacement asset can only be installed as replacement for one specific asset. For this reason only those replacement assets are listed in the figure which are not yet assigned to another asset.

Pop-up with Replacement by other Assets

Other Common Parameters

Must Run: For a asset, if the 'Must run' parameter is set to 'true', then the minimum allowed power is always enforced. If the minimum allowed power is not zero, this will mean that the unit must be running, and cannot turn 'Off'. If it is not possible to operate the asset at at least the minimum allowed power, then this will trigger a blackout. The 'Must run' parameter does not affect starting modes (e.g. gas turbine, CHP, steam turbine).

Maximum annual full load hours: The maximum number of full load hours that each individual unit is allowed to operate during a year. For generators, this value is per generator unit. If this value is empty, then it is ignored.

Maximum annual running hours: The maximum number of running hours that each individual unit is allowed to operate during a year. For generators, this value is per generator unit. If this value is empty, then it is ignored.

Full load scaling factor: This value scales with the rated capacity of an asset. This value is used to determine the amount of 'Full load hours' that an asset has operated in a year, which can be limited by the 'Maximum annual full load hours [h]' parameter.

Loads

Electric Load

Electric Load in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

Electric Load is the load that serves the DES customer needs. It usually does not contain losses. Losses are assumed to associate with assets and must be parameterized there. An electric load may be assigned costs for not satisfying it. This can be used for example to quantify blackout costs.

Parameters - by category

Capacity

Load [kW]
A time series describing the requested load in [kW]
Default load [kW]
When no time series is set for "Load[kW]", this value is used.

Stability (Grid, OR)

Operating reserve
Operating reserve is additional energy that the dispatcher must ensure available (e.g. online), so that if an unexpected change in either load or generation occurs. This concept allows short term changes in loads and renewable energy generation to occur without causing blackouts, because additional generation is available to meet these changes. Operating reserve has an associated cost, as it requires more generation to be online, therefore a system should be defined so that only the necessary operating reserve is kept.
Relative Operating reserve [pu]
A time series describing the required relative operating reserve. The relative operating reserve is calculated by a factor of the load and the timeseries at each time step. Therefore, if the load or the time series increases in a time step, then the relative operating reserve also increases.
Default relative operating reserve [pu]
If no time series is set for "Relative Operating Reserve [pu]", this value is used. This is a fixed value that is multiplied with the load at each time step. Therefore, if the load increases in a time step, then the relative operating reserve also increases. Typcially relative operating reserve is set to cover multiple loads that accumulate as the load increases.
Peak Operating Reserve [pu]
A time series describing the required peak operating reserve. The maximum load value in a year is multiplied with the Peak Operating Reserve time series at each time step. Therefore, if the time series increases in a time step, then the peak operating reserve also increases.
Default Peak Operating Reserve [pu]
If no time series is set for "Peak Operating Reserve [pu]", this value is used. The maximum load value in a year is multiplied with the Peak Operating Reserve default value at each time step. Therefore, the peak operating reserve is constant independent of whether the load increases at a time step or not. Typically the peak operating reserve is set for the largest load in a system that might start unexpectedly, e,g. a large motor; so that enough operating reserve is always available when the load is started.
Requires redundancy
If true, the load requires the existence of redundant power generation capabilities. This parameter is only active if the dispatcher must provide redundancy. If a load is critical and must be considered in the redundancy calculation then this value should be true. If a load is defined as non-critical and does not need to be considered in the redundancy calculation, then this value should be false.

Shedding

Shedding priority
When Shedding Priority is -1, this is a primary load, otherwise it is sheddable.

When the loads cannot be met, sheddable loads can remain unfullfilled. Sheddable loads with high priority numbers are shedded first. All sheddable loads with the same priority are shedded simultaneously.

Starting priority
After being shed, loads with low priority numbers are started first
Shedding event cost [EUR]
One-time cost incurred when load is shed, e.g. penalties due to startup times for the production process, damaged equipment replacement costs
Shedding time cost [EUR/h]
Hourly cost incurred while load is shed, e.g. penalties due to production losses over time.
Minimum shedding duration [s]
Minimum required downtime before safe operation may resume
Ramp rate after shedding [%/s]
Ramp up of load can take a certain time (relative to requested power). A value of 1 means that it will take 100 seconds to ramp up the full load after a shedding event.

Time

Installation delay [y]
The time delay (in years) after simulation start at which the asset is installed. CAPEX is booked and OPEX start after this delay. A delay of 5 years means that the unit starts producing at the beginning of year 6.

Explanation for Load Model

Loads require a certain amount of Operating Reserve, how much is specified in the corresponding parameters. That means, other assets should be able to deliver an additional amount of power to guard against short term fluctuations. Moreover, if redundancy is required, it is ensured that

Loads that are not tagged as primary loads can be shedded, i.e. the dispatcher can decide not to fulfill these loads and pay the specified shedding costs instead.

Deferrable Load

Deferrable Electrical Load in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

This is a load that can be connected to a reservoir. Together the load and the reservoir allow configuring a deferrable load, i.e. a load that must be satisfied at some point, but is decoupled by storage. A water tower with an outflow is a good example. The "water load" must be satisfied but this imposes no restrictions on the electrical load of the pumps as long as the tank is not empty and not full.

Parameters - by category

Economics

Charging incentive [EUR/kWh]
The deferrable load increases storage only when power is available at cost below the value of the charging incentive [EUR/kWh]

Capacity

Load [m³/h]
A timeseries for the outlet flow rate from the deferrable load's storage, e.g. for a fluid reservoir this may be a volume flow rate [m³/h]
Default load [m³/h]
When no time series is set for "Load", this value is used.
Conversion curve [x: kW, y:m³/h]
Curve defining transfer function from electric input power in kW into inlet flow rate. e.g. for a fluid reservoir, this may be in [m³/hr / kW]. The upper and lower limit of the curve also define the limits of operation for the load, i.e. maximum and minimum power consumption at a given time.
Storage capacity [m³]
Maximum capacity of the deferrable load e.g. for a fluid reservoir this may be in [m³]
Maximum capacity timeseries [%]
Timeseries defining the maximum allowable fraction of the storage capacity [%]
Default maximum capacity [%]
When no time series is set for "Maximum capacity timeseries", this value is used.
Minimum capacity timeseries [%]
Timeseries defining the minimum allowable fraction of the storage capacity [%]
Default minimum capacity [%]
When no time series is set for "Minimum capacity timeseries", this value is used.

Stability (Grid, OR)

Relative Operating reserve [pu]
A time series describing the required relative operating reserve.
Default relative operating reserve [pu]
If no time series is set for "Relative Operating Reserve [pu]", this value is used.
Peak Operating Reserve [pu]
A time series describing the required peak operating reserve.
Default Peak Operating Reserve [pu]
If no time series is set for "Peak Operating Reserve [pu]", this value is used.
Requires redundancy
If true, the load requires the existence of redundant power generation capabilities

Shedding

Shedding priority
When Shedding Priority is -1, this is a primary load, otherwise it is sheddable.

When the loads cannot be met, sheddable loads can remain unfulfilled. Sheddable loads with high priority numbers are shedded first. All sheddable loads with the same priority are shedded simultaneously.

Starting priority
After being shed, loads with low priority numbers are started first
Shedding event cost [EUR]
One-time cost incurred when load is shed, e.g. penalties in PPA, damaged equipment replacement costs
Shedding time cost [EUR/h]
Hourly cost incurred while load is shed, e.g. penalties in PPA, cost for loss of production
Minimum shedding duration [s]
Minimum required downtime before safe operation may resume
Ramp rate after shedding [%/s]
Ramp up of load can take a certain time (relative to requested power). A value of 1 means that it will take 100 seconds to ramp up the full load after a shedding event.

Time

Initial capacity level [%]
The initial capacity level of the deferrable load storage reservoir, as a fraction [%]
Installation delay [y]
The time delay (in years) after simulation start at which the asset is installed. CAPEX is booked and OPEX start after this delay. A delay of 5 years means that the unit starts producing at the beginning of year 6.

Explanation for Deferrable Load Model

Deferrable Loads Model Explanation

Deferrable electric loads are loads that have some flexibility in when they need to be fulfilled. Flexibility means that the power required for the load can be supplied at an optimal point in time (e.g. when energy is cheap, or renewable energy is available) Typically, there is a reservoir or other other physical buffer (e.g. building thermal latency, industrial process latency). The model includes a conversion unit (e.g. pump for a water or similar) if a ISED model is being used, this conversion can be set to 1. The model is indifferent to the medium and storage type. The user must define units and conversion. For the example of a water storage reservoir, in order to fill the water storage, power has to be used by the pump. The conversion curve specifies how much input power is needed for a given flow rate.

In order to make sure, that a single-step dispatcher, which only knows the present situation, fills the storage, the charging incentive can be used.

Like electric loads, deferrable electric loads require operation reserve and can be shedded.

Thermal Load (Steam, Hot Water, Cold Water)

Various Thermal Loads in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

The Thermal Load allows the user to specify the load which shall be met, either using a time series or a constant value. The Thermal Load can also be installed at a time later than the start of simulation. The Thermal Load is an optional asset; it is not required for simulation, if instead a Deferrable Thermal Load is used.

Currently, all thermal loads are primary loads, i.e. all thermal loads must be fulfilled to avoid blackouts.

External Energy Networks

Grid

Grid in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

For energy imports the Grid is usually modeled as an IPP with a grid-asset inside, which sells energy at cost. By default all grid-assets are assigned to an IPP called Grid. All energy export go to some undefined anonymous external grid. Each IPP or offtaker generation facility is assigned a tariff, at which it sells to this grid.

Explanation for Grid Model

Demand Charges

The user can choose between two kinds of demand charges: Monthly Demand Charges and Yearly Ratchet Demand Charges.

Since the maximum energy demand dictates the size of transmission lines, transformers, etc. it may be reasonable to use energy storage systems (ESS) or other power generation units in order to reduce the maximum peak power demand from the grid connection

If the use case Demand Charge Reduction is activated (parameters in the UI are set) in the grid asset, the dispatchers 'Robust Single-Step' and 'Multi-Step' will take the additional costs from these time-dependent demand charges into account and relevant KPIs will be computed.

An example Monthly Demand Charge Use Case from California looks like this:

  • 00:00 -- 16:00 & 21:00 -- 00:00: Off-Peak
  • 16:00 -- 21:00: On-Peak
  • Costs:
    • Off-Peak: 20.62 $ / kWp (see Figure X1: green)
    • Winter On-Peak (November -- May): 37.14 $ / kWp (see Figure X1: yellow)
    • Summer On-Peak (June -- October): 48.02 $ / kWp (see Figure X1: red)

Monthly Demand Charges

If the grid connection has an active Monthly Demand Charge Reduction use case, for every Tariff the dispatcher keeps track of the maximum power consumption from the grid (grid to bus) for every month. If this maximum exceeds the expected peak power for this tariff, the dispatcher enforces penalty costs. If you as a user are not able to estimate the expected peak power, zero as default input is used. The dispatcher will continually update the current peak power and make an economic dispatch decision accordingly.

In the transition phase from one month to the next the dispatcher is doing the following:

  • If no estimate for the expected peak power is given, the dispatcher will implictly try to reduce the peak power in the next month down to 80% of the peak power in the current month.
  • If a user input is available, the dispatcher tries to reduce the peak in the next month to this specific value.

In case of undesired behavior, like increase of peak power in the last day of a month, please check your input for expected peak power.

Coincidental Peaks

Coincidental Peaks (CPs) consider the electrical energy imported by a customer (at the site level) during periods when a utility or region has its highest electrical demand in a 12-month period. Typically, 1 to 5 CPs are used, and these must occur on different days (i.e. there cannot be two CPs on the same day). Utilities or regions have specific definitions of dates when CPs may occur, and how they are defined.

Service providers track demand and weather conditions to provide a forecast of when CPs might occur. It is common to have a forecast where up to 20 possible CP events are predicted 24 hours in advance. Based on this forecast, customers can use ESS, onsite generation or reduce loads to minimize their imported electrical energy during a CP. These CP forecasts have inaccuracies, and many customers may try to avoid the same potential CP, thereby changing the electrical demand of the utility or region. Therefore, there is a risk that the actual CP period differs from the forecast CP. It is common practice to try and reduce loads both before and after a forecast CP to increase the probability of have a low load during the actual CP, which is determined after the 12-month period is complete.

The following examples of CPs are known to be applied. Other examples may exist:

  • PJM, US: 5 CPs/a,
  • ERCOT, US: 4 CPs/a,
  • NY, US: 2 CPs/a,
  • ISO NE, US: 1 CP/a,
  • IESO (Ontario), CA: 5 CPs/a.

Implementation in ISED

For the implementation of Coincidental Peaks in ISED a timeseries is used to define the periods when potential CPs may occur. Each period should include a forecast CP, as well as any time before or after that is used to minimize risk of missing an actual CP.

The ideas for including this use case into the dispatchers are the following:

  • If in a time step potentially a Coincidental Peak occurs, the additional costs defined by Dispatch: Coincidental Peak Costs [EUR/kWh] are added to the objective function of the dispatcher.
  • This discourages the dispatcher from utilizing the grid during potentially expensive Coincidental Peak periods.
  • For the Robust Single-Step Dispatcher this may lead to an empty battery over time. It is therefore possible to add an additional charging incentive in case of activated triads depending on the SOC of the battery: Multiply the existing charging incentive with a factor f(x) determined as a linear interpolation such that

    • f(BA.maxEnergy) = 1

    and

    f(BA.minEnergy) = max {1, coincidentalPeakCost}.

Energy Contract

Energy can sometimes be purchased more cheaply in advance for a defined timeframe. This fixes the costs for both the purchaser and seller over the contract period. The Energy Contract algorithm allows this to be modeled in an electrical grid connection.

Energy Contract

The Energy Contract allows:

  1. Activation of the algorithm (Activated)
  2. Definition of multiple energy contracts. Only one contract can be active at a particular point in time. Each contract must be assigned to an integer, and a time series defines the active contract (Time Series for Defining Active Contract). A 0 value means that no contract is active, and the normal grid import and export prices will be used.
  3. The expected consumption of a contract integrated over time. The user must define how the energy is expected to be used over time. This is defined in a cumulative timeseries for each contract. The algorithm attempts to follow this forecast. The larger the deviation, the stronger the incentive is to return to the forecast. For example, it could be that higher consumptions are expected during the week, and consumption is lower during weekends. An appropriate curve would adjust for this accordingly.
  4. For each contract, the energy price can be defined as a fixed value in Contract Costs.
  5. For each contract, an overshoot limit can be defined. Within this limit, overshoot energy can still be purchased at the contract cost.
  6. For each contract, an undershoot limit can be defined. No costs are incurred for energy not purchased in the undershoot range.
  7. For each contract, an overshoot cost can be defined. Any energy that is consumed in addition to the expected consumption + overshoot will be purchased at this price.
  8. or each contract, an undershoot cost can be defined. Any energy that is not consumed relative to the expected consumption - undershoot will incur a penalty at this price.

Below is an example with two energy contracts.

  1. Contract 1 runs from January to the end of April and then continues from the beginning of September until the end of October.
  2. Contract 2 runs from the beginning of May until the end of August.
  3. In November and December there isnt an energy contract.

Energy Contract Example

Contract 1 and 2 are optimized separately. The timeseries for Expected Consumed Energy [kWh] must start at 0 for contract 2 and return to the last value of contract 1 end of April when the contract starts again in September.

The parameter Time Series for Defining Active Contract must change accordingly. This means from January to the end of April and from the beginning of September until the end of October it has a value of 1. From the beginning of May until the end of August it has a value of 2. For November and December, it has a value of 0.

Note that if energy is exported, then the export price is not affected by the energy contract and it is exported as defined by the grid export price (constant, time series or ToU editor).

Balancing (Ancillary Services)

Grid Providers have to deal with variability in load. Service providers can provide Frequency Response and Power Reserve (positive export to grid, negative import from grid). Service providers can earn money from availability (declaring balancing capability) and utilization (actually providing power for balancing services). There may be a time gap between the signal that balancing is required and actual utilization (response time). Out of scope for now: Participation decision, a priori decision if assets can meet response time requirements (ramps).

Balancing 1

Balancing 2

A preprocessing step is carried out, to determine different "service modes" within availability periods. These are also logged within the dispatcher logs as "balancing service mode [-]"

Balancing Service Modes
Unavailable
[-2] - The Grid is either unavailable, or is this is not a declared period of availability for balancing.
Available
[-1] - The Grid is available, and this is beginning a declared period for availability for balancing.
Recovery Time
[0] - Recovery times are sometimes provided by the utility for ancillary services with ESS. It is a period during which the requirements for ancillary services are stopped so that an ESS can be charged or discharged as the ESS operator wants. It means that predominantly periods of charging or discharging the probability that the ESS reaches an SoC limit.
Response Time
[1] - The Grid has been notified of a pending utilization signal.
Utilization
[2] - The Grid is being utilized and is providing balancing within the contstraints of the contract.

Balancing 3

If Balancing Requested Power is non-zero outside of periods deemed as "utilization", this will be ignored.

The only information the service provider knows in advance is whether balancing is currently available, and the maximum offered capacities. In particular, it is not known in advance when balancing will be utilized. To simulate this, the Balancing Requested power is not included in the forecast of the multi-step dispatcher.

If the project contains an ESS, the parameters "Required Time for Positive/Negative Battery Reserve" are important. The dispatcher uses these parameters to calculate how much energy must be reserved for ancillary services. The dispatcher then only uses the remaining capacity of the ESS to provide additional functionality. For example, an ESS may provide energy shift peak shaving simultaneously while providing ancillary services.

Balancing parameters

Balancing (Ancillary Services): Activated

Determines if Tariff Use Case "Balancing Services" is active.

Balancing: Offered Availability Time Series

Defines when balancing services are offered. 1 = availability is being offered; 0 when not.

Balancing Requested power Time Series [kW]

Defines when balancing is requested. Positive values mean "deliver more power to the grid" (decrease import / increase export). Negative values mean "deliver less power to the grid" (decrease export / increase import).

Balancing: Follow Expected Grid Power Setpoint When Balancing Offered

If true, the time series defined in Balancing: Expected Grid Power Setpoint Without Balancing Requests Time Series is used by the dispatcher as the hypothetical reference for grid power setpoint if balancing had not been offered. It is only respected when balancing is offered (i.e. the same if the balancing service mode = -1, and this setpoint minus the Requested power when the balancing service mode = 2.

Balancing: Expected Grid Power Setpoint Without Balancing Requests Time Series [kW]

Defines the expected power setpoint of the grid if the balancing request = 0. Positive values mean "import" negative values mean "export". This timeseries is not interpolated.

This is useful in projects with loads and on-site generation, for example PV or a CHP. Utilities will expect sites that provide balancing power to show that they have added or reduced power relative to their normal grid consumption. This time series represents the normal grid consumption.

For generation only projects, then this time series should normally be zero.

The easiest way to define this time series is to run a project with balancing deactivated, and then copy the electrical grid power setpoint. The easiest way to define this time series is to run a project with balancing deactivated, and then copy the electrical grid power setpoint.

This time series is only respected if Balancing: Follow Expected Grid Power Setpoint When Balancing Offered is set to true.

Balancing: Max. Offered Positive/Negative Balancing Power [kW]

Positive: Maximum positive balancing power (increase of export to grid / reduction of import from grid) as Time Series. This timeseries is not interpolated.

Negative: Maximum negative balancing power (increase of import from grid /reduction of export to grid) as Time Series. This timeseries is not interpolated.

If ESS is used for balancing, then this parameter is used together with the parameters Balancing: Required Time For Positive/Negative ESS Reserve [s] to determine the ESS SoC so long Balancing Requested power Time Series = 0kW.

Balancing: Response Time [s]

Maximum response time to a balancing request, typically defined by the network utility.

The response is typically intended for different technologies. Shorter response times typically have higher revenue. Gas turbines might participate in a market with a 15-minute response time, ESS is often used in a market with a response time < 2 seconds.

This parameter should be equal or longer than the simulation timestep (ideally it should be a multiple of the timestep).For example, for ESS set this to 0. For other assets like GTs that have a longer ramp rate, this response time should coincide with the simulation timestep.

Balancing: Recovery Time [s]

Minimum period after an utilization request, during which balancing power does not need to be provided. Typically a network utility will provide this to allow ESS to recharge.

Balancing: Maximum Duration of Utilization [s]

Maximum duration of balancing utilization. Typically a network utility defines this to allow ESS to participate. 0 is interpreted as no duration limit is given. If the balancing service mode is [2] (Utilization) for this period of time, then the balancing service is considered complete, and the balancing service mode will change to 0 (recovery time). This allows an ESS to be charged or discharged as necessary to have a suitable SoC.

Balancing: Maximum duration of null utilization requests [s]

If the requested power remains zero for this period after a utilization request, the corresponding utilization period is considered to be over.

Balancing: Required Time For Positive/Negative ESS Reserve [s]

The dispatcher uses this parameter to calculate the battery capacity that must be reserved for ancillary services. The dispatcher only uses remaining capacity to provide different functionality. For example, an ESS may provide energy shift peak shaving simultaneously while providing ancillary services.

Balancing: Income per hour for offered power (sum of positive and negative balancing power) [EUR/h/kW]

Income per hour of offered availability for balancing services.

Balancing: Default income per hour for offered power (sum of positive and negative balancing power) [EUR/h/kW]

Default value for income per hour available, used if no time series is set.

Balancing: Reward during Positive/Negative Balancing [EUR/kWh]

Price paid by the Grid provider during negative balancing (either increase imports or reduce exports relative to Expected Grid Power Setpoint Without Balancing Requests Time Series). This value is used if the "Reward during Negative Balancing Time Series" is not defined.

Balancing: Reward during Positive/Negative Balancing Time Series [EUR/kWh]

Price paid by the Grid provider during positive balancing (either reduce imports or increase exports relative to Expected Grid Power Setpoint Without Balancing Requests Time Series). This value is used if the "Reward during Positive Balancing Time Series" is not defined.

Balancing: Bound for Overfulfillment/Underfulfillment of Balancing [p.u.]

Overfulfillment: (1 + this fraction) of the requested balancing is the upper bound for interaction with the Grid.

Underfulfillment: (1 - this fraction) of the requested balancing is the lower bound for interaction with the Grid.

Balancing: Penalty per failure event [EUR]

Penalty incurred in the event of not meeting or only partially meeting a utilization request (i.e. exporting/importing power outside of the defined bounds). This timeseries is not interpolated.

Balancing: Default penalty per failure event [EUR]

Default penalty per failure event, used if no time series is set

Balancing: Time-based failure penalties [EUR/h]

Time-based penalties incurred while not meeting or only partially meeting utilization requests (i.e. exporting/importing power outside of the defined bounds). This timeseries is not interpolated.

Balancing: Default time-based failure penalties [EUR/h]

Default time-based failure penalties, used if no time series is set.

Balancing 4

During utilization, dispatchers have to respect bounds on the grid setpoints, which are computed using several inputs: Over-/Undershoot Limits, Balancing Requests Timeseries and Balancing Reference Values Timeseries (if available). The over- and undershoot limit together with the requests timeseries are used to calculate upper and lower bounds on the required amount of balancing. The reference values timeseries represents the expected behaviour of the Grid without balancing, i.e. they provide a baseline for the grid. This could either be imported or exported energy which was sold or purchased on a day-ahead energy market or a certain "normal usage" like a load, which is usually met by the grid. During utilization, the balancing bounds are combined with the reference values to compute the actual bounds for the setpoints. We will explain this using the example in the linked figure. Here, we have a load of 600, which is usually met by the grid and a balancing contract which rewards deviation from "normal" behaviour, therefore the baseline is set to 600 (matching the expected grid setpoint). Now, a balancing request of 500 is a request to decrease the grid setpoint by 500 kW. Therefore, during utilization we are required to import only 100 kW from the grid, while the remaining load has to be supplied by another asset, in this case the battery. Of course, the upper and lower bounds on the grid capacity are respected as well.

If no reference values are set (which makes sense in a project without committed amounts of power exports to or imports from the grid), the baseline is treated as if it were 0. In that case, a balancing request of 500 would lead to a grid setpoint of -500, meaning that other assets have to supply enough power that 500kW can be exported to the grid.

The question whether a reference values timeseries (baseline) is needed ultimately depends on the specific balancing contract: Does the grid provider pay for modification of "normal" or committed usage or for actual imported and exported energy? It is assumed that if ancillary services are offered, the ISED user intends for these to be fulfilled, therefore a black warning is triggered if they are not. If you are trying to fault find, or if you deliberately want to simulate unfulfilled ancillary services, you should set the check box for Ignore blackouts on the dispatcher tab to true.

Balancing 5

German Tariff Use Cases

ISED implements functionality to analyze two discount opportunities offered by German grid operators: atypical usage (atypische Netznutzung), for users with power consumption peaks outside of high-demand periods, and intensive usage (intensive Netznutzung), for very large power consumers that have a power consumption relatively constant in time (no large power peaks).

Atypical usage

Example of a consumption pattern which fulfills the criteria of atypical usage. ® User:Acteno / Wikimedia Commons / CC-BY-SA-3.0

German grid operators charge consumers for the total annual consumption (per kWh imported in a year) and for the annual peak power (per kW). In addition, they define in advance a set of high demand periods during which the total demand on the grid is expected to be high. Atypical usage discounts apply only to peak power charges, and are granted to consumers whose annual peak power during high demand periods is considerably smaller than their overall annual peak power.

  • Peak reduction factor
  • Overall annual peak power
  • Annual peak power within high demand periods

Atypical usage discounts only apply to users for which the peak reduction factor exceed a certain minimum value defined by the grid operator: the peak reduction threshold.

If a consumer qualifies for the discount, their peak charges are calculated based on their peak imported within the high demand period ( ) instead of the overall peak ( ).

Typical studies of this use cases involve the scaling of Energy Storage Systems (ESS), used to reduce the imported power within the height demand windows. In such cases, it is recommended to set up the ISED project with at least two variations: one including no ESS (or an ESS of zero capacity) and one with the ESS. If the "Atypical usage activated" parameter is activated for both variations, an estimation of the savings can be done by comparing the KPIs from the two variations.

Intensive Usage Intensive usage discounts are applied on the condition that the user imports at least 10 GWh in the course of the year and that they achieve a minimum value of the usage hours ("Benutzungstunden") parameter. This parameter is calculated according to the following formula

  • Benutzungstunden
  • Energy consumed within the year
  • Annual peak power imported

The minimum value of usage to qualify for this discount is 7000h.

The actual value of the discount depends on details of physical connection between the consumer and the grid. However, upper bounds for the discounts (which can reach up to 90%) are tabulated as a function of Benutzungstunden. These discounts are applied to total grid operator charges (those based on power peak and those based on energy consumption).

Analysis of Alternative Energy Prices (>2500h) Consumers that qualify for atypical usage discounts also have the possibility of being charged based on alternative energy and power prices, specifically those applicable to consumers with usage hours larger than 2500h. The energy price in this case is much lower, but the peak power price is much higher.

When the atypical usage feature is used, ISED calculates cash flow KPIs for both prices. By default, the dispatchers only take into account the prices for lower Benutzungstunden (<2500h) values. To change this behavior, the "Atypical usage: Optimize on >2500h prices" can be activated, making the dispatcher consider the ">2500h" instead. When both optimization strategies are of interested, a variation on that parameter can be used (see figure).

Analysis of Alternative Energy Prices

When a variation on the "Atypical usage: Optimize on >2500h prices" is setup like in the figure, two simulations will be run: One with dispatch optimization based on the "<2500h" prices and one using the ">2500h" prices.

KPIs

German Tariff KPIs: Grid operator charges in the German market are based on yearly values (consumption and power peaks), but are charged monthly. Based on the common charging practice followed by grid operators, monthly KPIs from January to November are calculated assuming the discounts will be met at the end of the year. In case the discounts are not met at the end of the year, or need to be adjusted, the retroactive charge is reflected in the December KPI.

In addition, monthly peak charges are calculated as one-twelfth of the yearly peak charged and based on the year-to-date peaks at the end of the month. In months in which the peak increases, a retroactive charge compensating for the lower price charged in previous is incurred and reflected in the KPIs. This is calculated as the difference between the sum of all monthly peak charges (from January to the current month) based on the new year-to-date peak minus the charges already made in the previous months (since January).

Atypical usage: Grid operator energy charges (under 2500h) (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual energy consumption based on the "<2500h" tariffs.

Atypical usage: Grid operator energy charges (over 2500h) (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual energy consumption based on the ">2500h" tariffs. This tariff is only available when the criteria for atypical usage discounts is met (a high enough peak reduction factor is achieved). This reflected by the KPI, which shows the actual incurred cost (based in the "<2500h" tariff) in the cases in which the simulation results do not achieve the atypical usage criteria. Consistent with the rest of these KPIs, for monthly KPIs this is reflected in the December KPI, while KPIs between January and November are calculated assuming the discount criteria is met.

Atypical usage: Grid operator peak power charges (under 2500h) (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual peak power based on the "<2500h" tariffs.

Atypical usage: Grid operator peak power charges (over 2500h) (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual peak power based on the ">2500h" tariffs. This tariff is only available when the criteria for atypical usage discounts is met (a high enough peak reduction factor is achieved). This reflected by the KPI, which shows the actual incurred cost (based in the "<2500h" tariff) in the case in which the simulation results do not achieve the atypical usage criteria. Consistent with the rest of these KPIs, for monthly KPIs this is reflected in the December KPI, while KPIs between January and November are calculated assuming the discount criteria is met.

Atypical usage: Peak reduction factor (%) The difference between the overall peak power and the peak power inside high-demand windows, expressed as a percent of the overall peak. Monthly KPIs show year-to-date values of this parameter (i.e. using peak values between start of the year and end of corresponding month).

Atypical usage: Annual peak power (kW) Overall peak power. Monthly KPIs show year-to-date values.

Atypical usage: Annual high demand peak power (kW) Peak power within high demand periods. Monthly KPIs show year-to-date values.

Intensive usage: Grid operator energy charges (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual energy consumption. When intensive usage is activated ">2500h" grid operator tariffs are used.

Intensive usage: Grid operator peak power charges (EUR) Indicated the grid operator charges based on annual peak power When intensive usage is activated ">2500h" grid operator tariffs are used.

Intensive usage: Annual peak power (kW) Peak power. Monthly KPIs show year-to-date values.

Intensive usage: Usage hours (Benutzungstunden) (h) Yearly values indicate the Benutzungstunden. Monthly values represent a projected Benutzungstunden value, calculated as the quotient between the projected annual energy consumption, based on the year-to-date average consumption, and the year-to-date peak power.

Grid Ramprates

Use Cases Ramprates on grid assets are intended to simulate the situation where a hybrid power plant is grid connected and the grid code penalizes power increase or decreases at the point of common coupling, if they exceed certain predefined levels. If the hybrid plant is primarily composed of strongly fluctuating energy sources such as photovoltaics, this situation exposes the plant operator to a financial risk, if he cannot guarantee the required ramprates.

In these cases a ISED simulation is intended answer the following question:

  • What is the financial risk if renewable fluctuations are directly translated to power fluctuations on the point of common coupling
  • Is it a financially beneficial strategy to mitigate the risks by curtailing a fixed amount of renewable energies proactively in anticipation of drops in production
  • Can the financial invest into a storage system be justified by the avoided penalties

Grid Asset To simulate such a use case first of all a grid asset must parameterized to reflect the grid code.

Ramprate for increased exports

This parameter contains the ramp rate restrictions for increased exports to the grid. If the grid also provides power to the plant the parameter also limits decrease in imports. The ramprates pose no hard limit. They merely indicate above which level of change penalties start to apply.

Ramprate for decreased exports

This parameter applies to the change, if exports decrease or imports increase.

Ramprate estimation interval

This is the measurement interval which used to determine the penalties. If within the interval the power increases by more than p kW above the allowed ramprate, the penalties for p kW in this interval are incurred.

Ramprate infringement cost for increased exports

With this parameter the penalties can be configured. The table contains the penalties per kW by which the ramprate is exceeded.

The following table provides an example.

A violation of 300kW is penalized by:

300kW*0.0025 /kW = 0.75 .

A violation of 1MW is penalized by:

1000kW*0.005 /kW = 5 .

A violation of 20MW is penalized by :

20000kW*(0.05 /kW-0.005 /kw)/(10000kW-1000kW)*20000kW = 2000 ,

because the table is linearly interpolated between points and linearly extrapolated at the end.

Ramprate infringement cost

Ramprate infringement cost for decreased exports

A second table is provided to configure penalties for decreased exports.

Timestep size and resolution The timestep size should be 1 minute (or below), as the renewable fluctuations are otherwise masked by insufficient resolution in time. By the same token all timeseries for such simulation should be provided in 1 minute resolution.

Use Case 1: What is the financial risk if renewable fluctuations are directly translated to power fluctuations on the point of common coupling Set up a grid with ramp rates and penalties. Set the PV operating reserve to 0. This way the PV is assumed fully trustable and all fluctuation in the PV are also seen at the point of common coupling.

Use case 1

In this case very little PV energy is curtailed but the export revenues on cloudy days are small compared to the penalties.

Use Case 2: Is it a financially beneficial strategy to mitigate the risks by curtailing a fixed amount of renewable energies proactively in anticipation of drops in production To simulate this use case set the operating reserve of the PV to e.g. 0.3. This way PV production is assumed to drop at any time by 30%. The exports to the grid are automatically reduced such that a 30% will not result in penalties.

Use Case 2

The curtailment is now higher but the penalties are lower.

The penalties are reduced as arriving clouds are detected and exports are

Use Case 3: Can the financial invest into a storage-system be justified by the avoided penalties Set the PV operating reserve to 1, i.e. do not trust the PV infeed at all and add a battery with power to compensate for all possible fluctuations, i.e. PV peak power.

Use Case 3

In this case all PV energy can be exported and not penalties are incurred. The state of charge of the battery is automatically adapted to always contain sufficient energy.

Net metering

Net metering is a billing mechanism that credits solar energy system owners for the electricity they add to the grid.

Annual vs. monthly billing

In NEM 2.0 customers may choose between annual an monthly billing. In NEM 3.0, incurred charges must be paid every month. Annual billing: Solar customers pay once a year for their net energy consumption instead of every month. The true up month has no effect on the true up statement, because credits form excess energy production can be used to cancel out consumption form any month in the year. Monthly billing: Credits must be built in the previous months before they can be used in future months.

True up month is the month when the 12-month billing cycle ends. At the end of the billing cycle, all charges and credits are reconciled to determine the remaining balance. For annual billing, true up month is set to December.

Non-bypassable cost [EUR/kWh] is charged per kWh of imported energy from the grid. NBCs are "non-bypassable" because they cannot be offset with the accumulated credits from solar energy.

Net surplus compensation rate [EUR/kWh] is paid out in case of remaining credits. Dividng the credits by the average export price over the billing cycle the equivalent value in kWh is determined. The determined power value is compensated with the NSCR that is usually much lower than the import price.

NEM 2.0 vs NEM 3.0

The major difference between NEM 2.0 and NEM 3.0 is the export price that is much lower in NEM 3.0. Under NEM 2.0, the price for providing excess self-generated power to the grid is equal to the export price of the grid. In NEM 3.0 the exported energy is recompensated with the whole-sale price. Since the revenue from exported energy can be used to offset import energy costs, in NEM 2.0 the owner can make signifcantly higher savings by selecting the ideal true up period compared to NEM 3.0.

Project Setup

  • Step 1: Activate Net Metering in the grid and define the required parameters for Net Metering. For NEM typically TOU schedules are used.

    Annual billing: True up month = 12 , Monthly billing: True up month from 1 to 12.

    NEM 2.0: Import price is equal to export price + NBC NEM 3.0: The export prices are in the same range as the NSCR and significantly lower than the import prices.

    Run the simulation with NEM start values set to zero.

    Step 2 is only necessary in case of monthly billing (only available for NEM 2.0).

    • NEM parameters with Start values equal zero
  • Step 2: Retrieve the end-of-year values from the logs and set these as NEM start values. Rerun the simulation to obtain the correct balance for the specified true-up month in the logs.

    • Results from simulation with start values equal zero

    Set end-of-year values as NEM start values

    Results from simulation with start values from end-of-year values from first simulation

If "false" the dispatcher considers grid operator energy and power peak prices assigned to lower Benutzungstuden values (<2500h). If "true" prices for larger Benutzungstunden values (>2500h) are considered.
Atypical usage: High demand windows
Timeseries with 1 and 0 values which indicates whether the corresponding point in time is within a high demand window (1 = yes, 0 = no).
Atypical usage: Expected peak power [kW]
Expected annual peak imported power, used to support dispatching to optimize for the "atypical usage" use case. Different values can be set for different years. If no value is set for a given simulation year, the closest earlier value is used.
Atypical usage: Discount threshold [%]
Minimum peak reduction factor necessary to qualify for "atypical usage discounts". Different values can be set for different years. If no value is set for a given simulation year, the closest earlier value is used.
Atypical usage: Discount threshold safety level [%]
Increases the discount threshold value the dispatcher will try to maintain. Adding a larger value here makes the dispatcher more conservative, but might lead to a less than optimal solution. A value of zero can set here for aggressive dispatching, but this could lead to failure to meet the "atypical usage" criteria for complex configurations. Different values can be set for different years. If no value is set for a given simulation year, the closest earlier value is used.
Intensive usage activate
Activates the "intensive usage" ("intensive Netznutzung") tariff use case. When this use case is activated, grid operator energy and peak costs for larger Benutzungstuden values (>2500h) are considered used.
Intensive usage: Expected consumption [kWh]
Expected annual energy consumption, used to support dispatching in optimizing for the "intensive usage" use case. Different values can be set for different years. If no value is set for a given simulation year, the closest earlier value is used.
Intensive usage: Target usage hours (Benutzungstunden) [h]
Value of Benutzungstunden (quotient between annual energy consumption and annual peak power) that the dispatcher will try to achieve during optimization. Different values can be set for different years. If no value is set for a given simulation year, the closest earlier value is used.
Intensive usage: Discount levels [%]
Discount values applied to the grid operator (energy and peak) costs, given that a certain minimum Benutzungstunden value is reached.

Losses

Operational losses [kW]
Losses incurred during use. The value is absolute and does not scale with size
Hour of day losses [kW]
Losses as function over time in a day
Permanent losses [kW]
Losses are absolute and not scaled with size
Linked Asset
Dedicated Converter
Link to an assigned converter. If no converter is assigned a default converter with no limits or losses is assumed.

Emissions

Carbon content [g/kWh]
The amount of carbon dioxide produced for the generation and transport of energy to the project location. Note that this amount affects the total carbon footprint for a project, but is excluded from calculation of carbon taxes.

Time

Grid availability
Lifetime [y]
Lifetime, i.e. the time between replacements in years
Installation delay [y]
The time delay (in years) after simulation start at which the asset is installed. CAPEX is booked and OPEX start after this delay. A delay of 5 years means that the unit starts producing at the beginning of year 6.

EV Charging Station Layout

Model

EV Charging Station Editor

This parameter is used to describe the types of Electric Vehicles arriving to the station, as well as the behavior of these EVs (e.g. when they arrive, how long they remain, price information, etc). This behavior is described in a series of four tabs.

  1. Behavior - Define EV users and assign vehicles
  2. EV Tariffs - Define Tariffs specific to this EVStation
  3. Vehicles - Define Electric Vehicles
  4. Advanced Setup - Assign all tariffs

EV Charging Station - Behavior Tab

In this tab, EV users can be defined as Personas, and some basic attributes can be set.

  • a: The desired tab can be selected here.
  • b: The selected Persona is shown, and other personas can be selected.
  • c: The configuration can be saved, or downloaded to file.
  • d: The vehicle can be assigned for a persona. The vehicle is defined on the Vehicles tab.
  • e: A plot shows the arrivals for the selected persona, as well as the number of vehicles present. If selected, all vehicles covering all personas can also be shown.
  • f: By dragging the time selection window, the plot in 'e' can be extended from 1 week to 1 year.
  • g: Definition Days are used to define behavior for a persona over time.
  • h: By clicking on the edit icon (pencil) the detailed view becomes available (next picture).
  • i: OK will save the current state and close the popup, Cancel will not save the current state when closing.

EV Charging Station - behavior Tab - Definition Day

In this detailed section, the behavior for a persona can be defined.

  • a: Arrivals - defines the number of cars arriving in a given time period. The table can be used, or a timeseries can be selected. Only timeseries of type 'Unitless' can be selected.
  • b: Visit Time - defines the length of time that a vehicle arriving will remain at the EV Station in hours [h]. Visit Time must be positive whenever a vehicle is arriving. The table can be used, or a time series can be selected. Only timeseries of type 'Time' or 'Unitless' can be selected.
  • c: Initial SoC - defines the State of Charge of the vehicles when they arrive. The table can be used, or a timeseries can be selected. Only timeseries of type 'Percent' can be selected.
  • d: Target SoC - defines the State of Charge that the vehicles should have when leaving. If they are not charged to at least this value, then an undercharging penalty will occur. The table can be used, or a timeseries can be selected. Only timeseries of type 'Percent' can be selected.
  • e: The distance enabled by this charging is shown. The calculation is (target-initial SoC)* capacity * number of cars arriving / Vehicle efficiency.
  • f: The initial and target SoC are shown in blue.
  • g: the number of vehicles arriving ar shown as a dark blue line.
  • h: the Visit Time is shown in green
  • i: The changes must be applied or discarded before continuing.

EV Charging Station - Tariffs Tab

In this tab, tariffs can be defined. This UI is based off of the Time Of Use tariff UI.

  • a: New Tariffs can be defined, and the selected tariff is shown.
  • b: New price tariffs can be added or configured.
  • c: Using the paintbrushes, the tariffs can be defined throughout the year.

EV Charging Station - Vehicles Tab

In this tab, Vehicles can be defined.

  • a: New Vehicles can be defined, and the selected vehicle is shown.
  • b: The vehicle parameters can be defined.

EV Charging Station - Advanced Setup Tab

In this tab, all tariff details can be defined for all personas.

  • a: Personas are shown as rows in this tab.
  • b: All tariffs can be set here. Prices can be set to a constant value, or a tariff from the EV Tariffs tab can be used, or a timeseries from the main Resources tab can be selected. Only Timeseries of type 'Energy Price' can be selected.
  • c: V2G - Vehicle to Grid selected means that it is allowed for a vehicle to discharge at the discharge price. This is only allowed if the Vehicle is V2G capable, as defined on the Vehicles tab. If discharging price is lower than charging price, then the vehicles may enter arbitrage with each other. See the special topic below on 'EVStation - Arbitrage'.
  • d: Incentives do not affect KPIs, and only affect dispatcher behavior. They can be used in situations like this, where the user 'Facilities Staff' does not pay for their vehicle to be charged, but it is still desired to charge these vehicles.

For the charging and discharging powers, these will limit how much power could be supplied to or from a vehicle. This limit will be combined with the charging station limits, and the most restrictive of both will define the system limits.

For the charging and discharging efficiencies, these will reduce the amout of power sent from the charger that actually reaches the vehicle. These losses are combined with the charger losses (e.g. 95% charger efficiency and 90% Vehicle charging efficiency result in a total efficiency of 85.5%).

For the Battery Capacity - this defines the "full" capacity of a single vehicle in kWh.

For the Maximum/Minimum allowed SoC - these define absolute limits on the SoC for a single vehicle. Initial SoC must always be within these bounds.

If discharging is possible for a vehicle, then it may be discharged over a short time if economically desirable.

There are 6 types of Tariffs relevant for an EV Type:

  • Price for Charging [EUR/kWh] - The price for charging is constantly varying. Any EV in a persona always pays the same price.
  • Incentive for Charging [EUR/kWh] - This is an artificial dispatch incentive that can be used to steer the system to operate in a certain manner.
  • Price for Disharging [EUR/kWh] - The price for discharging is constantly varying. Any EV in a persona always receives the same price.
  • Incentive for Discharging [EUR/kWh] - This is an artificial dispatch incentive that can be used to steer the system to operate in a certain manner.
  • Undercharging Penalty [EUR/kWh] - A fixed penalty is defined when an EV arrives at the charging station; if not charged to its target SoC when leaving, this penalty is enforced on the charging station operator.
  • Overcharging Price [EUR/kWh] - A fixed price is defined when an EV arrives at the charging station; if charged above the target SoC when leaving, this price is enforced on the charging station operator.

InternalPV

InternalPV in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

A photovoltaic system, also PV system or solar power system, is a power system designed to supply usable solar power by means of photovoltaics. It consists of an arrangement of several assets, including solar panels to absorb and convert sunlight into electricity, a solar inverter to change the electric current from DC to AC, as well as mounting, cabling, and other electrical accessories to set up a working system.

Orientation Matrix
The orientation of various groups of PV panels in the installation Percentage [%]: The percentage of the total power installation in a given orientation (must sum to 100%) Direction: The direction in which the panels are facing. Default of 0 degrees is directly towards the equator. 90 degrees is either directly East or West. Tilt [deg]: The tilt from horizontal for the panels in the current group. Recommended angle is 23.5 degrees less than the latitude, but at least 10 degrees.
Efficiency at STC [%]
The cell efficiency under standard testing conditions. (usually 25 °C and 1000W/m 2 and no wind)
Inverter Efficiency [%]
Efficiency of the inverter
Efficiency Temperature Coefficient [% / K]
The (positive) term defining the loss in cell efficiency attributable to increases in cell temperature. Then, Net_Efficiency = Efficiency_At_STC * (1 - Efficiency_Temperature_Coefficient / 100 * (T_cell - T_STC))
Constant Heat Transfer Coefficient [W/m ° K]
Describes the effectiveness of the panel in venting heat to the environment. Typical values: [Freestanding - 29.0, Well Insulated - 15.0]
Convective Heat Transfer Coefficient [W/m ° K / m/s]
Describes the effectiveness of the panel in venting heat to the environment via wind. Typical values: [Freestanding - 0, Well Insulated - 0]
Incidence Effect Parameter
The ASHRAE parameterization factor of the incidence effect, accounting for the angle at which radiation strikes the panel
Ground Tilt [degrees]
If the PV is installed on a hillside, the tilt from horizontal of that hillside
Hourly Shading Loss Profile
The fractional loss of power due to shading. This daily profile reduces the DC power produced at the Solar Panels due to effects of self or near shading.

Explanation for PV System Model

Sunlight can be converted directly into electricity using PV-systems. The power supply of a PV-system to a grid is limited to the radiation of the sun and the size and efficiency of the PV-system. Therefore, the PV feed-in curves is based on two models: the solar irradiance model and the PV-system model.

The irradiance on a surface dominant daily generation patterns depending on the season and short-term effects induced by clouds and other weather phenomena. Total radiation hitting a surface includes three parts:

  • Direct Normal Irradiance (DNI): Sunlight that makes it directly through the atmosphere and hits the surface
  • Diffuse Irradiance (DHI): Sunlight that gets redirected by the atmosphere and then hits the surface
  • Reflected: Any sunlight (direct or diffuse) that hits the ground and is then reflected onto the surface.

Global Horizontal Irradiance = DNI + DHI hitting surface laying on the ground

The basic parts of a PV-system are the PV panel and the inverter. A PV panel is a semiconductor device that converts solar energy into DC electricity and an inverter connects the PV-system to the grid. The figure shows a structure of a PV system.

PV system structure

ISED implements a PV cell temperature model which is based on the Faiman module temperature model. The PV performance model comes from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory online PV performance calculation application.

Renewable Incentives And Curtailment Priorities

Curtailment priorities and renewable incentives have to be consistent, to this end, the renewable incentives are reduced if necessary. That means, the higher the curtailment rank, the lower the renewable incentive. This way, the assets can be ordered by their (modified) incentives and curtailment ranks will automatically be respected (because the assets that should be curtailed first are also the ones whose economic incentive is smallest). The user will be warned if incentives are modified. Photovoltaic Systems and Wind Turbines are treated together here.

ImportedPV

Imported PV in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

The explanation of PV system can be found in the section of InternalPV. The imported PV system uses the PV power defined in a timeseries. To ensure that costs are operating reserve are correctly calculated, then the power timeseries should be normalized. This means that the entire timeseries is scaled (divided) by the nominal power of the PV plant. ISED uses the nominal power for necessary calculations, and multiplies the normalized time series to ensure that the correct power value is used.

At first glance, this process can seem unnecessarily complicated. The following example is given to explain the background: A 10MW PV park is located close to a proposed ISED project. A years measured data is provided by the customer, with the request to size the system including a new PV park. When the timeseries is normalized (divided by 10,000), it means that the original 10MW size of the existing PV/wind park is neutralized, and a search space of different PV park sizes (e.g. 15MW, 20MW and 25MW) can be defined in the nominal power. The CAPEX, OPEX, replacement cost and operating reserve are correctly scaled for each size in the search space.

There is one type of imported PV in the library:

  • Default PV

Explanation for PV System Model

The ImportedPV serves as an interface for external models, such as PVSyst or HelioScope. These modeling tools contain details well beyond those included within the InternalPV model. As such, these external tools are intended to be used by experts. For additional details regarding these models, please see the corresponding tool manuals.

Within ISED, the results of an external tool study is reduced to the amount of power available from the PV layout. This available power is converted into a timeseries, and is scaled, such that the final time series multiplied by the capacity of the PV layout yields the power in kW.

KPIs

  • Per PV Plant
  • Aggregated over all PV Plants

Explanation for Wind Turbine Model

The wind speed at the hub height is determined by three factors: location, hub height and roughness length of the ground.

The factor 'location' means that the wind speed varies in different locations, e.g. by moving from the coast to the interior, the wind speed decreases. Another two factors, hub height and roughness length of the ground, are used to calculate the wind speed at the hub height. Hub height is the height of the center of the wind turbine rotor above the terrain surface and it has increased over the years together with the growth of rated power output. With increasing height, the wind speed rises. Roughness length defines the roughness of the earth's surface. Onshore WTs are installed on landscapes ranging from agricultural terrain with very few buildings, trees, etc. to agricultural terrain with a closed appearance. The roughness length is estimated between 0.03m to 0.1m.

The Figure below shows the power output curve of a 2.35MW WT. The cut-in wind speed is 3m/s and the cut-out wind speed is 25m/s. A WTGS starts to produce power when the wind speed is more than 3m/s and it is shutdown when the wind speed exceeds 25m/s.

Wind Power Output Curve for a WT

If excess renewable energy is available, assets with higher curtailment priorities are curtailed first

Rated Power
The Wind Park 'Rated Power [kW]' must be defined. This ensures that grid forming, operating reserve and redundancy are correctly modelled. The power timeseries must also be 'Normed power to rated power' (Power / rated power).
Normed power to rated power output
The power timeseries must be 'Normed power to rated power' (Power / rated power). This ensures that grid forming, operating reserve and redundancy are correctly modelled. The Wind Park 'Rated Power [kW]' must also be defined. This also allows the user to rescale the Wind Park to various sizes easily.

Explanation for WT System Model

The ImportedWT serves as an interface for external models. These modeling tools contain details well beyond those included within the InternalWT model. As such, these external tools are intended to be used by experts. For additional details regarding these models, please see the corresponding tool manuals.

Within ISED, the results of an external tool study is reduced to the amount of power available from the WT layout. This available power is converted into a timeseries, and is scaled, such that the final time series multiplied by the capacity of the WT layout yields the power in kW.

Energy Storage System

ESS in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

Energy Storage System (ESS) An energy storage system is composed of a battery, a converter and optionally a container with Heating, Ventilation and Air Condition(HVAC).

ESS structure in ISED

Battery

An electric battery is a device consisting of one or more electrochemical cells with external connections provided to power electrical devices.

Two types of batteries are modeled in ISED

  • Lithium Ion Battery

Setpoint SOC
A setpoint for the state of charge. Only used in cycle charging by the dispatcher. In cycle charging this is goal SOC to be reached when charging
Charging incentive timeseries in [Euro/kWh]
This parameter determines how the batteries are used. High values allow charging the battery also from convention generation, low values prohibit charging that might damage the battery. For further information see also here.
Default charging incentive in [Euro/kWh]
When no timeseries is set for the charging incentive, this value is used. For further information see also here.
Charging incentive factor at SOC
The charging incentive for any given timestep is multiplied with this factor depending on the current state of charge. This way SOC dependent charging behavior can be realized.

Capacity

Number of racks
The total number of strings/racks per ESS
Number of modules per rack
Number of modules contained in one string/rack
Dispatch: Number of modules per rack for calibration
This should be the same as the Number of modules per rack. If these numbers are different, then the dispatcher's estimation of the costs of aging will be impacted. Ie. if this parameter is higher than the actual Number of modules per rack, then the dispatcher will reduce its estimate of the aging cost of the battery. When calibrating the models in the library, the aging is based upon Capacity (in Ah), which is dependent upon the Number of modules per rack. If this number is changed then the calibration will no longer be correct.
