Explanation for Battery Model

The battery model is shown in the figure . The model describes the behaviour of a full battery system, not of single cells or strings. However, since it is based originally on a cell model, it is possible to in the future develop it into a battery container model with explicit representations of cells, strings, and modules.

Battery model

The model described all battery states relevant for the usage in a sizing tool. Battery states are calculated by the model and the model reacts to some time-varying inputs, such as environmental temperature and electric power.

Additional to the battery model, the converter model sets the limitation of power conversion and the container model simulates performance of the heat, ventilation and air conditioner system.

Aging In Predictive Dispatchers

Several of the parameters in the Time Category specify the aging behaviour of the battery. However, many of the aging dynamics are nonlinear which means they cannot directly be incorporated within a predictive dispatcher. The user can choose to use a simplified model of aging dynamics for LithiumIon batteries in predictive dispatchers. This can be useful if a more precise battery model is necessary, however, it can increase the running time.

Explanation for Converter Model

ISED currently only considers topologies with common AC coupling. No multi bus systems are currently supported. Wind Turbines, Batteries and PV plants are thus assumed to be connected to the point of common coupling grid by inverters. The assets itself thus already contain some parameters that are influenced by their associated inverter properties such as short circuits current and grid forming ability.

The failure fraction of a converter (-group) adds to the failure fraction of the entire asset by assuming the worst case failure. E.g. if a PV Plant with a failure fraction of 0.1 is connected to the point of common coupling by an inverter-group with a failure fraction of 0.5, a failure fraction of 0.5 is assumed to the asset.

GenSet

GenSet in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

A generator set consists of one or more reciprocating internal combustion engines used to produce mechanical energy and one or more generators to convert the mechanical energy into electrical energy. The model supports ISO 8258-5, which defines the diesel generator as either PRP (Prime Rated Power) or COP (Continuous Operating Power). Typically, use cases involving ISED are better suited for COP parameterizations, with other sources providing peak power as needed. The PRP parameterization is supported by the dispatchers (in which the average permissible power is followed over a rolling 24 hour period) but the planning of these periods is not guaranteed to be optimal.

Usage Cost (Reverse) [EUR/kWh]
Usage cost for power transmission from bus 2 to bus 1 in EUR/kWh

Limits

Maximal power to be conveyed from bus 1 to bus 2
Power rating (Reverse) [kW]
Maximal power to be conveyed from bus 2 to bus 1

Consumption

Efficiency from bus 1 to bus 2 in percent
Efficiency (Reverse) [%]
Efficiency from bus 2 to bus 1 in percent

Stability (Grid, OR)

Failure fraction (Forward)
The fraction in per unit in which the converter fails, e.g. 1 means the converter is all or nothing
Failure fraction (Reverse)
The fractional loss of functionality that occurs when the converter fails, e.g. 1 means the converter is all or nothing

Time

Lifetime [y]
Lifetime, i.e. the time between replacements in years
Installation delay [y]
The time delay (in years) after simulation start at which the asset is installed. CAPEX is booked and OPEX start after this delay. A delay of 5 years means that the unit starts producing at the beginning of year 6.

Explanation for Cable Model

The Cable is a asset that can be used to unite assets that are connected over a larger distance. Because of this distance, losses due to transmitting power become significant. These losses are accounted for as a bulk efficiency loss. The cable itself provides no grid forming, but will allow other assets to provide grid forming through the cable. Thus, a load on one end of a cable may be supplied via a genset on the other end of the cable, and gridforming will be met.

Virtual Power Plant (VPP) Virtual Private Wire Network (VPWN)

The cable can be used either as a physical connection or as a virtual connection between geographically separated energy systems. This virtual connection is used in the application of Virtual Power Plant. A VPP is a distributed power plant that aggregates several types of energy sources for the purpose of enhancing power generation and supply. It offers the owners of small energy resources the possibility to either access the power market by aggregating grid management services, or share energy between different locations. For this second option a utility might require a handling fee for energy e.g. EUR/kWh, this can be modelled in the cable as network charges, see below.

In ISED, the asset cable can be used to model the VPP with network charges. As shown in the figure below, five buildings are connected virtually as one VPP. A building operator owns buildings in different locations in a city, which are each connected to local power utility grid.

VPP with Five Buildings in ISED

This kind of VPP is importing and exporting energy for different buildings using the real electric network. The network charges are calculated as shown in the figure below. There are two parts in the network charges for both export and import. If the electricity is transferred from building 1 to building 5, the network charge includes the NCE-1 and NCI-5 in the figure.

Network Charges for VPP with Five Buildings

In ISED, the network charges can be set in the Parameter table as shown in the figure below. The "Usage Cost (Forward)" is used for the export network charge and the "Usage Cost (Reverse)" is used for the import network charge. Either fixed price or time series can be set here. These network charges are included in the dispatch optimization and their economic and technical KPIs are in results view.

Network Charges for VPP with Five Buildings

Thermal Equipment

The production, storage, export and consumption of thermal energy flows are modelled in ISED. Steam (also known as High Temperature), Hot Water, and Cold Water flows are possible, and each energy flow is optimized on a bus like electricity. The actual pressure, temperature and mass flow are not modeled in ISED, and buses are used to ensure that only compatible equipment is connected. In addition to the specific buses dedicated to each energy flow, a Generic Thermal Bus is also available that can be used to connect thermal flows. However, note that no conversion occurs (eg 1kW_th Hot Water + 1kW Cold Water = 2kW General Thermal).

CHP (GasEngine)

GasEngine in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

A CHP is an internal combustion engine which runs on a gas fuel, such as coal gas, producer gas, biogas, landfill gas or natural gas. This asset can produce electrical energy, and also two forms of thermal energy. First, the exhaust heat from the operation of the GasEngine can be recovered and converted into usable heat via a heat exchanger. Second, the unit itself is often cooled via a fluid that produces usable hot water.

Rated Electrical Power [kW]

Ramp Rates

Starting ramp rate minimum [%/s]
The minimum allowed ramp rate during starting periods for gas engines in percent of rated power per second. e.g. with "Starting ramp rate minimum" of 0.1 and a minimum output limit of 30%, then the gas engine will take no more than 5 minutes (300 seconds) to reach 30% after which it will be "ON". This value must be positive.
Starting ramp rate maximum [%/s]
The maximum allowed ramp rate during starting periods for gas engines in percent of rated power per second. E.g. with "Starting ramp rate maximum" of 0.2 and a minimum output limit of 30%, then the gas engine will take no less than 2.5 minutes (150 seconds) to reach 30% after which it will be "ON". This value must be positive.
Minimum ramp rate [%/s]
The fastest rate during normal operation that a gas engine is allowed to decrease its operating set point, e.g. If a gas engine is operating at 80% and has a "Minimum ramp rate" of -0.08333 and a minimum output limit of 30%, then the gas engine will take 10 minutes (600 seconds) to its minimum output limit. This value must be negative.
Maximum ramp rate [%/s]
The fastest rate during normal operation that a gas engine is allowed to increase its operating set point, e.g. If a gas engine is operating at 80% and has a "Maximum ramp rate" of 0.16667 and a maximum output limit of 100%, then the gas engine will take 2 minutes (120 seconds) to its maximum output limit. This value must be positive.

Limits

Minimum Allowed Electrical Power [kW]
Defines the minimum power set point for a gas engine. This value is ignored if the gas engine is "Starting" and has not yet reached its minimum operating set point, or if its value is lower than the minimum row in the heat balance table (scaled relative to the rated power).
Maximum Allowed Electrical Power [kW]
A time series defining the maximum desired power set point for a gas turbine at a given point in time. This value is ignored if it is higher than the maximum value in the heat balance table (scaled relative to the rated power).

Explanation for GasEngine Model

The GasEngine currently contains 3 implemented "Operating Modes" {"Off", "Starting", and "On"}. While "Off" the GasEngine may neither produce electrical nor thermal power. "Starting" represents the initial time that the GasEngine begins to become operational - and linearly ramps its electrical and thermal powers from zero to its minimum operating point. In the "Starting" mode, the ramp rate for the power is restricted by the Starting minimum and maximum allowed ramp rates.

From its minimum operating point until its maximum, the GasEngine is "On." In this Operating Mode, the ramp rates for the power are restricted by the normal operating Minimum and Maximum allowed ramp rates.

The Minimum Operating Point is defined in the Heat Balance Table, in the first row. The Maximum operating point is defined in the Heat Balance Table, in the last row.

Gas Turbine

Gas Turbines in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

A gas turbine runs on a gas fuel, such as natural gas. This asset produces electrical energy, and also thermal energy from the exhaust heat. Typically, this thermal energy is recovered and converted into usable heat via a Heat Recovery Steam Generator (HRSG). The Gas Turbine Model includes the HRSG internally.

If a Simple Cycle Gas Turbine is configured, then this thermal power is not recovered. Typically this thermal power is then vented.

Turbine Performance and Guarantees Please note that all performance values provided are indicative only, and not for guarantee. Guarantee Performance can be provided upon request.

Scope of supply The Gas Turbine genset scope of supply for Simple Cycle application will typically include:

  • Gas Turbine including HRSG;
  • Package enclosure designed for outdoor installation including Fuel, Lube Oil, Fire and Gas protection systems;
  • Air Intake and Exhaust systems; AC Generator and associated Gearbox (where applicable);
  • Control system;
  • standard Project Management and Warranty;
  • Ex-Works.

More detailed scope of supply (and available options) is available upon request for the different GT models.

Library Assets

There are four types of library elements for the Gas Turbine

  • AeroderivativeGT
  • IndustrialGT
  • LargeFrameGT
  • Generic GT

The Aeroderivative, Industrial, and Large Frame gas turbines reflect actual offerings from the Siemens portfolio, whereas the Generic gas turbines are models which are not specialized to mimic an actual asset. The simple cycle variant produce only electricity as a useful output, whereas the other units produce thermal power using the exhaust gasses.

The inlet and exhaust ducting losses are typical for standard installation with exhaust heat recovery.

Ramp Rates

Purging
Included in the GT (both Simple Cycle and Combined Cycle) start time is a purge period, where ambient air is used to displace any residual combustible gases before starting. Purge time will vary by plant configuration, application type, and local regulatory requirements. Typical purge times can range from a few mins to 10+ minutes.
Cold start purge period [s]
For a cold start, the amount of time required for purging, syncronization, spin up, etc. from the start signal is given, until the gas turbine can begin to ramp up and produce power. See the figure directly below. A gas turbine is considered 'cold' if it has been in an "Off" mode for a period longer than the 'Hot period after stop' value.
Hot start purge period [s]
For a hot start, the amount of time required for purging, syncronization, spin up, etc. from the start signal is given, until the gas turbine can begin to ramp up and produce power. See the figure directly below. A gas turbine is considered 'hot' if it has been in an "Off" mode for a period less than the 'Hot period after stop' value.
Hot period after stop [s]
While running, a gas turbine becomes warm - but immediately begins to cool off after being shut off. This parameter defines the amount of time that a gas turbine remains 'hot'. If a gas turbine is 'hot', then starting the unit can generally be achieved faster. Within ISED this is controlled by the parameters 'Hot start purge period' and 'Cold start purge period.'
Starting ramp rate minimum [%/s]
This parameter has been removed - and is replaced by the new Purge period / syncronization parameters.
Starting ramp rate maximum [%/s]
This parameter has been removed - and is replaced by the new Purge period / syncronization parameters.
Minimum ramp rate [%/s]
The rate at which the gas turbine is allowed to decrease its operating setpoint during normal operation. E.g. If a gas turbine is operating at 80% and has a "Minimum ramp rate" of -0.08333 and a minimum output limit of 30%, then the gas turbine will take 5 minutes (300 seconds) to its minimum output limit. This value must be negative.
Maximum ramp rate [%/s]
The rate at which the gas turbine is allowed to increase its operating setpoint during normal operation. E.g. If a gas turbine is operating at 80% and has a "Maximum ramp rate" of 0.03333 and a maximum output limit of 100%, then the gas turbine will take 2 minutes (120 seconds) to its minimum output limit. This value must be positive.

Maximum Allowed Electrical Power [kW]
A time series defining the maximum desired power set point for a gas turbine at a given point in time. If this set point cannot be fulfilled, then the gas turbine will switch "Off"

Explanation for Gas Turbine Model

The Gas Turbine currently contains 3 implemented "Operating Modes" {"Off", "Starting", and "On"}. While "Off" the Gas Turbine may neither produce electrical nor thermal power. "Starting" represents the initial time that the Gas Turbine begins to become operational - and linearly ramps its electrical and thermal powers from zero to its minimum operating point. In the "Starting" mode, the ramp rate for the power is restricted by the Starting minimum and maximum allowed ramp rates.

From its minimum operating point until its maximum, the Gas Turbine is "On." In this Operating Mode, the ramp rates for the power are restricted by the normal operating Minimum and Maximum allowed ramp rates.

The Minimum Operating Point is defined in the Heat Balance Table, in the first row. The Maximum operating point is defined in the Heat Balance Table, in the last row.

While running, there exists a maximum and minimum fuel consumption rate that must be obeyed. These fuel consumptions correspond to the minimum and maximum operating point, similar to that of the GasEngine. However, there are shifts in these values, due to changes in ambient conditions (namely temperature and pressure). Typically, as Temperatures increase, the Gas Turbine releases thermal energy less efficiently, and begins to increase in temperature. Simultaneously, the density of the incoming air decreases, reducing the amount of oxygen available for combustion. As a result, the Gas Turbine should not be allowed to consume as much as fuel as at the standard testing conditions. A similar effect occurs to the minimum fuel consumption, and for ambient pressure effects.

Gas Turbine - Purge period and starting

Prior to v3.0.1, gas turbines had a starting ramp rate which was separate from the nominal operating ramp rate. In the current version, the gas turbine starting process is shown in the figure below. First, a start signal is given, after which 'purge period' occurs. In this period, the gas turbine is also syncronized and spun up, but no electrical or thermal power is produced. Then, the turbine may begin to ramp up its power production (at the nominal operating ramp rate) until the minimum power has been reached. After this point, normal operation may continue.

Purge period and starting for gas turbines

Parameters - by category

Economics

Price matrix

Figure shows the specific price from offers for typical heat pump units (without system integration) versus thermal output. The economy of scale is clearly visible.

Specific Price over Thermal Power

However, when integrating a heat pump into the plant or facility it is very difficult to estimate the integration cost in advance on a lump-sum basis. The integration cost vary significantly depending on the conditions and pre-requisites on site. An analysis of the integration cost factor for three commissioned projects are shown in figure.The range of the integration cost factor is between 2.5 and 7.5 and it is just a sample of three projects. This outlines that the integration cost can vary tremendously and are highly depending on the site and project.

Composition of heat pumps Integration cost

Capacity

Rated Capacity [kW_th]
The rated capacity is the heating power output an heat pump can provide at the reference source temperature.

Limits

Minimum source temperature
The heat pump model is valid in a certain source temperature range whereof the minimum source temperature represents the lower limit. The heat pump turns off if the source temperature falls below the lower limit even if "must run" is activated.
Maximum source temperature
The heat pump model is valid in a certain source temperature range whereof the maximum source temperature represents the upper limit. The heat pump turns off if the source temperature exceeds the upper limit even if "must run" is activated.
Bivalent Point
The bivalent point is the source temperature at which the thermal load can just about be covered by the heat pump.

Consumption

Heat Balance Table

A table defining the thermal power generated by electrical power (and thermal input). Each row defines a performance set point at different partial loads at a certain source temperature. The first column defines the amount of required input electrical power, while the second then defines the corresponding thermal output (Hot Water or Steam). The last column defines the source temperature at which the state is valid.

If the heat pump is not defined as a Standard heat pump, then there will also be a column for the provided cooling power of the unit or the required thermal input (hot water or steam). This means that as a Dual heat pump the unit must provide cooling power in order to be able to provide warming power. For Booster heat pumps a thermal input (hot water or steam) is required. The efficiency between the two thermal ports is assumed to be 98% by default. See also: Heat Balance Table under "Special Parameter Types".

As defined in the Model section, the efficiency of a heat pump changes as the cold (source) and hot (outlet) temperatures vary. The temperature-dependency of the model allows a user to describe the de-icing mode of a heat pump at cold ambient temperatures.

NOTE: For each temperature the number of part-loads states, i.e. number of rows, must be equal.

Environment

Source temperature [ ° C]
The source temperature is a condition under which the Heat Pump is operating. The model equations are depending on this value. It can be a timeseries or constant value.
Reference source (cool) temperature [ ° C]
This is the temperature for which the unit's performance is benchmarked in the Heat Balance Table. This value and the rated capacity should be a valid state in the HBT. If the rated capacity is lower/higher than defined in the HBT at this temperature, the thermal Output values are scaled accordingly.

Model

The Heat Pump model is based on a piece-wise linearization of the Heat pumps' behavior at different source temperatures for a fixed target temperature. The behavior at different source temperatures is defined in the Heat Balance Table and the number of defined states does not affect the simulation speed. It is shown that W/W Heat Pumps have a higher COP compared to A/W Heat pumps for same temperature lifts (the difference between the higher and the lower temperatures), (see below). It is also shown that the COP of Heat pumps in the range from 100 to 2000 kW_th changes insignifcantly (see Carnot effect below).

Rated capacity scaling: The rated capacity and the reference source temperature must be a defined state in the heat balance table if the scaling factor should be 1. E.g. is the rated capacity at a reference source temperature of 17.5C set to 2000 kW_th, then all output power values in the HBT are scaled by 2000/1228 = 2.629, i.e. the COP is scaled by 2.629. In order to keep the COP in the same range as in the original model, the electric input values must be scaled likewise.

Temperature lift: the difference between the heat sink temperature and the heat source temperature. The temperature lift is the most crucial parameter for the heat pump efficiency and is considered in the heat balance table.

Dependency on temperature lift: The temperature lift is the most crucial variable for the heat pump efficiency. There is a clear dependency with a usual range of scattering, see figure. The scattering comes from among others the fact that manufacturers use different kind of quality and sizes in equipment like heat exchangers, compressors, etc. In PSS-DE the temperature lift is taken into account within the heat balance table and must be specified properly by the user for a particular heat pump and its application.

COP over temperature lift for W/W and A/W heat pumps

Dependency on thermal output of heat pump: The Carnot efficiency depends on the thermal output of the heat pump when comparing over a range of several orders of magnitude (e.g. 1 kW to 100 MW), see figure. However, only a smaller range of the thermal output is typical for projects worked on within PSS-DE (e.g. 100 kW to 2 MW). Within this smaller range the increase in Carnot efficiency is insignificant and shows a very large scattering. Thus, in PSS-DE the thermal output of the heat pump can be scaled but the user needs to keep in mind that this scaling is valid only within the mentioned typical range.

Carnot efficiency over Heat Pumps rated size

Dual and Booster Heat Pumps

The heat pump model can be configured as a non-standard heat pump with an additional cold water output (Dual Heat Pump) or with a thermal input (Booster Heat Pumps). The dual heat pump simultaneously produces cold and hot thermal power while the booster heat pumps operate using a thermal warm input as its source heat which increases efficiency and hence uses less input electricity to operate. Instead of using lower temperature air/water, booster heat pumps can reutilize the waste heat of other assets in the topology. Booster heat pumps are not yet widespread, but are still more of a research topic.

In the decarbonization study the ratio between the heat pump's inputs and outputs is configured by the coefficient of performance (COP) and the efficiency that are defined as in the equations below:

Vent

Thermal Vent-Coolers in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

The Vent-Cooler is a secondary asset useful for when large thermal power assets are included in a system. Such large systems must successfully remove heat, and a Vent-Cooler enables this process. The Vent-Cooler is a large heat sink / cooling reservoir that accepts thermal power, but produces no usable side energy and exerts no work as a result. The maximum capacity of the Vent-Cooler is defined via the Rated Capacity.

  • For a Hot Water Valve - this implies from high temperature to lower temperature
  • For a Cold Water Valve - this implies from a low temperature to a higher temperature

Hydrogen Equipment

Overview

The production, storage, export and consumption of hydrogen is modelled in ISED. Contrary to the other energy types, the flow of hydrogen is shown in kg/h instead of kW. Both low and high pressure hydrogen buses are possible, and each energy flow is optimized on a bus like electricity and thermal power. Hydrogen can be transferred from low to high pressure with a compressor which has CAPEX, OPEX and losses. When transferring hydrogen from a high to low pressure bus, a reducing valve is used, which can have a CAPEX and OPEX. As with thermal energy, the actual pressure, temperature and flow are unknown, and the two buses are used to ensure that only compatible equipment is connected. The nominal pressure value for the low pressure bus is 1 bar, and for the high pressure bus it is 35 bar. For systems in which the operating pressure is different than nominal, compression losses can be considered by adjusting the efficiencies of the individual assets. In several places withing the tool, values for amounts and flows of hydrogen are displayed in kWh or kW, repectively, alongside their default kg/h or kg values. The convertion factor between these units is the lower heating value of Hydrogen: 33.336 kWh/kg.

Electrolyzer

Electrolyzer /w and w/o Hot Water output Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

An electrolyzer uses electricity to decompose water into oxygen and hydrogen gas. It is connected to an electric bus and to a hydrogen bus. Depending on the outlet pressure there is a high or low pressure bus the electrolyzer can be connected to.

Library Assets

  • Electrolyzer_LP
  • Electrolyzer_LP_HW
  • Electrolyzer_HP
  • Electrolyzer_HP_HW

Explanation for Electrolyzer assets in library

The present default values represent the linear behavior of Electrolyzer as they are given in the corresponding data sheets. The conversion between kg and kWh_LHV is performed using the lower heating value of hydrogen with a value of LHV_H2 = 33.336 kWh/kg. The Electrolyzer_LP discharges H2 at atmospheric pressure. The Electrolyzer_HP includes a compressor with the associated costs and losses. The replacement of this compressor is assumed to be included in the system costs for the Electrolyzer. The Electrolyzer w/ hot water output emits hot water as thermal by-product from hydrogen production.

Explanation for Hydrogen Compressor Model

The behavior of the hydrogen compressor is described by a linear model. The required electric power for the compression E.g. at a minimum hydrogen flow rate of 112 kg/h the compressor consumes 224 kW electric power. At a maximum hydrogen flow rate of 394 kg/h 783 kW are consumed. For example if the Electrolyzer operates at full load and is directly connected to the compressor, at the maximum outlet flow rate of 335 kg/h the electric consumption at this flow is 666 kW.

Hydrogen Storage

Hydrogen Storage Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

Hydrogen is stored at a target pressure (e.g. 50 bar, 100bar). Models ISED assume energy requirements are independent of the state of charge, i.e. constant-pressure storage. The target pressure is independent of bus pressure, as indicated in the storage name. There are two typical types of hydrogen storage: Tube and Tank. The main difference between these types are in their capacity and capital cost. Typically, Tube storage units would be used for storing smaller amounts of hydrogen.

Explanation for Hydrogen Storage Model

The hydrogen storage operates at constant pressure levels that can be 35bar, 50 bar or 100 bar. The integrated compressor compresses hydrogen gas from the pressure level at the inlet (LP: 1bar, HP: 35 bar) to the rated storage pressure level. The electric consumption while filling and emptying the storage is depending on the charging/discharging rate but is independent of the hydrogen level inside the storage tank. For example the library asset "Hydrogen Tank Storage HP_100bar" receives hydrogen gas at high pressure (35 bar) that is internally compressed to the rated storage pressure of 100 bar. The electric consumption of 139 kW at maximum charging rate is characterized by the 35 bar inlet pressure and the 100 bar pressure level to be achieved.

Hydrogen Turbine

Hydrogen Turbine Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

The hydrogen turbine is a gas turbine that is also capable of combusting a fuel mixed with hydrogen. Depending on the exact design of the turbine, it may be possible combust from 10% up to 100% hydrogen.

Parameters - by category

As the hydrogen turbine is a gas turbine, with additional features, all parameters for a gas turbine are also available to customize a hydrogen turbine. In this section, only the unique parameters will be additionally presented.

Economics
Hydrogen Incentive [EUR/kg]
This parameter describes an incentive to encourage usage of hydrogen. If positive, then the dispatcher sees an economic benefit per kg consumed. If negative, then the value acts as a disincentive. In either case, this value does not affect KPIs.

Consumption

Heat Balance Table [kW] and Hydrogen Heat Balance Table [kW]
Rather than a single table, as with the traditional gas turbine, the hydrogen gas turbine has two separate heat balance tables. In the first (Heat Balance Table [kW]) the behavior of the turbine when running purely on fuels can be defined. In this table, the user is not able to configure any values for the Hydrogen columns. In the second table (Hydrogen Heat Balance Table [kW]), the behavior of the turbine when running on a mix of Hydrogen and fuels. If the Hydrogen Heat Balance Table contains a mix of hydrogen and other fuels, then ISED will internally calculate the corresponding Heat Balance Table in which 100% hydrogen is used. Because this involves extrapolating, this can lead to strange results. When the user presses 'Save' or 'Run' this internal Heat Balance Table will be evaluated - and the user will be alerted if extrapolation is likely to yield strange results. Additionally, it is recommended that the 'Maximum hydrogen consumption [%]' parameter should be used to limit the hydrogen consumption from exceeding the provided hydrogen consumptions.

Limits

Maximum hydrogen consumption [%]
This parameter describes the maximum amount of hydrogen that may be consumed relative to "normal" fuels. This value is in percent, and relative to the total consumed fuel in kW_LHV.
Model
Calibration point [%]
The model calibration point in terms of percent of hydrogen. The model is most accurate for this fuel mix - as more or less hydrogen is consumed, then the accuracy of the model may be impacted. This parameter affects the calculated power production, as well as the estimated total fuel consumption.

Explanation for Hydrogen Turbine Model

The behavior of the Hydrogen is described by a linear model and is generally the same as the traditional turbine. There are two major differences to the traditional model.

1. The efficiency of each fuel (e.g. Natural Gas and Hydrogen) depends on the total amount of fuel being consumed. For example, if the fuel consumption from natural gas is already roughly 50% of the maximum total fuel consumption, and hydrogen is at 10% of the maximum total fuel consumption, then the total fuel consumption is 60%. This value will then define the efficiency of the gas turbine for each fuel, with some errors arising due to interpolation between the two heat balance tables. This interpolation contains the least error when at or near the "Calibration Point", which is specified as a percentage of hydrogen relative to the current fuel mix. In this example, the fuel mix would be 10%/(10%+50%) = 1/6 ~ 16.67%.

2. The hydrogen turbine may consume hydrogen in place of another fuel (e.g. natural gas) - but the total overal fuel consumption is still constrained. Assuming that maximum hydrogen consumption is 10MW_LHV, and the maximum natural gas consumption is 12MW_LHV, then for a "Calibration Point" of 30%, the combined maximum fuel consumption would be 30% * 10MW_LHV + 70% * 12MW_LHV = 11.4 MW_LHV. If the "Maximum hydrogen consumption [%]" is set to be 40%, then the maximum possible hydrogen consumption would be 40% * 11.4MW ~4.56MW_LHV. At lower part loads, this hydrogen consumption must reduce in accordance with the 40% fuel limit.

In the previous figure, Table 1 describes a potential Heat Balance Table for 100% Natural Gas. In Table 2, a potential Heat Balance Table for a mix of Hydrogen and Natural gas is presented. Table 3 presents an extrapolated Heat Balance Table for 100% Hydrogen consumption. The user never has to deal with Table 3, it is only calculated internally in ISED.

In the two right columns of the figure, two different calculations for Hydrogen mix are referenced. The H2 Mix (%LHV) is calculated using the ratio of LHV consumption from LHV divided by the total LHV consumption. In the example, Table 2 has a value of ~23%, because 24.6MW_LHV / 106MW_LHV ~ 23% (orange values in the Tables). The NG Reduction quantifies the transition away from 100% Natural Gas differently, in that it is calculated using the ratio of the Full Load NG consumption at the mix point to the amount of Natural Gas consumption at 100% Natural Gas. In the example, Table 2 has a value ~33%, because (1 - 82MW_LHV/123MW) ~ 33% (blue values in the Tables).

For each Electrical, Thermal, and Hydrogen consumption, Table 1 and Table 2 can be used to extrapolate and create the values in Table 3. To do this, the NG reduction factor is used. For example, the Full Load electrical production at 100% H2 is calculated like:

Elec_H2 = Elec_NG + (Elec_Mix - Elec_NG)/(NGReduction_Mix - NGReduction_NG)*(NGReduction_H2-NGReduction_NG)

27424 = 48416 + (41398 - 48416)/(0.33432 - 0.0) * (1.0 - 0.0)

This extrapolation is sensitive to the values 'Elec_Mix' and 'Elec_NG', and during extrapolation certain issues can occur that may lead to strange behavior. The first possibility is that the extrapolation may yield a negative value. This will result in significant problems for a realistic simulation, if high ratios of hydrogen are allowed. Additionally, it is possible that two rows will not extrapolate and preserve a reasonable ordering. For example, the 'Thermal Output' column of Table 3 contains entries that get smaller at higher part loads. At higher ratios of hydrogen, this will also cause strange behavior in simulations.

Lastly, note that the Natural Gas consumption at 100% H2 consumption (Table 3) must be 0 kW_LHV. However, since the fuel consumption at part load is not necessarily linar with NGReduction, there will be some minor discrepancy in fuel consumption calculated. This error has been found to normally be small (normally less than 3% peak fuel consumption at 100% Hydrogen) and the error decreases as the Hydrogen consumption ratio decreases. Nevertheless, this may lead to discrepancies in natural gas fuel consumption at part load.

Process Plant

Process Plants in Topology View

Overview - "What is this asset"

The process plant models a chemical or industrial process plant. The model includes the consumption of electricity and hydrogen as basic energy types, as well as a 'Consumable' which can be defined with a price (which affects KPIs), but is not shown in the topology view. The model also includes the production of a thermal output (hot water, steam or cold water) as well as a 'Product' and 'Byproduct' which can each be defined with a price, but are not shown in the topology view. The rated capacity of the unit is defined in the terms of the 'Product'.

Library Assets

  • Ammonia Plant
  • Ammonia Plant [HW]
  • Endothermic Plant

Parameters - by category

Definitions

Product Name
The name of the product that is produced by the plant (e.g. Ammonia, Urea ...).
Product Units
The units of the product that is produced by the plant (e.g. kg, m3, gal...)
Byproduct Name
The name of the Byproduct that is produced by the plant (e.g. H20, Urea ...).
Byproduct Units
The units of the Byproduct that is produced by the plant (e.g. kg, m3, gal...)
Consumable Name
The name of the consumable that is used by the plant to generate a product (e.g. Nitrogen, H20 ...).
Consumable Units
The units of the consumable that is used by the plant (e.g. kg, m3, gal...)

Economics

Price matrix

See Price Matrix under "Special Parameter Types".

Product Price [EUR/Unit]

The price at which a product (e.g. Ammonia) is sold.

Dispatch: Product Price Incentive [EUR/Unit]

The price by which the additional production of a product (e.g. Ammonia) is incentivized by the dispatcher. A negative price has the opposite effect. The incentive is only relevant for dispatch behavior and does not affect KPIs.

Byproduct Price [EUR/Unit]

The price at which a byproduct (e.g. Ammonia) is sold.

Consumable Price [EUR/Unit]

The price at which a consumable (e.g. Nitrogen) is purchased.

Capacity

Rated Production Capacity [Product Unit]
The rated capacity of the plant for the product and associated unit.

Limits

Minimum load [kW]
Minimum desired electrical input for the asset at each point in time. If the asset cannot operate over this condition, it will turn off
Maximum load [kW]
Maximum desired electrical input for the asset at each point in time. If the asset cannot operate under this condition, it will turn off.

See under "Special Parameter Types".
Maximum annual full load hours [h]
See under "Special Parameter Types".
Full load scaling factor [%]
See under "Special Parameter Types".

Losses

Operational losses [kW]
Electric losses incurred during operation. The value is absolute and not scaled with the asset size.
Permanent losses [kW]
Electric permanent losses. The value is absolute and not scaled with the asset size.

Emissions

Carbon content [g/kWh]
The amount of carbon dioxide produced for the generation and transport of energy to the project location. Note that if this value is negative, then the process will absorb Carbon Dioxide from the environment. This carbon capture is not limited by production elsewhere in the system, but will offset carbon taxes, possibly leading to a negative total carbon tax.

Time

Lifetime [h]
The number of operating hours before the asset is replaced
Capacity factor (Degradation) [%]
Indicates how the capacity of the asset degrades with time. If this parameter takes values below 100%, the maximum amount of electricity that can be used by this asset decreases.
Product Efficiency Factor (Degradation) [%]
Indicates how the product efficiency of the asset degrades with time. If this parameter takes values below 100%, the amount of product and byproduct at a given amount of hydrogen and electricity will decrease (this parameter does not affect thermal output or Consumable consumption.)
Installation delay [y]
The time delay (in years) after simulation start at which the asset is installed. o indicates at the beginning of simulation, 1 would be the beginning of the second year.
Outages schedule
See Outages schedule under "Special Parameter Types".
Replacement Strategy
See "Replacement Strategy" under "Special Parameter Types".

Consumption

Heat Balance Table [kW]
A table defining the thermal power and the amount of product (e.g. Ammonia) and byproduct (e.g. H20) generated by consuming hydrogen, electricity and a consumable (e.g. Nitrogen). The first row defines the minimum operating conditions for the Process Plant. The last row defines the maximum operating conditions for the Process Plant. If the Ammonia production in the last row is different from the Rated Production Capacity, then the entire table is scaled until they are equal.

Ramp Rates

Positive ramp rate [%/s]
The maximum rate at which the set point of the asset can be increased as a percentage of the rated capacity per second.
Negative ramp rate [%/s]
The maximum rate at which the set point of the asset can be decreased as a percentage of the rated capacity per second.

Bus

A Bus is not a "Asset" in the sense that a Gas Turbine or a Battery is a Asset. A Bus is a junction point over which power can be exchanged between assets.

Currently, the following Bus types are available to the user:

Buses in ISED

Multiple assets can connect to a Bus. Indeed, if only a single asset is connected, then this asset cannot "do" anything at this Bus. It cannot send power, because no asset could receive the power, nor could it receive power, because no asset could send it. This illustrates the key idea behind the Bus, the power flow must balance at a bus.

Topology Tab

Topology tab

Tool Bar

The buttons and check boxes at the top of the topology tab have the following functionalities:

Show frame lines Toggle visibility of grid lines.

Show names Display asset names above each asset icon and buses. By double-clicking on these labels, you can also change the corresponding item's name.

Show descriptions Show more detailed asset descriptions next to each icon. This will take up more space such that you will have to arrange the symbols accordingly to be able to see everything here without overlapping texts.

Load background image Load any image and place it on the layout view's background.

Remove background image Remove the background image, if any.

Background opacity To minimize distractions arising from the background image, you can adjust the image opacity with this slider.

Scale Background The background image will be fixed in position, but can be scaled using this slider.

Fit in view Clicking this button will result in fitting the bounding box of all visible assets (this includes texts and descriptions, if shown) into the layout view. This is useful after having zoomed in into a certain part of the topology, for example, and to quickly get back to an overview of the complete setup.

Asset Library

Assets from library can be directly added into topology window by drag-and-drop. The content of asset library here is the same like library in the Equipment Tab.

Topology Window

In the topology window, you can see an actual view of the project's topology, see the figure showing an empty project. The topology view also allows to show, edit, and add buses and connect assets to them. You can zoom in and out via the mouse wheel.

A new bus can be added to the project by right-clicking on an empty cell in the topology view. This will open a context menu as shown in the figure . When clicking on the menu item Add bus, a new bus will appear in that cell. Likewise, a bus can be removed from the project by right-clicking on it and selecting delete.

Add a bus by right-clicking on an empty cell

Assets can be added from the asset library simply by drag-and- drop, as indicated in the figure . Note that assets can only be dropped into cells that are not already occupied by another asset or bus. When a new asset is dropped onto the canvas, it will automatically be connected to a matching bus (in the figure ).

Add assets from the library via drag-and-drop
Newly added assets are automatically connected to a matching bus

As soon as there are assets that have ports of multiple types (like, for example, electrical and thermal), missing buses and connections to them will be automatically generated. Bus types can also be changed manually if there are assets with matching ports. You can change a bus's type by right-clicking on it and selecting an option from the appearing context menu; see the figure for an example.

Change a bus type via its context menu

Assets can also be disconnected from a bus. This is simply done by right-clicking on a asset's port that is currently connected to a bus, and selecting the appearing option to disconnect from the bus. Similarly, you can right-click on an open port to see a list of all available, matching buses this port may be connected to. By selecting the desired port, the connection will be created.

Re-arranging the layout is possible by simply dragging the assets around. They will always snap to the closest grid cell, and placing more than one asset in one cell is not possible.

To quickly see asset parameters, it is possible to select it by double clicking on it which will mark the asset's cell in blue. When switching to the equipment tab, that asset's parameters will be shown. Double-clicking on an empty cell de-selects the asset again. This also works the other way around: When a asset is selected in the asset tree view on the equipment tab, the corresponding asset's symbol is highlighted in blue on the topology tab for quick and convenient navigation.

Some assets are available with different in- and output configurations. In the topology view an asset can be converted to every of its variant that exists in the library by right-click on the asset icon. E.g. a Standard Heat Pump can be converted to a Booster Heat Pump or a Dual Heat Pump and vice-versa.

Simulation and Dispatcher Tab

Simulation and Dispatcher Tab

Simulation Parameters

Simulation only first year (extrapolate) If this option is selected, only first year is simulated and the simulation time is reduced. KPIs are extrapolated to the full project lifetime.

Simulate all (entire project lifetime) A full simulation is carried out for all years for the project.

Logging

Log directory The directory to which all output is written. If the directory of the project file is selected or no directory is selected, each run will generate a new output-folder showing time, date and project name.

Log dispatcher results If selected, time step information from the dispatcher is logged in addition to the KPIs. This may be useful when trying to understand dispatch behavior.

Log asset results If selected, time step information from all assets are logged. This might be useful when trying to understand individual asset behavior.

Fault Finding

Ignore blackouts If selected, the system continues as if blackouts do not occur.

Blackouts occur if the sum of the requested load and the required operating reserve is bigger than the maximum available generation. If that is the case, in Normal Operation the generation and loads are set to 0kW. If blackouts are ignored, the missing operating reserve and power is provided "for free" and the maximum available generation is utilized.

Ignore operating reserve If selected and operating reserve is missing, the system simulation continues as if the missing operating reserve is provided for free. As a consequence, complexities of operating reserve and renewables and loads are not considered.

This has effects only in the electrical bus.

Ignore grid forming If selected, boundary conditions for grid forming are ignored. This has effects only in the electrical bus, specifically relevant for renewables.

Log detailed slack variables Controls whether the 'slack' variables are shown in the log. This feature is only possible for the Robust Single-Step and Multi-Step dispatchers.

Slack variables are used to help understand the cause of blackouts in a system. They capture the amount of power 'Missing' or in 'Excess' on a particular bus. For example, if an electric load requests 10 MW of power, but a generator can only deliver 8 MW, then there will be 'Missing' power of 2 MW. Alternatively, if the electric load requests 2 MW of power, but the generator's minimum power is 4 MW, then there would be 'Excess' power of 2 MW. These values are given per bus, and some detailed information can also be plotted for some components.

Dispatcher Parameters

Common Parameters

The following parameters are independent of the selected dispatcher.

Time Step Size

Time step size is the time resolution at which the simulation is performed.

Required Grid Forming

If "Require grid forming" is selected, it requires the sum of rated power of all active power sources multiplied by their grid forming factor to be greater than the currently served load.

The underlying reason for this constraint is that a phase estimation error by a PV inverter causes feed-in of excess reactive power into the power grid. On account of an increasing photovoltaic power supply, this effect is amplified. In order to compensate the excess reactive power, the diesel generator varies the voltage. This in turn leads to an excitation of the phase estimation error. Thus, both voltage and frequency fluctuations arise, which can lead to an unacceptable power quality. Siemens AG carried out a study to determine a maximum ratio between photovoltaic and diesel generator to which the system continues operating stably. This ratio is defined as grid forming factor.

Allow Blackouts

If this option is selected a blackout will not be reported as an error, but only as a warning.

Generation Redundancy

Generation redundancy determines how many unforeseen failures the system shall handle without interruption, i.e. for a generation redundancy of 1 in each time step the single largest contributor to grid forming, operation reserve and short circuit current is identified independently and enough reserve is dispatched in order to handle the failure of any one of those. The effect of this constraint on dispatching is heavily influenced by the internal failure model of each asset. The failure model is parametrized by the failure fraction of each asset. It represents to which degree a asset fails in case of a failure. For example a wind parks might have a failure fraction of

  • 1, if it is connected by a single land line that might fail. So the entire wind park might go off-line in one strike.
  • , if the worst case scenario foresees only single turbine failures.

The following common parameters can be shown by clicking the "Advanced parameters" button.

Bridging Duration

If a battery contributes to the operation reserve, it must be ensured that the committed operation reserve is available for a sufficient amount of time. Otherwise the battery might run out of energy while bridging a generator startup. The bridging duration should be chosen in a way that it is longer than the diesel startup time (off to full load) and significantly lower than the maximal energy content of the battery divided by the maximum discharge power.

Filter Averaging Time Period

To avoid unnecessary generator starts and stops the required operation reserve is smoothed, i.e. the operation reserve that is required at some time step t 0 is a weighted average over past required operation reserves. The filter averaging time period is a measure of the influence of past values on the current requirement. For example for a value of 900 the past 15 min (900 seconds) of operation reserve are relevant.

Operation Reserve Margin

Defines a small dead band, in which changes in operation reserve will not trigger generator stops. This is also used to "calm" generator behavior.

Output Additional Information for These Time Steps

Here a list of numbers (time step ids) may be entered. The numbers must be separated by spaces. For this list extra information is provided in the log folder on why a given dispatcher decision was made.

Operating Reserve Correlations

Large differences between generation and consumption in a power system can lead to blackouts. The provision of a sufficient operating reserve (OR) can prevent this issue. This reserve is called required OR and consists of two events:

  • Consumption fluctuations
  • Production fluctuations of renewables

In contrast to that, there is the available OR. It is a kind of 'fast reserve' that can be provided by generation units within the primary control. The resulting technical boundary condition for the operation of a DES system is that the available OR must be at least equal to the required OR: Available operating reserve e Required operating reserve

Required operating reserve

  • Operating reserve as fraction of peak load Is the amount of operation reserve that scales with the annual peak load, i.e. if annual multipliers are used on the primary load, the resulting operation reserve will stay constant within a year and change from year to year.
  • Operating reserve as fraction of actual load Is the amount of operation reserve that scales with the current primary load in a specific time step.
  • Operation reserve as fraction of solar power Is the amount of operation reserve that scales with the used solar power within a specific time step.
  • Operating reserve as fraction of wind power Is the amount of operation reserve that scales with the used wind power within a specific time step.

The Operating Reserve Correlations cover the relationships between different types of asset groups. In general, spikes or sudden drop-offs can occur in assets expected to supply power, or loads may suddenly require additional power with little notice. The correlations between these events dictate how much net operating reserve should be provided in order to account for the likelihood of these events occurring simultaneously. In general, a lower correlation factor will result in less required operation reserve. In the most conservative case - a correlation factor would have a value of "1.0" indicating that a single event is likely to occur at the same time as other events. Within a single technology group, PV for example, this is proper, as Photovoltaic installations tend to be located closely together. Then, when a cloud passes over a single installation, it is likely to also be near other installations. Mathematically, the total required operating reserve is defined by the risk aversion of the user and the statistical likelihood of the co-occurrence of these events. This can be decomposed into the operating reserve required from the load (relative and peak) and other producing assets (PV or WT). The total variance of a random variable can be calculated as the sum of the covariances over the two (or more variables), with the covariances then defined as the product of the individual variances, multiplied by a correlation term. If this correlation term is 1, then the two variables are perfectly correlated. If the correlation term is 0, then the two variables are not correlated at all. For more details, please consult:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_and_dependence

Economic Inputs for Dispatcher

Operation and Maintenance

There are two types of methods for the O&M calculation in the dispatch:

Method 1:
Timestep COST [EUR] = OPEX [EUR/RS] * Reference Size [? e.g. kW] * timestep [hr]
Method 2:
Timestep COST [EUR] = OPEX [EUR/RS/year] * Reference Size [? e.g. kW] / 8760 [hr/year] * timestep [hr]

Each asset in ISED is using one of these two methods as following.

Method 1:
Absorption Chiller, Compression Chiller, Cold Water Storage, Conventional Hydro, District Cooling, District Heating, Gas Boiler, Genset, Heat Pump, Hot Temperature Storage, Hot Water Boiler, Heat Storage, Hot Water Storage, Gas Engine, Steam Turbine, Steam Boiler, Vent, Pumped hydro, Hydrogen Fuel Cell, Hydrogen Electrolyzer, Hydrogen Compressor, Hydrogen Network, Hydrogen Storage, Hydrogen Turbine, Hydrogen Valve, Thermal Valve
Method 2:
Cable, Converter, Electric Load Bank, Energy Storage System, Fixed Costs, Electric Grid, HVAC, Photovoltaic, Wind Turbine

Replacement Costs

Timestep COST [EUR] = Replacement Price [EUR] / lifetime [hr] * timestep [hr]

Each replacement cost has an annual multiplier for the replacement cost.

Fuel

The fuel costs as defined by the user are used by the disptacher at each time step. This can be a constant value, or the user can define a timeseries. Changes each year can also be defined with the annual multiplier.

Energy Import and Export Costs

The cost of importing energy, as well as the revenue from exporting energy as by the user are used by the disptacher at each time step. This can be a constant value, or the user can define a timeseries. Changes each year can also be defined with the annual multiplier.

Demand Charges

The demand charges are also included in the dispatch decision. More details can be found in the section for Demand Charges.

All Incentives

Incentives are used to economically promote behavior that might otherwise not take place. Within ISED it is important to differentiate between external and internal incentives.
  1. External incentives are typically monetary, and are provided by government or utilities to promote things like renewable energy. Money is paid the government or utility if the prescribed behavior is met e.g. a renewable incentive might mean that extra money is paid to the IPP for energy that is proven to be produced by PV or wind. The benefit of these incentives are shown in the KPIs and contribute to the business case.
  2. Internal incentives are used within ISED to encourage specific behavior from a dispatcher. In many cases these are needed because a dispatch algorithm does not have enough information to make a reasonable decision. This means:
    • The single step optimizers (Robust Single-Step and Fast Single-Step) can only use the information available at each timestep, meaning that they have no sense of time. Ensuring sensible charging or discharging ESS, or starting and stopping reciprocating engines or turbines requires additional input on a project basis.
    • The Multi-Step uses a predictive window to create an optimal generation plan. Any events that occur outside of this window also requires additional input on a project basis. In particular this affects long-term effects like H2 storage.
    • The MGC is a heuristic (rule based) dispatch and therefore doesn't use incentives.
    • Internal incentives are intended for the dispatcher only, and are not included in the KPIs. They have no direct affect on the business case apart from affecting the behavior of dispatch.
The following table gives an overview of the costs and incentives in ISED. Unless stated these incentives are used for Multi-Step, Robust Single-Step and Fast Single-Step.

Curtailment Priorities

The user can set a curtailment priority for each wind and PV asset. PV assets with a higher curtailment priority will be curtailed first, lower numbers last. If PV or wind assets have the same priority then an economic dispatch decision is made (cheapest unit runs).

Charging Incentives

A charging incentive can be used to influence when a storage is charged or discharged. This parameter overcomes the limitation that dispatchers are presented with short periods of information (e.g. the dispatching horizon for the Multi-Step, the actual timestep for Robust Single-Step and Fast Single-Step). The charging incentive provides a bias to the dispatcher for each kWh that is charged. Therefore, if there is energy available at a price cheaper than the charging incentive (minus the cost of the using the storage such as losses, replacement, O&M), the storage will be filled. To stop unwanted discharging the same bias (in a negative sense) is applied by the dispatcher when discharging.

The consequence is that storage is only charged if the cost for doing so is lower than the charging incentive. Note that the cost of energy can include many factors including fuel costs, starting costs, renewable incentives etc. By the same token the storage is only discharged if all other sources of energy are more costly than the charging incentive.

A wrongly configured charging incentive leads to extreme behavior.

  • "always full": the storage charges until full and never discharged. The charging incentive is probably too high.
  • "always empty": the storage discharged and never charges. The charging incentive is probably too low.

This is a common phenomenon as the correct choice in charging incentive depends on the absolute and relative variations in energy cost over the project lifetime.

Note that the charging incentive for the Li-Ion battery is not considered by the Multi-Step. This is because the storage capacity for Li-ion batteries is typically much shorter than dispatching horizon and a charging incentive leads to unexpected results.

Dispatcher Variations

Users can choose different algorithms for power dispatch optimization. Decisions of the dispatcher are motivated by reaching the minimum of the minimization problem's objective function:

Costc,t = Cost of component c at time t

  • Fuel costs
  • Switch on/off costs
  • Time variable O&M costs
  • Starting costs (GTs only)
  • Aging & replacement costs
  • Load shedding penalties
  • Grid tariffs: demand charges, time of use tariffs, energy contracts, intensive/atypical usage
  • Carbon taxes

Revenuec,t = Revenue of component c at time t

  • Grid tariffs: exports, balancing services
  • EV Station tariff sales
  • Renewable incentives
  • Sellable products and byproducts

Internal dispatch incentivesc,t = Incentives of component c at time t

  • Charging incentives for storages
  • External energy network import and export incentives
  • Energy storage throughput costs (Multi-Step only for Electrical ESS)
  • Symmetry breaking

Note that CAPEX is not included, as the dispatcher is not able to.

Robust Single-Step

Overview

The Robust Single-Step dispatcher solves a Mixed Integer Linear Program( MILP) in order to find the cost-optimal solution for each of the set-points in a single time step. The underlying MILP solver ensures that a global optimum is found, but long-term events such as night/day, daily weather or load forecasts are not considered. To ensure that these events are considered, heuristic mechanisms have been developed to ensure consistent behavior with the multi-step optimizer of actual automation system. The following parameters are used to configure these heuristics. The key features of the Robust Single-Step optimizer are:

  • Model based development with AMPL
  • State of the art Robust Single-Step solver: SCIP
  • Guaranteed optimal solution within a time step
  • Easily modified and extended (variables, constraints, and costs)
  • Roughly 10 ms per time step (depending on number and complexity of assets and topology)

In certain cases the Robust Single-Step dispatcher does not just solve a single MILP problem, but several problems. Namely, in case the original problem is not feasible (i.e. the restrictions are so tight that no set points can satisfy all of them), the problem is slightly relaxed and then resolved. For example, if redundancy is required this redundancy will be relaxed. Or if balancing services are active, these will be disregarded. Corresponding warnings can be found in the messages page.

Specific Parameters

There are no specific parameters.

Restrictions

For a 1 minute resolution over one year this requires approximately 90 minutes for 1 configuration (60*24*365 * 0.01 / 60), for simulations with annually changing values (load, fuel or battery prices) this will scale linearly for every year that needs to be simulated.

Important Info

Fast Single-Step

Overview

The Fast Single-Step dispatch strategies are heuristic versions of the MILP strategy. They also try to minimize the cost of a single time step under the same constraints as formulated in the MILP. However, in order to decide which states (on/starting/off) or operation modes the assets should use, a local search heuristic is used which just modifies the state one by one until feasible states are found. Among the feasible states the one with the minimum cost set points is selected. In contrast to the MILP this search might not be exhaustive. To account long-term effects the same techniques as with the MILP strategy are used.

The key features of the Fast Single-Step optimizers are:

  • Fast, but contain approximations
  • Simulation of long time periods
  • Simulation of many variants
  • 0.5 ms per time step

For a 5 minute resolution over one year this requires approximately less than 1 minute for each configuration (12*24*365 * 0.0005 / 60). This means that the Fast Single-Step algorithm is well suited for simulating standard projects, exploring large search spaces or making quick evaluations for customers.

Specific Parameters

There are no specific parameters for these dispatchers.

Restrictions

Fast Single-Step can only cope with convex cost functions. This means, that, e.g. diesel generators which have non-convex fuel consumptions or electric grid connections with non-convex costs will be considered with approximate convexified modifications of these functions. Fast Single-Step cannot cope with balancing services or special tariffs. For these services, Multi-Step or Robust Single-Step are more suitable.

Important Info

The local search for coping with discrete state decisions in Fast Single-Step can lead to increased computation times, when a large number of assets with many states (on/starting/off) are present in a configuration. This can even lead to cases, where these heuristics are slower than the Robust Single-Step dispatcher.

For example, we consider the case of 10 identical diesel generators modeled as individual assets. If 5 of them are running and 5 are off, Fast Single-Step would consider switching a running one off and another one on. This alone, leads to 25 possible successor configurations, which have to be investigated further, thus blowing up the calculation time.

Another example is a situation with, say, 10 gas turbines, having 3 states each (Off, Starting, On). In this situation Fast Single-Step will investigate each possible successor state combination, which amounts to 3 10 H 60000 possibilities. It is ongoing research, to improve the heuristics in order to avoid these combinatorial explosions.

Multi-Step

Overview

The Multi-Step is a tool for operative power dispatching in Microgrids. It uses a model predictive control approach with rolling prediction horizon of 24 hours. Time discretization will be adaptable by the user. Originally, Multi-Step uses an equidistant time grid of 15 minutes. The first time steps of each dispatching optimization run will be implemented by the underlying simulation in ISED. After a fixed time interval (user's choice) the MILP dispatching is re-triggered. Originally Multi-Step re-triggers optimization after each 15 minute time step.

Model predictive control

Multi-Step input parameters

Dispatcher Specific Parameters

When choosing Multi-Step as dispatcher the following default parameters are set:

  • Simulation time step: 3600s
  • Prediction time steps:
    • 08:00 01:00, i.e. choose 1 hour time steps between 00:00 and 08:00 in every single optimization run
    • 16:00 02:00, i.e. choose 2 hours time steps between 08:00 and 16:00 in every single optimization run
    • 24:00 04:00, i.e. choose 4 hours time steps between 16:00 and 24:00 in every single optimization run
  • Dispatching horizon in h: 24:00
  • Retrigger interval in h: 04:00, i.e. restart optimization after four simulation time steps (implement the first four time steps from the result of a single optimization call)
  • Discounting factor: 0.99, i.e. the costs in the MILP model are (artificially) decreased linearly over the dispatching horizon to 99% of the actual value (this is for breaking symmetries in the MILP model)

Restrictions

Multi-Step supports all dispatcher features currently available in ISED.

Important Info

The variable time step length concept can be used to speed up the computational time for solving the dispatch problems. Since in ISED long term simulations over several years are performed, this is crucial. There are several time step length options already available or they can be configured manually.

MGC

Overview

The SICAM Microgrid Controller is a rule based tool for controlling small to medium scale hybrid power grids (electrical and thermal) that can operate independently or in conjunction with main grid connections. It is a rule-based single-step dispatcher that is called in every time step of the simulation in ISED and decides how to share loads based on the current system state and power limit constraints coming from the simulation.

User Interface

Because the MGC dispatcher uses a priority based system for dispatching, the user needs to first specify the priority of the assets and buses which should be dispatched.

MGC: Bus Priority

MGC: Component Priority

As shown in the pictures above, the user can set the priority of buses and assets by clicking in the correct column, and then selecting either the up or down arrow as relevant. If the bus or asset already has the highest/lowest priority, then the up/down button is deactivated, respectively.

If a bus has a higher priority - then it will be dispatched first, according to the process described in the sections below. If a asset has a higher priority, then it will be dispatched before other assets on the same bus.

The MGC uses predefined rule sets and prioritization of buses as well as power generation resources on each bus for economic power dispatching with respect to system reserve constraints. Based on prioritization of buses, the MGC decides about starting/stopping generation sources in order to balance the power production and the load on each bus. This process can be supported by storages and external grid connections (if available). After starting/stopping conventional generation sources and setting power setpoints for renewables, conventional generation sources and grid connections, the MGC checks if power setpoints have to be shifted (storage charging or discharging) in order to meet the load requirements.

In the last step potential power shifting for the following economic purposes is evaluated:

  • Demand charges
    • The 'MGC' tries to reduce demand charges by using ESS to shave import from grid to peak target with as much power as possible (parameterized via target peak power in demand charge UI of grid connection). Note that gensets and CHPs are not considered for demand charge reduction.
  • Tariff handling
    • The 'MGC' tries to discharge storage with (additional) target discharge setpoint (based on target discharge period parameter) if import & export prices are above high price threshold.
    • If storages are not used for peak shaving, the 'MGC' tries to charge them with (additional) target charge setpoint (based on target discharge period parameter) if import price are below low price threshold.
  • Use excess power of renewables
    • If there is any excess of power from renewable resources on the electric bus, the 'MGC' tries to use it for
      • Exporting power to the grid
      • Charging storages
      • Exporting to other buses
    • If RE Self Consumption is not active exporting has priority, else charging.
  • Target power storage discharging
    • For every storage: If
      • Preferred Rest-State SoC: Empty is true AND
      • The storage is not charging AND
      • No renewables are curtailed (which is typically the case when storages are full and enough renewables are there to cover the load)

      Then the 'MGC' tries to discharge storages with (additional) economic discharge setpoint (based on economic discharge time parameter) to reduce the power setpoint of generators or power import from the grid.

If no feasible power dispatching can be found, an iterative process of re-evaluation after shedding loads (with respect to priority ranking) and reducing redundancy requirements is started.
