Specific Parameters

When choosing MGC as dispatcher the following parameters have to be set:

  • Power Generation Units (per Bus)
    • Priority list: Priority ranking for conventional generation sources and grid connections. By default these generation sources are ranked with respect to operational costs. The user can change the priority ranking by drag-and-drop.
    • Storage Charge Threshold [EUR/kWh]:
      • If grid import price ≤ low threshold: try to charge storage (increase import setpoint)
      • If grid export price ≤ low threshold: try to charge storage (decrease export setpoint)
    • Storage Discharge Threshold [EUR/kWh]:
      • If grid import price ≥ high threshold: try to discharge storage (decrease import setpoint)
      • If grid export price ≥ high threshold: try to discharge storage (increase export setpoint)
  • Storages
    • Priority list: Priority ranking for Storages. The user can change the priority ranking by drag-and-drop.
    • Target discharge period [h]: Time frame, in which a storage should be completely discharging from 100% SOC (measure for how aggressive a storage should be used)
    • Target discharge power, determined from target discharge period as 'target power = capacity / target discharge period' is also used for demand charge reduction & tariff handling
    • Preferred rest-state SoC: Empty [true/false]: Switches the preferred rest-state of the storage from 'Empty' to 'Full'.
      • If this is 'True' (rest-state = 'Empty'), then the storage will remain empty until there is a reason to charge it.
      • If this is 'False' (rest-state = 'Full'), then the storage will remain charged until there is a reason to discharge it.
      • The following uses cases show how this parameter can be set:
        • Fuel offsetting/Diesel genset bridging : The storage should normally be empty (discharged) so that when excess energy is available the storage can charge.
        • Renewable energy shift: The storage should normally be empty (discharged) so that when excess energy is available it is able to charge.
        • Resilience/blackout avoidance: The storage should normally be full (charged) so that when there is a grid failure the storage can provide energy to the load
        • Demand charges/peak shaving: The storage should normally be full (charged) so that when there is a benefit to limit the power that the grid is providing the storage can provide energy to the load
        • Time dependent energy tariffs: The storage should normally be full (charged) so that when the import energy is expensive the storage can provide energy to the load
  • Maximum Renewable Penetration [%]: Upper bound for power production of renewables (as percentage of current load) - only available in 'Islanded' mode
  • RE Self Consumption: If 'RE self-consumption' is selected, then renewable energy that is excess to the load will be used to charge the storage. If the storage is fully charged, then additional excess renewable energy will be exported to the grid. The storage will be discharged once the renewable energy no longer supplies all the load.
  • Explain time steps: Choose time steps for which additional information for the 'MGC' dispatching shall be written to files.

Seasonal Changes

It is sometimes desired to have changing dispatch priority orders throughout the year. For example, in the summer, it may be desired to prioritize the electrical bus and cooling assets, whereas in winter, a customer may want to prioritize the hot water assets.

In the MGC dispatcher, this can be done through the definition of 'Seasons' and 'Periods' as shown in the picture below.

Defining Seasons and Periods in MGC Dispatcher
  1. Seasons can be added or removed by clicking the '+' or '-' buttons. If the '+' button is clicked, the currently selected season will be copied. If the '-' is clicked, the currently selected season will be deleted.
  2. The available seasons are shown as tabs. To rename a season, double click on the name of the tab.
  3. Each season can have its own priority ranking for buses and components.
  4. If more than one season is defined, then it is possible to define this season for a given time period. To select a season for a given period, select the name of the season in the dropdown box.
  5. The first season always begins at the begining of January 1st.
  6. More periods can be added by clicking this '+' button. A period can be deleted by clicking the '-' button.
  7. The end point of one period is also the starting point of another period. It is possible to select any date for a change in periods, but they must be chronologically increasing. It is also possible to define a change in periods at at a time other than midnight, e.g. 7:00 AM.
  8. The last season always ends at the end of December 31st.

In case all Seasons are not utilized, the user will recieve a warning to consider if this intentional.

Restrictions

Before starting a ISED simulation with MGC dispatching, several consistency checks will be performed. ISED assets of the following type are not supported:

  • Deferrable loads
  • Deferrable thermal loads
  • Dual fuel generators
  • Hydrogen, steam & hydro-electric assets and buses
  • Balancing Services, Balancing Energy contract, UK Triads, DE Atypische Netznutzung, DE Intensive Netznutzung
  • Multiple electric buses in topology

Local Control

Overview

The Local Control dispatching strategy is supposed to imitate plant operation, if there is no common dispatcher or controller, but only local control routines for every single asset in the microgrid. All renewable sources (PV/WT) can be connected to at most one battery. Multiple renewables, which are connected to one battery, are a group.

Local Control starts dispatching by trying to set the power produced by each group of renewables and battery to the desired power output limit (user input). The remaining difference between load and delivered power is then distributed to conventional generation units and the grid, with respect to load supply priority (user input). For the conventional generation units operating reserves (static per running unit and dynamic as fraction of power setpoint) and possible bridging of unit starts with the grid are taken into account. If the conventional generation units are CHPs, the electric power limits resulting from bounded thermal power output are respected, too.

Local Control is a rule-based single-step dispatcher that is called in every time step of the simulation in ISED and decides how to share loads based on the current system state and power limit constraints coming from the simulation. If no feasible power dispatching can be found, an iterative process of reevaluation after shedding loads (with respect to priority ranking) and reducing redundancy requirements is started.

Local Control dispatch strategy

Parameters

When choosing Local Control as dispatcher the following parameters have to be set:

  • Priority list for Conventional Generation Sources and Grid Connections
  • Start Up Delay for Conventional Generation Sources: Percentage of unit peak power that should be bridged with power from Grid Connections (if available) before starting a new CG
  • Operating Reserve for Conventional Generation Sources
  • Peak Operating Reserve: Percentage of unit peak power that should be available as reserve (constant)
  • Relative Operating Reserve: Percentage of current power production that should be available as reserve (dynamic)
  • Preferred Generation Source: Conventional Preferred true/false(static prioritization of generation sources)
  • Output power limit (%): Power limit for wind or PV asset. The limit is a percent of the AC power. The parameter is specific to local control as it must set to a conservative value to provide stability at all times. Systems with supervisory control can update this for higher loads so that more renewable energy is utilized.

Restrictions

Before starting a ISED simulation with Local Control dispatching, several consistency checks will be performed. ISED assets of the following type are not supported:

  • Deferrable loads
  • Deferrable thermal loads
  • Dual fuel generators
  • Thermal assets (GasEngine, gas turbine, steam turbine, gas boiler, thermal vent, absorption chiller, thermal storage, heat pump)
  • Multiple electric buses in topology

Important Info

Note that because Local Control does not use a supervisory algorithm, operating flexibility must be provided by generation units rather than intelligent control. For Local Control it can be expected that:

  • Conventional generators such as diesel gensets are stopped and started more regularly
  • If energy storage is used, it is used to firm the output of a group of renewable generators (i.e. PV or WT). It does not operate to help the operation of the entire generation system.
  • The system is more sensitive to higher levels of renewable penetration. This is because the conventional generations are forced to operate with a small amount of units that generate around their minimum load, which can often lead to infeasible conditions leading to black out.

If simulation with Local Control leads to many black outs, this can be improved by the following measures:

  • Use conventional generators (i.e. diesel gensets) with a minimum load significantly below 50%. This provides an overlap for operating small numbers of conventional generators (e.g. transitioning between 1 to 2 operating gensets).
  • Increase the number of allowed stops per day for conventional generators. In some instances Local Control leads to more starting and stopping of conventional generators.
  • Shorten the minimum time on, as Local Control can lead to many gensets starting and stopping within a short period of time. An over-lap of several minimum time on constraints from several gensets can cause an over-supply of power, which will cause a black out.

Configuration Selection Dialog

The configuration selection allows to deselected specific configurations from the search spaces that do not need to be simulated. If for example the size of a GasEngine was varied and the size of the connected Absorption Chiller was varied, it might make sense only to simulate the large GasEngine with the large Chiller plant.

Sort and filter in the selection table

  • By clicking the header of a column the selected column can be sorted ascending/descending.
  • The blue row of the table can be used to filter for values. To filter for values double click on the blue column where you would like to apply a filter. Type in the filter and hit "Enter"/"Return". Each filter is only applied on its column. A filter can be used for each column expect the first one (Selected). When multiple filters are used only the rows that fulfill each filter are shown. For numbers the filter accepts numbers. Using "456" in the third column will return the first row. Using "1,000" or "1000" will return the second row. Using "10" will return nothing. When filtering for text each row that contains the substring will be returned. If the row X has the value "Cost function" and the row Y has the value "Consumption" and the filter with the value "cost" is applied, only the row X will be shown.
Configuration Selection Tab

To filter for multiple strings or numbers in one column use " " (whitespace) or ";" (semicolon). This filter is based on an OR concatenation. This means that when looking for multiple values a parameter will be shown if one of the values matches the filter.

Messages

Shows a list of warnings and errors that occurred during simulation for a given configuration.

Tip: If a configuration contains errors, it is marked red. If it contains warnings, it is marked yellow.

Errors

  • Errors should not occur when running a simulation for a given configuration. Errors are a clear sign of misconfiguration and must be avoided.
  • Local search heuristic can handle only one relevant system bus! For some reason more than one system bus were configured. Current heuristics cannot deal with the incurred complexities.
  • None of the system buses has a asset or load! For some reason the system has neither loads nor generators.
  • Dispatcher is starting the diesel without following ramp rate The dispatcher ignores the diesel constraints. This should not happen.
  • Power set point = < set-point > although diesel is in off state The dispatcher assigned a set-point to a generator without starting it. This should not happen.
  • Postprocessor: Could not write to DB; in function ... ISED could not write to the results DB-file. Tip: Maybe permissions or space restrictions on the hard disk cause this problem.
  • Simulation failed. For unknown reasons a simulation could not be performed. If prior error messages offer no explanation on why this happens, contact the support.
  • SOC below 0%. Physically impossible, cutting off Battery constraints were violated. This should not happen.
  • error( ) "temperature dynamics are too high for the chosen time step size! Reducing temperature gradient to at least stabilize simulation. Choose a smaller simulation step size!!"

Warnings

Warnings indicate that something happened that might indicate a problem. Please ignore warnings only if these underlying effects are thoroughly understood.

Problem with failure redundancy < n > requirement at time < t > is infeasible; reducing failure redundancy requirement For some reason the required failure redundancy could not be achieved at a given time step. The simulation just continues without fulfilling the requirement in this time step. Tip: Maybe too few diesel generators were configured for the load at hand.

Problem with satisfy all loads requirement at time < t > is infeasible; removing satisfy all loads requirement For some reason the required load (costumer load plus losses) could not be met. Load is being dropped this time step. This usually indicates significant problems. Tip: Maybe too few diesel generators were configured for the load at hand.

Could not solve dispatching problem at time < t > even without satisfying all loads requirement For some reason the dispatcher could not solve the local optimization problem, even when dropping load. Please analyze the output time- series in Seaview the indicated time step.

Using states with minimum and maximum number of active units If the dispatcher could not solve the local optimization problem at a given time step, it will select one of the following solutions

  • turn all generators off
  • turn all generators on

Time steps with infeasible n- < n > failure redundancy < no > Summary warning: Shows the number of time steps for which the redundancy requirement could not be met.

Time steps with load shedding < no > Summary warning: Shows the number of time steps for which the load could not be met.

Starting unit dispatch problem could not be solved; remaining power < no > [kW] Diesel constraints prevent the generator-group to start the required number of generators. Should not happen.

losses initialized negative value Wrong values for loss parameters.

Dispatcher tries to start an already started generator unit The dispatcher is out of sync with the asset-states. Should not happen.

Dispatcher tries to stop a generator unit which is not running The dispatcher is out of sync with the asset-states. Should not happen.

The current update interval for the cyclic ageing = < no > is smaller than 3 times the time step size for the update of the battery internal states The time step size is too large for the configured battery. Tip: Reduce time step size.

Cell power set point < no > W would lead to negative SOC. Fixing it at < no > W. The dispatcher is out of sync with the asset-states. Should not happen.

Battery cell temperature has risen beyond < no > degree Celsius. Fixing cell temperature at < no > degree Celsius. The battery became too hot during operation and must cool down. Tip: Consider having an HVAC asset

SOC turned below < no >. Fixing it at < no >. The minimal SOC was violated. Should not happen.

You might be using an old battery parameterization An old battery parameterization is used. This might cause inaccuracies. Tip: Use a battery parameterization from the current asset library.

You have configured a battery end of life smaller than 50%; this is unusual (60-80% are common) The end of life for the battery is unusually low. This might be due to the fact that old battery models did not have this parameter.

You have configured a battery end of life greater than 90%; this is unusual (60-80% are common) The end of life for the battery is unusually low. This might be due to the fact that old battery models did not have this parameter.

SOC exceeded current temperature-induced SOCmin!! The current estimated SOC is below the minimal SOC. This can happen if temperature changes rapidly. Tip: Consider having an HVAC asset

Current larger than I max! For some reason I max was violated. This should not happen.

Current smaller than I min! For some reason I max was violated. This should not happen.

SOC exceeded SOCmax!! The current estimated SOC is below the minimal SOC. This can happen if temperature changes rapidly. Tip: Consider having an HVAC asset

SOC exceeded absolute SOCmin!! The current estimated SOC is below the minimal SOC. This can happen if temperature changes rapidly. Tip: Consider having an HVAC asset

Battery temperature = < no > T max = < no >! Power limits = 0 will be enforced until battery cools down. The battery became too hot during operation and must cool down. Tip: Consider having an HVAC asset

Cannot open log file < filename > this file will not be written ISED could not write a log file. Tip: Maybe permissions or space restrictions on the hard disk cause this problem or a strange character set was used when creating the project's name.

KPI overview

  • Yearly or Monthly The economic and technical KPIs can be compared either yearly or monthly.
  • "<" and ">" Buttons KPIs can be unfolded with ">" button and folded with "<" button.
  • Selection Table Both economic and technical KPIs are shown in the table according to different assets, categories and units by choosing check boxes.
  • Update KPI selection Clicking this button can update the selected KPIs overview on the right side.

KPIs for Project Lifetime

Cash Flow KPIs

  • Capital cost All asset independent cost for setting up the system
  • Replacement cost Cost of replacements over lifetime.
  • Operating cost Operating and maintenance cost are based only on the rated power of the asset, not on the actual power produced. This means that specific costs (EUR/kWh) for OPEX are higher when assets are operated at part-load. This might be because less energy is produced for the same Operating and Maintenance costs, or that costs for Operating and Maintenance are non-linear for part loads.
  • Fuel cost Cost of Fuel
  • Salvage value Value of asset and the end of project lifetime. The Salvage value at installation is the replacement cost of the asset. As the asset ages, the salvage value is calculated with a linear drop in book value. Thus, if a GenSet with a rated lifetime of 200,000 hours has a service life of 150,000 hours at the end of the simulation, and if it would cost 1M EUR to replace, then it's salvage value is 0.25M EUR.
  • Total cost (Capital cost)+(Replacement cost)+(Operating cost)+(Fuel cost)+(Salvage value)

System Costs

Levelized Cost of Energy [LCoE] The levelized cost of Energy is given by the discounted relative cost of production of energy. The LCoE is calculated using the following formula. For more information, see also: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cost_of_electricity_by_source

Calculation of Levelized Cost of Energy [LCoE]

Where:

  • n: the project lifetime
  • r: the discount rate
  • System Costs: all costs including CAPEX, OPEX, Replacement, Fuels, Grid Import Costs, Non-conformance costs, ...
  • System Revenues: all revenues including Salvage Value (if included), Grid Export revenues, Ancialliary service revenues, ...
  • Revenues from Target Energy: Revenues from exports of the target energy type (e.g. electricity) to loads, grid exports, or EVs
  • Target energy leaving system: Loads + exports (does not include losses from inside the system)

This change applies to the following KPIs:

LCoE KPIs by AssetType

Technical KPIs Over All Assets

  • Total energy production Sum over all PV, Wind and Generator assets of Actual production
  • Total primary load consumption All energy consumed by costumer applications, excludes all loads created by the plant itself (sum of all requested load unmet electric load)
  • Renewable excess energy Sum over all PV and Wind assets of unused energy
  • Unmet electric load Request load that could not be satisfied
  • Total constant operational energy losses Sum over all PV, Wind, Battery and Generator assets of constant operational energy losses
  • Total dedicated converter losses Sum over all PV, Wind and Battery com- ponents of dedicated converter losses
  • Total permanent energy losses Sum over all PV, Wind, Battery and Genera- tor assets of permanent energy losses
  • Renewable energy share The share of energy that was generated from renewable sources. All energy types are considered. Losses are included.
  • Utilized renewable energy share The share of energy used for loads or exports that was generated from renewable sources. All energy types are considered. Losses are excluded.
  • Total carbon emissions with renewable exports The KPI Total carbon emissions with renewable exports includes an offset for CO2 emissions based the CO2 content of the grid and the amount of exported renewable energy. In each timestep, when PV and Wind combined exceed all electrical loads and is not used by other assets (i.e. heat pumps, electrolyzers), then it is exported. This exported energy is multiplied by the carbon content of the grid and summed over all timesteps as saved emissions. The saved emissions are then subtracted from the total carbon emissions. For projects with multiple electrical grid connections, the carbon content of the first grid in the equipment tab for dispatch is used for this emission calculation.

Renewable energy share considers only inputs of the system. Any energy conversions within a project are not explicitly considered in the calculation.
Utilized renewable energy share considers renewable inputs and useful outputs of the system. Useful outputs only include loads and exports.
Any energy conversions within a project are not explicitly considered in the calculation.

Seaview

Basic Functionality

Seaview is a trending tool to display the time series which can be either the input data or the output results. It helps users to verify their input data and check the simulation results. This tool is independent from ISED and can be separately opened to analysis available data.

User Interface Basics

Based on the functionality of Seaview, it can be activated either in "Resources Tab" or in "Result View" in ISED. Seaview can be opened with clicking button "View time series ..." in Resource Tab. In "Result View", Seaview can be opened with selecting "View Logs" in dropdown list to analyze the relevant configuration. The technology abbreviations in Seaview can be found here.

Seaview display window

The label in the upper left corner lists the available time series and some these time series can be set as default here. The input data or simulation results can be dragged from the label window into the trend display window on the right side.

In the right side of the Seaview UI, there are four drag areas:

  • Drag here for new plot If one of the results in label window is dragged here, a new time series plot will appear in the trend display window.
  • Drag here for new stacked plot If one of the results in label window is dragged here, a new stacked time series plot will appear in the trend display window.
  • Drag here for new CDF plot If one of the results in label window is dragged here, a new CDF plot will appear in the trend display window.
  • Drag here for new heatmap If one of the results in label window is dragged here, a new heatmap will appear in the trend display window.
  • On the left corner the Seaview UI contains two check boxes, five buttons and a monthly calendar:
  • show center labels Center labels are shown in the trend display windows when this box is selected.
  • Interpolate The results in the trend display window is interpolated when this box is selected.
  • Unique colors per plot If selected, then every time series for each asset type will have a unique color. Otherwise, all time series for each asset type will have the same default color.
  • zoom in Instead of mouse wheel, this button can be used to zoom in for the trend.
  • zoom out Instead of mouse wheel, this button can be used to zoom out for the trend.
  • save intervals Intervals in the trend display can be saved with this button.
  • load intervals Intervals in the trend display can be loaded with this button.
  • Calendar The date of the time series can be selected here.
  • save plots Plots are saved using this button.

Data Import

There are two possibilities to import the simulation results into the Seaview. The user can import the results either using the Result View or directly dragging the data files into the Seaview. As shown in the figure, a window is popped with a right click on the configuration in the Result View. The first option enables the user to select the data files from the target directory. The second option displays the simulated dispatch logs for different years. When the user selects one of these logs, the Seaview is opened and the selected logs are imported in Seaview. The trend tool Seaview can be also opened independently from ISED Simulation. Therefore, it is also possible to import the data directly into the Seaview. Currently, only the .txt and .csv data can be dragged in the tool. The simulation timestep and timeseries start day can be set when the data is imported.

Financial Tool

Overview

The Financial Tool supports analysis of the financial benefits for different configuration and stakeholder setups. It helps to quantify benefits, allowing the configuration that best meets a customer's needs to be identified. The Financial Tool is opened by clicking the icon in the upper left corner of the results view.

Select financial evaluation view

The figure below shows a schematic overview for the simulation of a customer project. After the project definition in step 1 and the simulation in step 2, in step 3 the financial evaluation is used to evaluate the potential financial benefit of specific configurations. The results of this analysis can be used to improve the project definition, creating an iterative process to find the best results.

Schematic overview for the simulation of a customer project

The Financial Tool is based on the concept shown in the figure below. If there are loads in the project, then they are assigned to the Offtaker. Assets can be owned by the Offtaker or by one or more Independent Power Producers (IPPs). The IPPs have a Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) with the Offtaker. The PPA consists of a tariff for each energy type that is exchanged.

Financial Tool Overview

A schematic overview of a typical stakeholder setup with only electrical assets is shown in figure below. Each stakeholder can have an electrical grid connection but does not have to. In the cases that multiple stakeholders have an electrical grid connection, each connection needs to be specifically defined in the project. This concept can be extended to cover other energy types.

Schematic overview of a typical stakeholder setup

The Financial Tool is based on the results from a ISED simulation. It uses the financial KPIs to define the cashflow for each configuration e.g. CAPEX, OPEX, fuel, replacement costs, imports, exports, and Non-Conformance Costs (NCCs). Stakeholders defined in the project can be assigned assets, so that specific business models can be evaluated. Energy is sold from one stakeholder to another via a PPA (Power Purchase Agreement) that defines the energy costs. In the financial evaluation a tariff must be flat (i.e. it is a constant value within a day, month, or year), and can be changed by a fixed percentage each year as defined in the annual escalation. While the cost of utility tariffs which include additional costs are modeled in the electric grid connection (e.g. demand charges, triads, atypical grid charges, etc.), tariffs in the Financial Tool consider only energy [kWh].

Tariffs are provided for the following energy types. No differentiation is made between multiple buses of the same energy type (in this case all amounts of energy that are the same type are added together):

  1. Electricity
  2. Steam
  3. Hot Water
  4. Cold Water
  5. Hydrogen

Escalation rates can be set for fuel, O&M costs, grid imports and tariffs. The 1st year flat tariff and annual escalation must be set for all but one energy types. For the energy type that is unfixed, the flat tariff is optimized to obtain the target benefit for the stakeholder e.g. "Target RoE" or "Target IRR before tax". A schematic overview is shown in the following figure.

Schematic Overview for Financial Tool

Stakeholders include:

  • Offtaker- The offtaker is the consumer of the energy. There can only be one offtaker in a project, and the offtaker is unique in that all loads must be assigned to it. Also, the offtaker has one tariff for each energy type to all other partners. Typical examples of an offtaker are utilities (who then distribute their energy to end users), a campus, hospital or university, an industry such as a mine or factory, etc.
  • IPP1 (Independent Power Producer 1) - An IPP is a company that owns and operates energy generation assets. Typically, its business model is to own and operate generation assets. In the Financial Tool it is assumed that an IPP aims to recuperate costs and make profit by selling energy via a PPA. It is possible that multiple IPPs operate in the same project. This may occur due to historical reasons (i.e. over time different IPPs establish operation) or due to specific competencies (i.e. an IPP may specialize in specific technologies).
  • Other: The user can define new stakeholders with appropriate names on the Project tab of ISED. Names can be freely defined. The functionality for new stakeholders will be like IPP1 in that they will have PPAs with the offtaker.

Assets are assigned to a stakeholder on the Equipment tab of ISED. Assets can be retrospectively moved between stakeholders on the Setup tab of the Financial Tool after a simulation is completed.

A high-level sensitivity analysis is provided for a quick evaluation of how important factors affect a project's financials. The following sensitivity parameters are available:

  • Fuel offset and annual escalation
  • O&M offset and annual escalation
  • External imports
  • Annual escalation for internal imports and exports

Financial Tool Layout

The Financial Tool has three tabs for Setup, Comparison and Analysis. These are further broken down as shown in following diagram.

Financial tool functional map

Financial Tool Header

Header

The following is shown in the Financial Tool Header:

  • Tab selection between Setup, Comparison and Analysis
  • Project name
  • Stakeholder selection: The checkboxes activate which stakeholders are shown.

In addition, the following are shown at the top of each tab:

  • Selected Configuration: The Selected Configuration determines which configuration is shown on the Setup and Analysis tabs, and in the Tariff window.
  • LCoE Energy: The LCoE is calculated for one energy type, this type can be selected in the dropdown in each tabs header. The values of all other energy types are defined by the user in the tariff structure. This selection is important because assets can create multiple energy types (e.g. a gas turbine produces electricity and steam), or convert one energy type to another (e.g. an absorption chiller converts heat to cooling or a compression chiller converts electricity to cooling), then this is accounted for in the LCoE calculation.

Setup Tab

Overview

The Financials tab allows the user to

  • Define the overall project values (currency, time, tax rate)
  • Change ownership of assets
  • Define the financial structure for each stakeholder
  • Setup the tariff structure and target optimization for each stakeholder, and
  • Modify inputs from the ISED simulation.

All numbers with white background are inputs, all other values are results.

Upper Window

The parameters in the upper window set the common project values and therefore apply to all configurations and stakeholders.

Currency

  • The currency including a fixed exchange rate and 3 letter alphabetic currency code can be manually set. All financial values are multiplied by this value and shown with the currency code.

Year of production start

  • The year in which energy production commences. The financial analysis assumes the exact date to be the 1st of January of this year.

Construction time

  • The number of years it takes to build the power plant. CAPEX is assumed to be spent equally over this time. The construction time is not considered in the project simulation for ISED.

Production time

  • The number of years the plant is assumed to be operational. This is the period considered for the IRR/RoE calculations. If this is shorter than the specified Project lifetime, all additional data in later years (including possible salvages values) are ignored.

Reference Configuration:

  • The Reference Configuration represents the alternative configuration for an end-customer if a DES project does not proceed. For a brown-field project this will be the existing equipment, and for a green-field project, or when the customer has already decided to upgrade or replace equipment, it represents the likely alternative. The reference configuration is used to calculate:
    • NPV of offtaker savings compared to reference
    • Offtaker savings compared to reference
    • Cumulative savings compared to reference
    • Carbon saved (t/year)

Corporate Tax

  • The rate at which profits are taxed. "Corporate Tax". This is the same for all stakeholders.

Modify Inputs

Modify Inputs

A button is provided to open a window that allows viewing and modification of all inputs from the simulation results to the Financial Tool. Examples of where it may make sense to use this function include updating CAPEX or O&M costs from supplier quotes. Specific costs that occur for limited configurations could also be quickly updated. Care is needed as a user can change any input without any checks or restrictions.

If a value is modified, then the new value is shown next to the original input value from the simulation in brackets. The new value is used throughout the Financial Tool

The main functions included in the Modify inputs window include:

Filters

  • Filters for Configuration name, Asset, KPI and Unit allow easy viewing of relevant information. Multiple filters can be used simultaneously. The Clear filters removes all filters

Hide null values

  • Hides any rows that only contains 0 values.

Hide non-modified values

  • Hides any rows that have not been modified.

Copy filtered table

  • Copies the values to the windows clipboard. This can then be pasted in other programs such as Excel for editing.

Reset values

  • Resets all values that have been modified back to their original value from the simulation.

Tariff Optimization

The following three options are provided for tariff optimization for all stakeholders except the offtaker (from hereon called IPPs or Independent Power Producers).

  • Roe - Return on Equity
  • IRR - Internal Rate of Return
  • Fixed Tariff

Individual project internal tariffs for each energy type (electricity, steam, hot water, cold water and hydrogen) are provided to and from the offtaker and each IPP. When RoE or IRR is chosen as a target optimization for an IPP, then all but one tariff must be fixed. First, all inputs in the Financial Tool (including escalation rates, debt structure, sensitivity analysis, etc.) are applied to the results of a ISED simulation. Then an optimization automatically sets the unfixed tariff to meet each IPPs investment goal. If an IPP has a fixed tariff as the optimization target, then the RoE and IRR are defined and shown as a result. Note that all tariffs are given for year 1 and have their own annual escalation rate.

The offtaker is a special stakeholder because it has all loads assigned to it. In general energy is an input to an offtakers business case and the loads create value for the customer (i.e. an industrial process, lighting, heating and cooling for customers at a shopping mall or students at a university, etc.). This business case and revenue is in not represented in ISED, therefore it is not possible to talk about RoE or IRR for the offtaker. Instead, the financial impact on the offtaker of each configuration compared to the reference are used as a measure, specifically as the Net Present Value and Offtaker Savings.

Target RoE

The Return on Equity (RoE) calculates the stakeholders equity benefit. It is the discounted rate at which the NPV of dividends is equal to the equity investment for a stakeholder over the project lifetime.

The definition of RoE is as follows

Where:

  • N = number of production years
  • En = equity investment for every year (n) where production start (year 1) =0
  • Dn = dividends payed for every year (n) where production start (year 1) = 0
  • r = the RoE

The unfixed tariff is solved so that the sum of the above equation above equation over the project lifetime = 0 for the stakeholder.

More information on how the dividends are calculated can be found in the section on fund utilization.

Target IRR after tax

The Internal Rate of Return (IRR) calculates the stakeholders overall investment benefit. It is the discounted rate at which the configurations NPV of a stakeholder would be 0 EUR over the project lifetime.

The definition of IRR is as follows:

Where:

  • N = number of production years
  • Cn = cash flow for every year (n) where production start (year 1) =0
  • Y = number of construction years
  • r = the IRR

The unfixed tariff is solved so that the sum of the above equation above equation over the project lifetime = 0 for the stakeholder.

Assets

The Assets section shows the ownership structure of the project, which is initially defined on the Equipment tab of ISED. Stakeholders that are defined in ISED and have assets assigned to them are shown in the Financial Tool. In addition to visualizing ownership, it is also possible to drag and drop an asset to a different stakeholder to evaluate different ownership structures. The only restriction is that loads must remain with the offtaker.

Example of assets in a project

Financing

The "Financing" parameters define how financing for each configuration and stakeholder.

CAPEX

  • For each stakeholder, costs for the initial installation of equipment for the selected configuration are shown. This includes installation costs for any equipment with a delayed installation, and it does not include equipment that replaces equipment that reaches end of life as defined by the replacement strategy. For assets with a delayed installation, disbursement takes place in the 6-month period before assets go online.

CAPEX reduction

  • This value allows a quick sensitive analysis by reducing the CAPEX for all configurations of a stakeholder by a fixed percentage. Positive (CAPEX reduction) and negative (CAPEX increase) values are possible.

Additional costs

  • Costs that fall outside of the equipment CAPEX. This might be developer costs, land costs, etc. 'Additional costs' are applied to all configurations.

Direct costs

  • The summation of all CAPEX with CAPEX reduction and additional costs for the selected configuration. This is the sum that needs to be financed for a configuration. "Direct costs" are specific for each configuration.

Grants

  • Money that is gifted to the project without cost, for example from a government or NGO. A grant does not require to be paid back or incur interest repayments. "Grants" are applied to all configurations except for the configuration that is selected defined as the "reference" in the ISED simulation.

Equity Share

  • The percentage of the initial financing (CAPEX, additional costs, and grants) that is to be provided by the owners (or shareholders). "Equity share" is applied to all configurations.

Equity

  • The money that is provided by the owners (or shareholders). This value is determined by the following equation:

    Equity typically has the highest risk, and in the event of project failure will be repaid last. "Equity" is specific each configuration.

Credit

  • The money that is borrowed as debt. This is typically money that the bank provides but may also come from other lenders. Credit normally has the lowest risk, and in the event of project failure will be repaid first. "Credit" is specific for each configuration.

Credit Share

  • The relative share of credit in financing. The credit share is 100% - Equity Share

Credit Buffer

  • It is normal practice to secure more credit than what is expected to be needed. This allows unexpected expenses to be covered. The credit buffer allows a percent value to be set for this.

RoE for WACC

  • The Return on Equity (RoE) is used in the WACC calculation; however, if a fixed tariff is set or the target optimization is IRR, then RoE is not explicitly defined. It is therefore shown with the WACC calculation. The Target RoE and RoE for WACC are always kept consistent (i.e. if one is changed, the other is automatically updated to the new value). As described in the section Tariff Optimization, the offtaker cannot have a target RoE. The RoE for WACC is used for their WACC calculation.

    The "Weighted Average Capital Cost" (WACC) represents the cost of financing for a stakeholder. It is used throughout the analysis as a discounting factor.

Debt

The "Debt" parameters are used to define how the debt for a plant's construction organized.

Interest rate

  • The yearly interest rate paid on the debt. The interest rate is assumed to be fixed for the period of the loan. The "Interest rate" applied to all configurations.

Repayment period

  • The number of years used to pay back the debt by principal payments. The principal payments are assumed to be evenly distributed over the repayment period. The "Repayment period" is specific for a stakeholder and is applied to all configurations.

Grace period

  • The number of years for which initially no principal payments are due. The grace period starts at the beginning of the construction period and is typically used to bridge the time until generation and associated revenues start. The "Grace period" is applied to all configurations.

Commitment fee

  • The yearly fee due for the credit allocated but not yet disbursed. This means for the entire credit during the grace period (normally the construction period) and the credit for equipment that has a delayed installation. The "Commitment fee" is applied to all configurations.

Upfront fee

  • An initial one-time fee for taking the credit. The "Upfront fee" is applied to all configurations.

Tariffs

Tariff and Escalation rate

  • Tariffs define the price of energy sold internally in a project, either from an IPP to the offtaker, or vice versa. A typical stakeholder setup is shown in figure Schematic overview of a typical stakeholder setup. All internal tariffs must be to or from the offtaker, creating a star-shaped topology for multiple IPPs. Tariffs between IPPs are not possible. Tariffs will only be shown for energy types that are in the project. All tariff values are shown for the first year with an escalation value in percent.

    1. Tariffs for the same energy type from an IPP to the offtaker may be different for each IPP.
    2. The tariff for an energy type from the Offtaker must be the same to all IPPs.
    3. Any stakeholder (offtaker or IPP) can export externally if the external network connection is assigned to them.
    4. For IPPs that use the Target RoE or Target IRR after Tax, one energy type tariff from a stakeholder to the offtaker must be left unfixed, this will be automatically set to meet the target.
    5. The user must set the value of all other tariffs,
    6. The user must set escalation rates for all tariffs

Fix

  • The user chooses which energy can be optimized to meet either the Target RoE or Target IRR after Tax with the selection boxes in fix.

Reserve Accounts

The Reserve Accounts parameters allow users to configure the reserve accounts setup. Reserve accounts allow the project operator to put aside money for costs that occur during daily business. This ensures that the ongoing liquidity of the project is maintained and that the project does not go bankrupt. It is possible that a project has a very good return over the project lifetime; however, this is not useful if the project fails early due to liquidity problems. Reserve accounts are generally expert parameters that do not need to be changed during a typical project.

A waterfall model is used for the Financial Tool. This model uses a predefined priority for costs to be met. On a 6-monthly basis, available funds are used to meet running costs, then Total Debt service, then to complete the Working Capital Account and reserve accounts. Any remaining funds are then paid out as dividends. This can be seen schematically in the following figure.

Waterfall model to determine fund utilization

WCA

  • The "Working Capital Account" contains funds to cover the upcoming operational cost for the plant. The user can specify the timespan in months for which reserve must be retained. This value is then accumulated and maintained. As defined in the waterfall model, it is funded after debt service payments are met. The interest in the WCA is then revenue accrued by the stakeholder. This means that the balance held in the WCA earns interest at the rate determined by the user. The WCA is recalculated for every 6-month period. At the end of the project the WCA is left to run down to zero. Project lifetime is 20 years and construction time is 2 years in the below graph. WCA value is shown for the end of the last 6-month period of each year.

    Example of a typical WCA with different monthly requirements

DSRA

  • The "Debt Service Reserve Account" (DSRA) ensures that the required funds for capital and interest payments for the coming 6 months are available. As defined in the waterfall model, it is funded from the cashflow available after debt service and WCA payments are met. The interest in the DSRA is revenue accrued for the stakeholder. This means that the balance held in the DSRA earns interest at the rate determined by the user. The DSRA is recalculated for every 6-month period. In the last 6-month financing period the DSRA is left to run down to zero. Project lifetime is 20 years and construction time is 2 years in the below graph. DSRA value is shown for the end of the last 6-month period of each year.

    Example of a typical DSRA with different coverage values

    (Please note that Capital expenditure have been limited to 2,000T to allow better visualization of the graph in the figure .)

RCRA

  • The "Replacement Cost Reserve Account" (RCRA) anticipates the total capital requirements for replacement investments until the end of the project. As defined in the waterfall model, the RCRA is filled from the cashflow available after debt service, WCA and DSRA. and builds up over time and then maintains a specific share of this. CAPEX investments that occur later in the project are not included in the RCRA; this is counted in the initial credit. The user can define what share of the total replacement cost (from the respectively current period until the last period) must be on its balance in each period. When the replacement is more than what is in the RCRA then the difference is met from running costs. The interest in the RCRA is then revenue accrued by the stakeholder. This means that the balance held in the RCRA earns interest at the rate determined by the user. The RCRA is recalculated for every 6-month period. With the last replacement the RCRA is left to run down to zero. Project lifetime is 20 years and construction time is 2 years in the below graph. RCRA value is shown for the end of the last 6-month period of each year.

    Example of a typical RCRA with different coverage values

Graphs - General function

Graphs General function The graphs on the Comparison and Analysis tab have the following functionality:

Example showing the general functionality of a typical graph layout
  • The stakeholders selected in the Financial Tool header are shown (red box)
  • Any item in the legend can be hidden or made visible by clicking on it (green box)
  • The mouse scroll when the mouse is over a graph can be used to zoom in or out. A button is provided on the bottom right to reset to the original zoom (grey box)
  • Thumbnails of other relevant graphs are shown to the right (orange box)
  • An Inspect button is provided at the bottom right. This opens a full window view of the graph (purple box). Within this window:
    • The user can view or hide the input data with the tick-box "Display table data"
    • he input data can be copied to the windows clipboard. This can then be pasted in other programs such as Excel for editing.
    • The Close button is always at the top right, this returns the user to the original view
  • To allow easy differentiation of stakeholders, different patterns are used. The offtaker is solid, IPP has right sloping diagonals, IPP2 left sloping, etc.

Tariffs

Below each graph, the tariff window can be opened and closed. Within the tariff window the same values as in the Tariff section of the Setup tab can be viewed and edited. (pink window)

Sensitivity Analysis

Inputs for the general sensitivity analysis are shown on the bottom right (brown window)

The "Sensitivity Analysis" parameters allow the user to quickly evaluate the sensitivity of the simulation to costs parameters, including Fuel, O&M, and Grid imports for all energy types. The offset and escalation values are applied to the cashflow of each configuration. An offset is a constant amount that is applied to every year and does not change over time. An escalation is a percentage that is applied each year and accumulates over time. The sensitivity analysis is in addition to annual multipliers. If both are used, then the effects are additive.

It is important to note that the project is not re-simulated; therefore, there is no change in the economic dispatch. This means that if changes in the sensitivity values mean that a different dispatch would be optimal. This is not reflected in the results in the financial evaluation. For significant changes the project setup should be updated and re-simulated to ensure that new values from the sensitivity analysis are correctly handled.

  • Fuel offset and annual escalation. This helps investigate the global effect of change fuel prices. Global means that the offset and escalation are added to all fuels and all stakeholders.
  • O&M offset and annual escalation - global effect of changing OPEX values for all assets and stakeholders.
  • a. External imports - affects all external connections e.g. electrical grid connections, district heating and cooling, H2 Networks. The offset is applied only to imports (i.e. EUR/kWh), the escalation is for both imports and exports and affects the financial value (i.e. % of EUR)

Comparison Tab

The Comparison tab visualizes the results for each configuration. This allows the comparison of different configurations for each view.

Configuration selection

The configurations selected in the Configurations window are shown (blue box)

Generation

The first-year generation breakdown for each configuration is shown. In each graph:

  • Only the energy types in the project are shown
  • One energy type is shown in each graph
  • Positive values are generation and imports
  • Negative values are losses, exports and inputs to assets that generate energy (e.g. the input steam to a steam turbine is shown as negative)
  • LCoE values for the target LCoE energy are shown for each stakeholder in a configuration

Cashflow

Graphs are shown for the summation of costs over the project lifetime. The following three graphs are shown:

  • Project total revenue and expenses CAPEX, O&M, replacement and salvage costs, internal and external imports and exports, fuel purchases
  • Project capital expenditure (CAPEX) the CAPEX of equipment that is installed over the project lifetime. This does not include replacement costs.
  • Operating expenditure (OPEX) O&M, replacement and salvage costs, internal and external imports (but not exports), fuel purchases

Financial

Important financial Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are shown:

  • Net present value of Offtaker savings compared to reference. This shows the relative financial benefit of each configuration compared to the reference configuration selected in the Financial Tool (note that this is not necessarily the reference in the sproject).

    This is stakeholder based calculation rather than a project value, and is based on the fund utilization, and is defined as:

    This calculates the monetary savings for the Offtaker compared to the reference, it is not a project value.

  • 1st year PPA for target energy The value of the target LCoE energy calculated for the 1st year PPA.

  • Levelized Cost of Energy (LCoE) for (X) The LCoE shows the average cost of energy over the project lifetime, discounted by the WACC to the present value. X is the target LCoE energy selected in the tab. LCoE values for each stakeholder in a configuration will be shown.

    The energy production includes energy exported to the offtaker, exports to external networks (e.g. electrical grid connection or District Heating or Cooling, H2 export), losses, and conversions between energy types(e.g. electricity to H2 in a Electrolyzer).

    The cost of production is what the stakeholder incurs including CAPEX, OPEX, fuel, replacement, and financing. Both energy production and costs are discounted with the stakeholders WACC.

    The cost is reduced by all revenues (e.g. exports to external energy networks, exports to stakeholders, ancillary services, ...) except export revenue for the target LCoE energy type.

  • Return on Equity (RoE) The Return on Equity for all IPPs in a configuration. Note that the Offtaker is not shown as their business case is not directly calculated in the Financial Evaluation.
  • Internal Rate of Return after tax (IRR after tax) The IRR after tax is shown for all IPPs in a configuration. Note that the Offtaker is not shown as their business case is not directly calculated in the Financial Tool.
  • Payback period The period required for the equity of an IPP to be repaid by dividends. Note that the Offtaker is not shown as their business case is not directly calculated in the Financial Tool.

Environmental

The environmental impact for each configuration is shown for:

  • First year carbon emissions show the tons of CO2 produced by each configuration in the first year. The amount of CO2 produced is calculated by the amount of fuel used and its carbon content, as well as the carbon content for energy imported by an external energy network.
  • First year renewable share the percentage of loads met by renewable assets. Renewable fuels and external energy networks are defined in the ISED project. Wind and PV are always considered to be renewable.

Analysis

The Analysis tab visualizes the results for the Selected configuration (found in the upper toolbar). The x-axis of charts show the year, this value is set by the Year of production start and Construction time on the Setup tab.

Results

Key results for the selected configuration are shown on the upper-right window.

First year PPA

  • The first year PPA for the target LCoE energy type from each IPP to the Offtaker.

LCoE

  • The Levelized Cost of Energy (generation) is given by the discounted relative cost of production of energy for the plant owner. A full description is given in Financial.

Return on Equity

  • Return on Equity refers to the investors benefit on their investment, and refers to the dividend returns relative to the equity investment. The IRR calculation is described in detail in Tariff Optimization.

IRR (after tax)

  • The Internal Rate of Return after Tax is an indicator to measure the financial return on investment of a project, often favored by providers of debt (e.g. banks). The IRR calculation is described in detail in Tariff Optimization.

IRR (before tax)

  • The Internal Rate of return before tax is another KPI to measure the financial return on investment of a project, without tax payments. The IRR calculation is described in detail in Tariff Optimization.

Payback period

  • Payback period is the amount of time required to for the accumulated dividend payments to exceed the initial investment. This is measured after production start. The payback period is independent of the WACC. If a replacement is made after this point and the RCRA is not large enough to cover the replacement costs, then the first time that it is positive is considered.

Break even period

  • Break even period is when the cumulative project revenue is equal or greater to the project costs. This is the number of years after production start after which the accumulated net cashflow is first positive. It is therefore dependent on the WACC. If a replacement is made after this point and the RCRA is not large enough to cover the replacement costs, the cumulative net cashflow will return to a negative value. In this case the first time that it is positive is considered.

Sensitivity Analysis

Inputs for the general sensitivity analysis are shown on the bottom right. A description is given in Sensitivity analysis.

Summary

The Summary tab provides a simple overview of the financial and environmental impact of a configuration compared to the selected reference configuration. There are three main views:

Average annual generation breakdown shows a percentage visualization how different energy was produced for both the reference and selected configuration and their renewable share.

Average annual CO2 reduction shows the amount of CO2 produced in the reference and selected configuration, including the difference in CO2 saved in tons/year.

Financial benefit shows the cumulative offtaker savings and the cumulative net cashflow for the IPPs.

Generation

The generation breakdown for each year is shown. In each graph:

  • Only the energy types in the project are shown
  • One energy type is shown in each graph
  • Positive values are generation and imports
  • Negative values are losses, exports and inputs to assets that generate energy (e.g. the input steam to a steam turbine is shown as negative)

The Energy flow to others graph shows the energy sold within PPA (tariffs) in the configuration.

Cashflow

Revenue and expenses for configuration "x"

Example showing the typical graph for Revenue and expenses for configuration x

Configuration x is selected in the dropdown menu at the top right of the graph (see red).

Buttons are provided to help activate and deactivate groups of interest (see blue). These are:

  1. Annual expenses, which includes CAPEX, O&M, replacement, fuel costs, costs for internal and external imports, and carbon tax
  2. Annual revenues, which includes revenues from internal and external exports, salvage, and renewable incentives

  3. Net cashflow, which includes:

    1. The Offtaker net cashflow (annual revenues annual expenses),
    2. The Offtaker (annual) savings (Offtaker net cashflow in configuration Offtaker net cashflow in selected reference), and
    3. The net cashflow for each IPP (annual revenues annual expenses)

  4. Cumulative net cashflow. Note that these are shown on the secondary (right hand) axis, because they are typically an order of magnitude larger than the other values. This includes:

    1. The Offtaker cumulative net cashflow (summation of the Offtaker net cashflow),
    2. The Offtaker (annual) savings (summation of the Offtaker savings), and
    3. The cumulative net cashflow for each IPP (the sum of the net cashflow for each IPP)

As with all graphs, any elements can be hidden or shown by clicking on them in the legend.

Cashflow

  • The cashflow graph shows:

    1. Net cashflow, which includes:

      1. The Offtaker net cashflow (annual revenues annual expenses),
      2. The Offtaker (annual) savings (Offtaker net cashflow in configuration Offtaker net cashflow in selected reference), and
      3. The net cashflow for each IPP (annual revenues annual expenses)

    2. Cumulative net cashflow. Note that these are shown on the secondary (right hand) axis, because they are typically an order of magnitude larger than the other values. This includes:

      1. The Offtaker (annual) savings (summation of the Offtaker savings), and
      2. The cumulative net cashflow for each IPP (the sum of the net cashflow for each IPP)

Free cashflow

  • The free cashflow shows what is invested as equity, what is returned as dividends, and any salvage costs. This represents the money that the IPP must invest, and what is returned as income.

Financial

Fund utilization for configuration x

  • Fund utilization for configuration x shows how expenses are met based on a predetermined prioritization. As shown in the waterfall model below, immediate expenses including tax, O&M, fuel and imported energy costs, replacements and non-conformance costs are met. This is followed by debt repayments, then the WCA, the DSRA and the RCRA. Any additional money is then paid out as dividends.
Waterfall model to determine fund utilization

Inflation

All escalation rates are considered to include inflation. A specific inflation value is not available.
